TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, I inform the Senate that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Gareth Evans, will be absent from question time today, tomorrow and Wednesday. Senator Evans is currently in Paris leading the delegation of ministers from South Pacific Forum nations making representations to the French government on the resumption of nuclear testing in the South Pacific. In Senator Evans's absence I will be acting as Leader of the Government in the Senate, and Senator McMullan will take questions on foreign affairs.

—My question is directed to the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: is it not true that France's decision to resume nuclear testing was foreshadowed by Jacques Chirac as early as 17 March this year in the lead-up to the presidential elections? Also, after his election, is it not true that there was much media speculation that he would make an announcement in the terms he subsequently did? But was it not the case that, in the meantime, your government failed to take any action to put Australia's point of view on this matter? In particular, why were not delegations and other diplomatic actions mounted of the type that are now being mounted subsequent to the announcement? What were you doing in the meantime, when there was a chance—when there was still an opportunity perhaps—to influence France away from this particular course of action?

—The answer to part one of Senator Hill's question is yes, and the answer to part two is yes. Senator Gareth Evans wrote to the French government on this particular issue, as did the Prime Minister. Senator Evans also, when he was in France some weeks ago—
—Did you release that letter at the time?

—No, we do not release every letter that we write to other governments, Senator Alston. Maybe you will do that if you ever get into government, but governments rarely do. Mr President, it is my understanding that Senator Evans raised this question with the then foreign minister, subsequently now Prime Minister, Alain Juppe, while he was in France, and I know I also did so when I was in France for the VE celebrations. Any Australian minister that was in France at that particular period raised the question of nuclear testing and how seriously we in Australia regarded it. So the basis for Senator Hill's question, of course, is wrong.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Isn't it not surprising, therefore, that if, on the one hand, the French government had what might be called form representations, a letter from the foreign minister, they knew that Australia was not serious on this matter when, at the same time, the Prime Minister of our country was writing to the French endorsing their bid to join the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council?
—Well, why not?

—Because you are sending inconsistent messages. Obviously you are not serious about this issue. The question is this: in writing to the French inviting them to join Pacific regional organisations at a time when you knew they were going to make an announcement to resume tests, does that not demonstrate that your letter to the French President and the communications with the French foreign minister were simply a matter of form and that, in fact, no serious effort at all was made by the Australian government to dissuade the French from the action that they have now taken?

—One does not normally take punitive action before a French, or any other, government makes a particular decision. The government made clear its position on these particular issues, as it has for a number of years—reluctantly and finally joined, I may say, by the opposition. You only have to go back to the parliamentary debates of 1985 and 1986 and look at what the opposition spokesmen, Mr Downer and Mr Peacock, said at the time to see how little support we have had over the years from the opposition. It accused us of running interference with the United States policy when we brought these issues up at the United Nations. When a nuclear-free South Pacific was up we got exactly no support from those opposite and now they lecture us on how we should handle our relations with France. We made it quite clear to the French government, as did other countries in this region, that we oppose the resumption of nuclear testing in this region. We made it absolutely clear. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Last Friday the Minister launched the national wilderness inventory. Can he inform the Senate about the inventory's findings and can he tell us how this information will be used?

—The national wilderness inventory is a database containing measures of wilderness quality across the entire Australian continent. This is the first time in the world that this sort of mapping has been done at such a level. There is both good news and bad news from the inventory. The good news is that, unlike most countries, Australia still retains large areas of wilderness, and it gives us options for conservation which are the envy of most other countries. The bad news is that the wilderness does not include all the ecosystems which were represented in Australia. Most of the wilderness areas that remain are either desert or very arid.

PARA.TAB: The inventory is a flexible decision-making tool that can assist scientists and administrators in monitoring wilderness loss, delineating wilderness areas, defining management options and predicting the effects of development on wilderness areas. It can also be used to assess the benefits of wilderness restoration proposals. For example, the inventory could stimulate the improvement in wilderness quality if a road or other structure were removed from a wilderness area. This improvement could then be assessed against the cost of such a proposal.

The inventory can be used to help identify boundaries for wilderness reserves and for developing management plans in those areas. While the national wilderness inventory does not in itself define these boundaries, it can provide invaluable information to state and territory governments when they make decisions. The inventory will also be used for evaluating forest areas for the 1996 woodchip licences. Data from the national wilderness inventory is also being used in the compilation of Australia's state of the environment report. Work is also currently being undertaken with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to adapt the national wilderness inventory methods for marine environments.

The national wilderness inventory model is also being utilised on an international scale. For example, an international consortium has completed a survey of the Barents Sea region in northern Scandinavia and north-west Russia using national wilderness inventory methods. This study is likely to be extended to the entire Artic region and possibly all of Europe. Interest has also been expressed by both US and Canadian agencies.

It is important to acknowledge that a lot of the data used in the national wilderness inventory has been provided by state and territory governments. Their involvement means that it is truly a national achievement, not just a Commonwealth inventory. This is particularly important because the land use decisions of the state governments are the ones which have the greatest impact on wilderness areas.

This inventory is an exciting landmark development in Australia's environmental management. I think it will become an invaluable tool for decision makers in Australia. I congratulate all those who have been involved over a very long time in its development.

If they have been able to effect an improvement under our system, what on earth would your system mean—that they would not make that choice and there would not be that improvement? —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask: what is the Australian government's response to recent media reports which suggest that the United States is now considering the resumption of underground nuclear testing? Secondly, in view of the huge environmental implications, the fact that China has never ceased nuclear testing and that France is now resuming it, does the government recognise the role of its uranium export policy—a policy, I might add, which is shared by the opposition—in the cause and effect relationship between the mining and export of uranium and the resumption of French nuclear testing in the Pacific? Finally, does this potential escalation on the part of the world's nuclear powers undermine the strength and validity of last month's agreement to indefinitely extend the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, particularly the commitment that right now nuclear weapons states should exercise the utmost restraint?

—The government has said repeatedly and emphatically that we are absolutely opposed to nuclear testing by any state. Therefore, we are disturbed by reports that US Defense Secretary Perry has said that the US is considering the possibility of the resumption of nuclear testing. It would be inconsistent with the strong leadership President Clinton has given to the conclusion of the comprehensive test ban treaty, and we are seeking clarification of Secretary Perry's comments.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to assume at this stage that he has been accurately reported. There is debate about some issues that might have been misunderstood to have led to a suggestion from him that there might be a proposal for the US resumption of nuclear testing, so I am not yet accepting that it is true. But if it is true, we would oppose it emphatically—as we would do of anybody—but I am not assuming it is true. More likely than not, in my view, it is not. But if it is, we oppose the US doing that.

Nevertheless, you are correct that China continues its testing and France is proposing to resume its testing. I cannot accept that in any way the export of Australian uranium is contributing to that. Our export is only to countries which are members of the non-proliferation treaty and with which we have a bilateral nuclear safeguards agreement, which is designed to ensure that Australian uranium does not end up in nuclear weapons programs or for purposes of nuclear weapons.

With regard to your third question concerning the non-proliferation treaty, the non-proliferation treaty is the single most important arms control and disarmament treaty we have. It is the only internationally legally binding instrument which commits nuclear weapons states to the goal of disarmament. That is why the French decision to resume testing is a breach of faith, including the point concerning utmost restraint to which you referred in your question, Senator Kernot. It is a breach of faith with all of those countries which supported indefinite extension of the NPT without a vote in New York last month. What is more, it could have an adverse effect on the climate of the comprehensive test ban treaty negotiations.

We have made this point very strongly to France. We will be working to ensure that the CTBT negotiations do conclude as scheduled in 1996 and that France does live up to its undertaking, repeated by President Chirac, that it would sign that comprehensive test ban treaty and, therefore, at that stage, cease nuclear testing forever.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for that answer. I now ask: can we sit here and accept that what has been entered into with the nuclear non-proliferation treaty has the sort of moral support to continue, or do we ask why eight tests are better than ten, 11 or 12, if there is to be more of them?

—There are two important points in that question and I cannot answer them both in a minute. It is important that the nuclear non-proliferation treaty continues because, imperfect as it is, it is the only operative constraint, particularly on the proliferation of nuclear weapons. That is one of the reasons why, to the extent that the French initiative undermines the treaty and undermines French commitment to utmost restraint, this decision is so deplorable. It is one of the grounds—although not the only ground—on which the decision should be condemned. It is also one of the points I made to the French ambassador when I called him in on behalf of the Australian government.

PARA.TAB: As to whether it is better to have fewer tests than more—yes, it is. The preferred number is zero but the smaller the number of tests, the better.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the minister to previous statements he has made on the need to facilitate the travel to Australia of business people who need to come here on short-term visits, and the need for speedy processing of their visas. The announcement last month of a new, multiple entry visa category for business visitors was one of a number of welcomed reforms in this area. Can the minister inform the Senate of any further moves to streamline immigration processing for business visitors?

—I thank Senator Childs for his question. He is right; this issue has been of interest to the business community for quite some time, particularly because that community is concerned to maximise business and economic opportunities in today's global economic environment. With Australian businesses interacting more than ever before with the region and the rest of the world, it is imperative that immigration processes facilitate that interaction and not impede it.

PARA.TAB: We do have a reform agenda in this area. As some senators would be aware, the government has already implemented a number of significant reforms in the area of permanent business migration. Those changes are now in place. But temporary migration is also of critical importance. In the area of temporary entry, as Senator Childs has already pointed out, there is a raft of reforms, some already implemented, some planned for the future—reforms all together intended to make it much easier for business to do business overseas.

For example, in the budget it was announced that the government would introduce a single visa class for business people, and that business visitors would have the option of applying for visas in a free one-month category, a three-month multiple entry category, valid for five years or the duration of their passport, or a more than three months category. The latest initiative, which will come into effect on a trial basis next month, is designed to streamline the process even further, particularly for international business visitors nominated by selected corporations and state governments.

Initially operating as a pilot program, this option will be available to the Queensland and Northern Territory governments and five or six large corporations. In essence, it will work on the basis that the people nominated will not need to complete an application form themselves, nor will they need to provide their passports to our overseas posts. In turn, nominators will provide the business people's passport details and other relevant data to my department's Brisbane office. Once a decision has been made, the evidence will be returned to the nominator. A visa granted under this particular provision will be for a three-month stay and will be valid for four years for a $35 fee.

This will be a pilot program but we intend to extend it in two ways by the end of the year. From November this year the option will be extended to nominated business visitors in the new budget initiative of a three-month multiple entry category. Secondly, at that time we intend to expand this initiative to cover all state and territory governments and it is also expected to involve a larger number of corporations. We have been liaising with the Business Council of Australia on the latter point.

The government has a firm agenda in this area to ensure that migration processes open up Australian business initiatives, not close them. As part of the initiatives in this area, I have asked Mr Neville Roach, the managing director of Fujitsu, to conduct a wide ranging review of temporary entry for business people. Once we receive his review—hopefully that will be in the not too distant future—we will be in a better position to make even greater changes to this particular area.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. Is the government considering amending the Hazardous Waste (Regulation of Imports and Exports) Act to exactly replicate Australia's obligations under the Basel convention? Is it correct that the government is considering watering down the act's provisions from explicit and strictly defined provisions requiring all waste to be `disposed of safely' to more vague and weaker phrases such as `all practicable steps are taken to ensure environmentally sound management of waste'?

—The main reason for amending the act is to ensure that the legislation gives full and thorough effect to our obligations under the Basel convention. As part of that we are, wherever possible, adopting the phrasing that is used in the convention itself. For this reason, we are dropping the phrase `dispose of safely' from the act and replacing it with the words `environmentally sound management' which is the phrase that is used in the convention. Given that the scope of the act will be very significantly extended to pick up a wide range of hazardous waste which it currently excludes, it is not clear how this could be interpreted in any way as a weakening at all. In fact the definition of `environmentally sound management', like any such phrase, including the phrase `dispose of safely', could be interpreted with differing degrees of stringency.

PARA.TAB: I can say to Senator Chamarette that I will be ensuring that we do not export our hazardous waste to other countries unless we are sure that it will be managed in an environmentally sound manner and that human health and the environment will be fully protected. There are international processes already established to provide guidance on what is in fact environmentally sound management. In Australia there will be a broadly representative and qualified technical group under the amended act to advise me on what in fact constitutes environmentally sound management.

The other point worth saying in relation to this particular issue is that this bill will be coming very shortly before the Senate. Senator Chamarette and other honourable senators will have an opportunity to examine all these issues in detail at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The minister has just admitted that there is going to be a change to the existing act and a lowering of standards to comply with the Basel convention. How does the government justify lowering the current provisions in the existing act which are higher than the minimum required by the Basel convention? What will the government do to ensure that the changes do not increase the potential for unsafe and unnecessary trade in hazardous wastes?

—I do not appreciate those words that were put into my mouth by Senator Chamarette. I did not say that. I made it very clear that I thought any interpretation of weakening was one that could not be made by any reasonable or objective person. What I can say very clearly is that Australia does support the Basel convention, which regulates transboundary movements in hazardous waste, and the government is amending the Hazardous Wastes (Regulation of Exports and Imports) Act to ensure that we fully meet our obligations under that convention.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, you recently travelled to Washington to discuss current agricultural trade issues with key players in the US administration and congress. Can you, minister, advise the Senate on the outcome of those consultations?
—Mr President—
—Kick a goal.

—Thanks for your support, Ron. Why don't you have a yarn to your Liberal colleagues and tell them to back-off. Thank you very much. Mr President, I was able during that visit to meet with my counterpart, the United States Secretary of Agriculture, Dan Glickman—
—If it is so important why don't you make a statement?

—I think you are occupying most of the afternoon, as I understand it, Senator. No more government legislation again! I also met with Pat Roberts and Richard Lugar, the chairs of the house and senate agriculture committees respectively and other key members of congress and the administration and also the leaders of some of the major industry peak bodies in the United States whose insights I found particularly valuable on how the farm bill was going. In addition, because of the timing of the visit, I had the opportunity of meeting with the newly appointed European Union agriculture commissioner, Dr Fischler, who was in Washington during the same week.

PARA.TAB: These meetings enabled me to put in the strongest terms Australia's concerns with the operation particularly of both EEP and DEIP—that is, the support programs for grain and dairy—the next year's allocations for which are currently being developed by secretary Glickman's department. I urged that there be no further extension of the subsidies into the Asia-Pacific markets in particular on the basis that further use of subsidies in markets that are strong and growing cannot be justified. I pointed out that such subsidies would only serve to depress prices for everybody. There is room in that market—and it is a strong and growing market—to sell product without subsidies.
Secretary Glickman said that he understood Australia's concerns and that it was not the intention of the United States programs to harm Australian interests.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have been saying that for years.

—That is correct, Senator. I have written to secretary Glickman to reiterate the points I made during our meeting and to remind him again of the importance Australia places on the assurances we have received from the President of the United States, President Clinton.

PARA.TAB: The other main issue that was discussed at these meetings was the development of the farm bill itself. It is still too early to be certain of the outcome of this debate, but it is clear that the debate is being driven, understandably, by the United States budget process. Cuts in the order of $6 billion to $9 billion for agricultural support over the next five years are probable and indeed they will be very welcome by Australia should they occur. But the degree of change may not be sufficient to bring about the fundamental reform that Australia and, I might add, members of the United States Congress as well would like to see.

While we may think the changes are small from this side of the Pacific, they are still seen to be unpalatable to many American farmers and are therefore being proposed as part of a broader package of reform that includes positive taxation measures for farmers. So the debate is still very fluid. We expect the content of the farm bill to be fluid during the congressional debates as members grapple with the impact of any changes in farm policy on their individual electorates. Congressman Roberts is pressing to have legislation for consideration by congress in August, but the consensus appears to be that the bills will not be ready before September at the earliest.
It needs to be reiterated in conclusion that the US farm bill is an extremely important piece of domestic United States legislation. But Australia has a legitimate role to play in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you have obviously had no influence.
—What do you suggest, Senator—that we should not be making our concerns felt to America? That is not very consistent with the points that you have just been making in a previous debate.

PARA.TAB: I do not think I can change the fact, by a visit to Washington, that the US farm bill is an important piece of domestic US legislation; it is. But Australia has a legitimate role to play in this debate and it is recognised by the United States. I do believe—and industry peak leaders will tell you this, Senator Tambling—that we are running, in terms of the group that is co-chaired by Senator McMullan and me, the most coordinated and professional campaign that Australia has ever run to influence the outcome of the United States farm bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer him to today's report of a Reuters survey which forecast an average growth rate for Australia of only 3.2 per cent for the next financial year. Given this forecast, and the fact that many other Australian economists are now forecasting lower economic growth than the 3.75 per cent contained in the budget, including the National Australia Bank's estimate of 2.8 per cent, does the minister agree that the economy is slowing faster than the government thought it would when the budget was framed? If so, won't this lower growth result in higher unemployment than the government's budgeted 8.25 per cent?

—I am not going to engage in the sort of knock-on type speculations which Senator Gibson engaged in in his question by proposing, `Oh my God, given our employment record, there might be higher unemployment in the future.' That is certainly not the government's view. For all the components, the budget forecasts that we have made are broadly consistent with the private sector forecasts. The general picture of GDP growth presented in the budget is slightly higher than that conveyed by the private sector forecasts, mainly reflecting the higher public final demand and business investment forecasts in the budget.

PARA.TAB: The budget forecasts and private sector forecasts describe a similar outlook, despite some compositional differences, with the expectation of continued strong GDP growth—although not as strong as in the 1994-95 year—underpinned by continued strong business investment, modest inflation, strong employment growth, and a current account deficit at about the same level as in in monetary terms; in percentage terms we expect it to decline by half a per cent.

Private consumption, dwelling investments, stocks and net export forecasts in the budget are consistent with what the private sector forecasters are saying. The budget forecasts for employment growth and the unemployment rate in the June quarter 1996 are consistent with the private sector average. The budget headline CPI forecast is again consistent with the private sector average forecast. The budget forecasts for business investment and the current account deficit are higher than the private sector forecasts. The budget forecast for final demand is higher than some private sector forecasts.

Broadly, we see no reason why the budget forecasts ought to be varied. Forecasting is, of course, a business in which one tries to read the economic tea-leaves and predict the future. When we came down last year with a forecast in the budget for business investment in Australia, the figures that came out were, in the end, that the Treasury was wrong. It had underestimated in the budget the level of growth. But at the time that we made that forecast, everyone else in the forecasting field virtually said we were wrong because we had overestimated by a huge percentage. Nonetheless, the record here is quite a strong one and there is nothing happening out there that we believe ought to encourage us in the slightest to amend our forecasts.

On the question of employment, we still look forward to reaching what we believe is a figure within our grasp by the year 2000 of a level of unemployment in Australia of about five per cent. That would still be too high for what we think is ideal but it would be a magnificent achievement in terms of growth. In order to achieve that it requires us to have strong, sustainable levels of growth, which is what we have at the moment. The budget forecast of 3 3/4per cent for this financial year has the economy growing in a strong way but, importantly, sustainable over the long haul, so that we do not go into dips and peaks all the time; rather, so that we have a strong level of sustainable growth ever onward, creating the right platform for employment growth.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

ANSWER.PARA: Power without responsibility may be the dream of more than the odd politician in Canberra but it has no place in a democracy.

The important thing about this is that, if a combined assault upon the budget by the Australian Democrats and the coalition pushed the budget figuring bottom line from surplus into deficit, that is an important symbolic change. TALK.START.PARA: —We could all get into a competition on selective quoting of editorials. I will start with, `The federal government has only itself to blame over the mess it now finds itself in'. And, `There is also some truth in the statement by Democrats Leader, Cheryl Kernot, that the tax is unfair. It is also inefficient and hypocritical'. However, Minister, why was it a holy alliance in 1981 when Mr Willis thought it was the right thing to do to join with the Democrats, and it is an unholy alliance now because it is with the opposition?

—The way in which this proposition is cloaked is that the coalition and the Democrats are doing some sort of service, when the net effect of what they are proposing to do is to remove the downward pressure that the budget brings on interest rates and invite a massive disservice. There is a major principle in this. You ought to pause before you go over the brink. Think about it, take a deep breath, have a good cup of tea, lie down, get up and not do it.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is the minister aware of media reports yesterday that CSIRO scientists have obtained indications that an exotic virus may have caused the massive pilchard kill along Australia's southern coastlines and that this virus may have been brought in by imported pilchards and fishmeal? Is the minister aware that AQIS commissioned a report from Mr John Humphries on the importation of the pilchards and fishmeal? Did that report indicate what category of risk was specified for importing such products? Can the minister explain why AQIS has refused to release the report for public comment, having told the office of shadow minister John Anderson that it was only a draft report yet AQIS has already put protocols in place for the importation of these fish products?
—The cause of the mass mortalities of pilchards around the Australian coast is not yet known, but it has been subject to intense scientific—

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The report will be released, Senator.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether you will know even when the report is released, Senator Bell. As I have said to the Senate before, and it is a fact, there is division among the expert scientific community—that is, the expert rather than the inexpert—about the cause of the deaths. All of the key scientific organisations are represented on the task force that is investigating this matter, including the CSIRO, the BRS, AQIS and the relevant state technical experts from the state departments of fisheries.

PARA.TAB: All senators would be aware that these processes have to be scientifically sound and thorough. An interim report will be available shortly, although the indication is that the process will need to continue. When that interim report is available, I will make it public. I note in the media reports that Senator Boswell referred to that a virus has been isolated. Those reports are not correct. When you read the body of the story, I think it is reasonably accurate; once again, unfortunately it is a question of a misleading headline.

A viral-like cytopathic effect has been identified in tissue cultures that have been treated with samples taken from both domestic and imported pilchards, but I am advised that no virus or any other infective agent has yet been isolated. The tests are continuing. Those tests have produced the effect that I have just been talking about; that is, clumps of cells have occurred in the tissue culture that are characteristic of the effect that can be caused by a virus but that can also be caused by a whole host of other agents. So no virus or any infective agent has yet been isolated from the tests which are continuing. Senators may or may not be aware that pilchards have been used extensively in long-line fishing in Australian waters since the 1950s and are continuing to be used in significant quantities by long-line fishing.
Senator Boswell interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. However, there has been a rapid increase in the use of these fish for feed stock in the past 18 months. AQIS has been working with Customs in recent months to improve its information base on the importation of this product. I was advised by AQIS as late as this morning that a new database will be operative by the end of this week. Further—and this is important—the BRS has been working on a comprehensive examination of aquatic animal quarantine controls, and this work should be completed by the end of next month. This has been a major piece of work conducted by the BRS. The work was commissioned by AQIS in 1992 and is now nearing its completion.

PARA.TAB: While there is insufficient evidence at this time to warrant the imposition of new quarantine controls, the situation has been kept under review. As I just said, when the interim report from the scientists is available, which I understand will be later this week, I will make it public.

TALK.START.PARA: —I particularly referred in my question to the Humphries report—a report commissioned by AQIS and in AQIS's office at the moment. I ask the minister specifically: did that report indicate the category of risk specified from importing fish products such as pilchards?

—The situation—with respect, Senator Boswell—is far more complex than that, as the interim report will demonstrate. In fact, the bottom line in terms of research for your benefit—and indeed for Senator Coulter's benefit—is that there has been a concentration of research, not surprisingly, in the marine area on the high-priced end of the market—that is, tropical fish, aquarium fish, fish such as salmon—but there is a huge and comprehensive dearth of scientific knowledge available around the world on the lower-priced products such as pilchards at the other end of the scale. As I just said, a comprehensive report from the scientific committee will be available later this week, and I will make the report public.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. The minister will be aware that one of the reasons cited by the government for the slow initial take-up of traineeships by employers under the Working Nation program is the delays in the implementation of the national training wage in the states and territories. Can the minister indicate whether any further progress has been made to improve the access to the national training wage of employers and trainees in state industrial jurisdictions?

—Yes, I can report that recent developments in my own state of South Australia, and also in Senator Murphy's state of Tasmania, mean that the national training wage is now accessible in all jurisdictions throughout Australia. The national training wage is a new, integrated system of wages to apply to entry-level training and the training of the long-term unemployed. Employers taking on trainees are able to access a simple wage structure that takes into account the loss of productivity flowing to the business from the time spent by the employee in training.

PARA.TAB: There is now nationwide coverage of the national training wage in the retail, metals and clerical industries, with the exception of Western Australia. Employers, unions and governments have worked together to implement the national training wage in all jurisdictions. The award was first made by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission in September of last year. It was effective immediately, and has since enabled employers who are members of some 70 employer associations named in the award to employ trainees.

Under state industrial jurisdictions, industrial arrangements are in place in major employment areas such as clerical, retail, hospitality, state public sector and manufacturing in the eastern states, with comprehensive coverage in Victoria and Queensland. There has also been considerable progress in South Australia with 13 state awards varied.

Last week the national training wage Tasmanian private sector award was made covering most of the Tasmanian private sector. The clerical administrative employees award was also varied. The majority of the public and private sector in Tasmania can now access the national training wage. We trust that the Tasmanian employers will respond to the award changes that have been made and we trust that this announcement of last week will get wide coverage in Tasmania. This is a further achievement of the Working Nation statement of last year which will enable the government to deal with the issue of the long-term unemployed in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—I have some additional information for Senator Boswell. It has just been suggested to me where the confusion is in Senator Boswell's mind.
—You will need longer than five minutes.
—No, one minute will suffice. Senator Boswell, I clearly said to you during question time that the BRS report will be available next month. It has been undertaken now since—
—What about the Humphries report?

—That is the Humphries report, Senator Boswell; there is not a separate report. The BRS report, as I told you during question time, will be completed next month. It has been under way since 1992. The interim report of the pilchard mortality task force on the current problem with pilchard deaths will be available later this week and, as soon as I have it, I will make it public.

—I have further information to a question asked by Senator Patterson during question time on 7 June. The Minister for Human Services and Health, Dr Lawrence, has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question. One of the most effective measures for identifying and removing discrimination against older people is to give older people a voice. The Minister for Human Services and Health has done this by establishing the older Australians advisory councils. The national, state and territory councils provide advice and information to the minister on the care and well-being of older Australians. One measure which could be regarded as discriminating in favour of older people is the application of community rating principles to the operation of private health insurance. Community rating requires a reinsurance pool to ensure that there are no incentives to discriminate against older and sicker people in private health insurance.

PARA.TAB: Some of the programs which are delivered by the Department of Human Services and Health are targeted to define age groups. These age-based distinctions have positive outcomes and do not discriminate adversely against other age groups which are not covered by those programs. Such age-based distinctions are found within the aged and community care program and the children's services subprogram. Responsibility for specific government measures on anti-discrimination lies with the Attorney-General. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to provide some further information to the Senate, consequent upon answers given during the last sitting week by Senator Cook. I specifically refer to the non-tabling in 1991 of guidelines associated with legislative amendments to the EMDG act. The amendment and guidelines provided access to the scheme for approved joint ventures and consortia and approved trading houses. The amendment provided that approvals were to be made in accordance with guidelines approved by the minister and published in the gazette. The amendment also provided a requirement new to the EMDG scheme that the guidelines were a disallowable instrument.

PARA.TAB: In April 1991 guidelines for the approved JVC and TH were prepared by Austrade and the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce. They were approved by the then minister and gazetted. This is the point at which the administrative oversight occurred. Relevant officers were unaware of the procedural requirements for disallowable instruments which are contained in amendments to the Acts Interpretation Act. As a result, the guidelines were not tabled as required under disallowance provisions.

In 1994 new guidelines for JVCs were issued in accordance with all procedural requirements. I have signed new trading house guidelines which I intend to table after they have been gazetted on Wednesday. Austrade has received advice from the Attorney-General's Department that the guidelines issued in 1994 are valid. If the new guidelines are issued and tabled, they will be valid also. Decisions made under the invalid guidelines are nevertheless valid unless successfully challenged in court.

Austrade has provided me with advice that during the time in which there were no valid guidelines, only 10 applicants were denied approved JVC status and nine applicants were denied approved trading house status. Austrade also advises me that these applicants were not disadvantaged as their applications would not have been successful under the properly constituted guidelines. However, in order to put the issue beyond question, I will be seeking appropriate amendments to the EMDG act. Austrade has advised me that since it took over operational carriage of the EMDG legislative process, measures have been put in place to ensure that such an oversight does not occur. Indeed, all guidelines in the form of disallowable instruments since then have been tabled and it has met its obligations to the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

Monetary policy is one of the three fundamental planks of economic management.

PARA.TAB: Last week the Treasurer had been trying to denigrate the very legitimate statement by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, following the admission by the Governor of the Reserve Bank, speaking in London last week, that interest rates could well go up in the future just as they could go down or remain unchanged. The important thing was that he was not ruling out further interest rate increases in the near future. He was not ruling them out because he expressed concern about the inflationary pressures that are arising in the economy as a result of the pressure of wage increases and also the inflationary consequence of the falling value of the Australian dollar in the international currency markets.

Those concerns have also been expressed and shared in the latest National Australia Bank confidence index, which shows that there has been a significant fall in that index of confidence from a peak of 30 per cent in September 1994 to just 8 per cent in June this year, with the main reason for that dramatic fall in confidence being given as the fear of further interest rate rises. I asked the Minister representing the Treasurer what changes in the administration of monetary policy could have led the Treasurer to the conclusion he came to in his statement last week that the Reserve Bank has infinitely greater autonomy in terms of monetary management than it had a decade or more ago and, therefore, any political manipulation of interest rates for such obscene things as electoral timing purposes could not happen.

One would have expected the Minister representing the Treasurer to be able to tell us in this chamber what the Treasurer had been referring to last week, but he did not have a clue. More significantly—and a matter of very great concern—he had no answer to the question about the inconsistency between Treasurer Willis's remarks last week and the remarks of one of the Treasurer's predecessors as Treasurer, the Prime Minister. Paul Keating took part in some famous Placido Domingo type interviews back in 1989. One was on the record during an AM program. About the Treasury and Reserve Bank, the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: They do what I say, I can assure you of that. That you can put your money on.
He said that to the interviewer, Carolyn Currie. He said:
I have Treasury in my pocket, the Reserve Bank in my pocket, wages policy in my pocket, the financial community—both here and overseas—in my pocket.

He thinks that having those institutions in his pocket is all about leadership. In the last week or so, the government—in the form of the Treasurer—has been walking right away from it. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Boswell this day, relating to an Australian Quarantine Inspection Service report into the imporation of pilchards.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins, in his answer to a question from Senator Boswell, said that the article in the Sunday Herald-Sun was rather misleading. Having looked at the headline and what was said in the article, I am inclined to agree with him. But the article makes a couple of points that concern me and probably concern most senators, including Senator Coulter and Senator Bell as Tasmanians. It said:

PARA.TAB: Researchers at the Australian Animal Health Laboratory have detected a "transmission agent" in frozen pilchards fed to farmed tuna in South Australia . . .

SPEECH.PARA: It then quotes Dr Crane, a marine biologist. He talks about what is in Australian pilchards and in North American pilchards as far as viruses are concerned and how viruses may have jumped to Australian species and there is the presence of transmission agents. It all seems very complicated to me as a layman. Then again, it just shows how possible it is for these diseases to transfer in such an easy way.

PARA.TAB: What brought this home to me was evidence by the beekeepers association that the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport received at a hearing in Brisbane last week. In its submission to us, it made it clear in no uncertain terms that it holds AQIS responsible for the introduction of chalkbrood, which is a very dangerous disease that was introduced into Australia, through Queensland, in January 1993. That is when the first-known presence of it was discovered. It has now spread to New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia.

The association pointed out that the beekeeping industry has for many years been trying to get AQIS to take the threat of the incursion of chalkbrood into Australia as a serious matter. It was obviously put off—it states this further in its submission; I will mention it—by the same sorts of arguments that have been made about the potential danger of viruses in pilchards to the fish industry in Australia and what it calls the minimal or acceptable risk of these things.

The industry asked AQIS to ban the importation of pollen into Australia because it believes that that is the way this disease was introduced. But AQIS would not ban the importation of pollen into Australia from countries which had chalkbrood. It was well known at that time that pollen was the vector for carrying these spores in the importation of honey. Obviously AQIS indicated that it may do that. However, it was later found that there was not a complete ban on the importation of pollen. As a result, it was generally recognised that the incursion of chalkbrood came from the importation of infected pollen.
In evidence, Mr Weatherhead said that a large shipment was found in South Australia but that it had entered through Brisbane. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The perceived attitude with the threat from pollen importation was, `You are only beekeepers. We are the scientists with the University degrees'.
Today we heard Senator Collins talking about the expert scientific community. I wonder whether it takes the same attitude that it took in the case of the chalkbrood infestation.

PARA.TAB: While we were in Queensland, we also heard about the introduction of a bush known to most people as the biten bush. It was introduced through ships' ballast into Australia through faulty quarantine procedures. It has been of great concern. I stand as a farmer whose property has been in quarantine for 30 years. I have been infested with a noxious weed that has covered my place for 30 years. That was also as a result of incorrect procedures in importing seed. I have an interest in this. Senator Coulter may wish to follow on from what I have said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will use this opportunity to make a personal explanation. Several papers over the weekend, starting with a Melbourne paper in an article by Fia Cumming, had me saying that a foreign virus had been identified on the gills of dead pilchards. I said that a virus had been identified on the gills of dead pilchards. I made that distinction very carefully. One of my concerns—it was amplified today in the reply of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Bob Collins)—is that insufficient research has gone on in Australia to establish the database of viruses and naturally occurring disease organisms in the Australian marine environment. Against that `dearth' of information—to use the minister's word—we are now really floundering in an attempt to find out what exactly has caused this massive fish kill. Unfortunately, that article was followed by similar articles in several other papers. I just use this opportunity to make that point.

PARA.TAB: I did check back with Fia Cumming, and she read over the original draft of her article to me. Senators may be interested to know that the word `foreign', as a qualifier for `virus', crept in somewhere at the subeditorial level. So even if while reporting you a journalist writes something carefully and accurately, evidently subeditors will jazz up a story sometimes and add in other words which change the whole sense.

The minister referred to a survey which has been going on, he said, since 1992 and which will shortly be completed. However, it indicates—and I think the point needs to be stressed again and again—that this government is spending far too little on research in understanding the Australian environment comprehensively and completely so that there is the database in place and so that we do know whether a foreign pollen, a foreign wheat, a foreign pilchard or a foreign Atlantic salmon is carrying an agent which is not present in the Australian environment and which potentially could cause a disease and also know something about the immunity of natural populations in Australia so that again we can get a better handle on it.

I suspect that, although this inquiry into the pilchards has been going on for weeks and in fact for months, it may simply be that dearth of background information—and I use the minister's word `dearth' again—due to the failure of this government and of successive governments to spend enough on environmental research which will preclude a definitive answer to the question. It should be relatively simple with that background information to identify exactly what was causing this fish kill. The inability to identify the cause, in my view, relates to the fact that scientists, unfortunately, are working against a background of insufficient knowledge; and that insufficient knowledge relates very much to the government's lack of spending on research.

Of course, this is pre-eminently an area of research in which you do not find large private investment. You do not find industry investing in establishing that background information, that is, the database on which industry can then work later on if it wants to use it in some exploitative way. But the basic fundamental data, the background on which you do this sort of research, must be public interest research. It must be carried out in universities and CSIRO. It must be publicly funded. Governments must spend a great deal more in this area—certainly a great deal more than is in this present budget.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Kernot this day, relating to sales tax on building material.

SPEECH.PARA: In his answer to me today, Senator Cook took the liberty of saying what he thought was the Democrats' rationale for deciding at this stage to oppose the building hardware tax. I wanted to put on the record, obviously, the factors that we took into consideration. We did not jump up on budget night and say, as others do in this place, `We are opposed to everything on principle.'

PARA.TAB: I need to go through the chronology of this kind of tax to point out that it was in 1981 that John Howard tried to impose a 2 1/2 per cent tax on building supplies, and that it was in 1981 that Mr Ralph Willis, the current Treasurer, said that this was a regressive tax and that it would impact unfairly and affect the equity of the tax system. These sales tax bills were used as a double dissolution trigger in 1983, and the Liberal government was defeated. In 1988, Treasurer Paul Keating then said, `Oh, we have to extend the sales tax net to bathroom fittings just to address a couple of anomalies.' He said that some household fittings were already taxed. That time, the opposition voted with the government for that extension to occur.

In 1995, we see current Treasurer Ralph Willis extending the sales tax to all building hardware other than basic materials like concrete and timber, again using the argument that the current tax situation is anomalous. The tax is also extended to things like nails and paint and tiles, and creates a whole range of new anomalies. One that comes to mind is the fact that kitchen cupboards which are prefabricated and which are built off site are subject to the tax. But if you ask the builder to build your kitchen on site—and builders will say that this is often a less efficient use of resources—then that kitchen is exempt from this 12 per cent tax.

The new tax arrangement creates as many new anomalies as it addresses. A future government could say, `We are going to close these new anomalies by extending the sales tax regime even further.' For those who have been involved in this debate since 1981, there is a question of consistency.

I also draw attention to other measures the government has taken, specifically the cuts to public housing funding. In 1995, the budget cut housing funds by $44 million in real terms. That followed a $68 million cut in 1994. In the 1995 budget, the government similarly cut $6 million from rental assistance. According to ACOSS, that change has left 325,000 households worse off. These things are worth considering when you are considering what to do about this particular tax.

In relation to what dropping this measure would do to the budget, Mr Willis has responded with the blackmail tactic of saying, `The Senate will be held accountable for interest rate rises.' He should have thought about that in 1981 when he said, `It is right and appropriate to block these bills because they are not in the best interests of this country.'

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate the need for changes to the Family Law Act of Australia and to the child support scheme.
Your petitioners therefore request that the Senate support the following changes.

PETITION.PARA: (1)That the existing Family Law Act be scrapped and replaced by a more simplified version together with the minimum of rules and regulations necessary.

(2)That the Family Court be replaced by a Tribunal and that all matters resulting from divorce and family breakdown be heard before, and determined by a panel; the panel to be made up of persons qualified in matters arising from family breakdown.
(3)That legal professionals be barred from appearing before the Tribunal resulting in vast savings to the disputing parties.
(4)That a modified fault clause be re-introduced to Family Law primarily designed to discourage adultery and to stop rewarding adulterers at the expense of deserted and innocent parties.
(5)That the Child Support Agency be scrapped and replaced by an appropriate administrative procedure within the Tribunal.
(6)That apart from cases of exceptional circumstances parental-child access become the inalienable right of all parents.

(7)That alternative counselling, (Government funded) be made available through the Churches and that much more emphasis be placed on mediation in resolving disputes prior to the commencement of legal proceedings.

PETITION.TITLE: Logging and Woodchipping
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We are dismayed at the continuing destruction of old growth and wilderness forests around Australia, despite the National Forest Policy Statement jointly signed by the Commonwealth and all States except Tasmania.

Intensive logging, most often to feed a voracious woodchip industry is under way or planned for many high conservation value forests. These forests should be protected by the commitments of the Commonwealth and State Governments under the NFPS.
These forests include:

PETITION.PARA: Coolangubra Wilderness and other areas of the S.E. Forests of NSW along with rainforest and other N.E. areas of NSW including Wingham, Mistake, Richmond Range, Chaelundi, North Washpool, Barrington and Dorrigo.
The Southern Highlands, Great Western Tiers and Tarkine Wilderness of Tasmania.
The Karri and Jarrah forests of S.W. Western Australia.
The Errinundra Plateau and other areas of the East Gippsland forests of Victoria.
The rainforests of the Proserpine region of Queensland.

PARA.TAB: We request that the Government act urgently to protect our precious forests by utilising the Commonwealth's legal and constitutional powers, including:

PETITION.PARA: Refusal of export woodchip licences
Powers to control corporations
Protection of areas listed on the register of the National Estate
Protection and effective funding of areas identified for their World Heritage values.

PARA.TAB: Genuine and effective action by the Government to protect these and other old growth and wilderness forests is critical. A comprehensive plantation strategy rather than exploiting native forests is the way forward for a truly environmentally responsible timber industry. We further request that the Government take effective action without further delay.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The correspondence read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The Hon David Beddall MP
Minister for Resources
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2601
Dear Minister
I refer to the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Plan 1995 being NPF01 and the Southern Bluefin Tuna Fishery Management Plan 1995 being SBT 01 made under s.17 of the Fisheries Management Act 1991.

The Committee is concerned that the Plans appear to have no commencement dates. Clause 2 of each of the Plans provides that the Plan is to commence "when notice of the fact that the plan has been determined is published under subsection 19(1) of the Act". Although this means of commencement is appropriate the NOTE at the end of the Northern Prawn Fishery Management Plan 1995 does not contain a commencement date. Also, there is no NOTE (and no date) at the end of the Southern Bluefin Tuna Fishery Management Plan 1995. As the 1952 Act ceased to apply to the fisheries after 2 February 1995, the commencement dates are very significant.

The Committee would be grateful if you could clarify the position with respect to the commencement dates of the Plans. The Committee would also appreciate your advice as to whether consideration could be given to inserting commencement dates in such Plans in the future to avoid the dates being omitted.
Yours sincerely
Mal Colston
Chairman
6 June 1995
Senator Mal Colston
Chairman
Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Colston

Thank you for your letter of 11 May 1995 concerning the commencement dates of the Northern Prawn Fishery (NPF) Management Plan 1995 (Plan NPF01) and the Southern Bluefin Tuna (SBT) Fishery Management Plan 1995 (Plan SBT01).

The SBT Plan commenced on 3 February 1995 and the NPF Plan commenced on 10 February 1995. These are the respective dates on which notices of the determination of each plan were published in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette.

The SBT Plan commenced the day after the Fisheries Act 1952 expired. This was the earliest day that the Plan could commence. Along with transitional provisions in the Plan itself, commencement on 3 February 1995 allowed the current fishing season in the SBT Fishery to continue uninterrupted.

The commencement of the NPF Plan was delayed until the last of the Offshore Constitutional Settlement Agreements required to give the Commonwealth complete jurisdiction over the area of the NPF under the Fisheries Management Act 1991 could be formally executed by the Commonwealth. The delay in the commencement of the NPF Plan had no impact on the management of the NPF as, in accordance with established practice, the fishery was closed during the period December 1994 to April 1995.

The Australian Fisheries Management Authority has advised that commencement dates will be inserted into all future plans of management, either by way of notes in the case of plans that are designed to commence on gazettal, or in the plan itself in the case of plans designed to commence on a previously ascertained date.
Yours sincerely
(sgd) DAVID BEDDALL
