SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)condemns the decision of the Government of France to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific;
(2)calls on the French Government to reverse its decision and not to resume testing;
(3)shares the resentment of South Pacific countries at nuclear testing in the South Pacific and endorses the statement condemning the decision issued by the South Pacific Forum;
(4)deplores France's decision to breach its 1992 moratorium which had improved relations between France and countries in the region;

(5)expresses its outrage that France's decision undermines the outcome of the recent Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons Review and Extension Conference, particularly the commitment made at the Conference that, pending entry into force of the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty (CTBT), the nuclear weapon states should exercise utmost restraint;
(6)notes that Australia will do all in its power and urge all other countries to hold France to President Chirac's statement that France would sign a CTBT without reservation in autumn 1996; and
(7)calls on France to sign and ratify the protocols of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty.

This motion is in exactly the same terms as the motion moved by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the House of Representatives just after 12.30 p.m. today. I realise that there is also a Democrat urgency motion around on this issue. We deemed it desirable that if possible both houses would carry motions of principle and later get into the partisan political aspects of criticising government for political gain if it so desires.

PARA.TAB: The track record of this government when it comes to matters nuclear is very defensible and very extensive. This government has been a supporter of non-proliferation treaties. In New York in May we were very influential in getting an indefinite extension to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Further, we have been a great supporter of the negotiation of a comprehensive test ban treaty. Finally, we have also strongly supported the South Pacific nuclear free zone.

We have worked very hard in international forums to prevent both vertical and horizontal proliferation of nuclear weapons. Like most others, we thought the great dividend for the end of the Cold War was the removal of the threat of nuclear weapons to an enormous extent. We have seen enormous progress since the end of the Cold War, at least in this one field.

We contend that France's decision to resume nuclear testing flies in the face of all of this. It is our contention that the actions it has taken to resume nuclear testing does much to damage the progress that has been made over recent years. We would believe fairly certainly that France could have used computer simulation techniques to obviate the need for these nuclear weapons. There is no way that the current French government would be unaware of the feelings of Australia, New Zealand and the rest of the Pacific island countries on this particular issue. Those views were made clear to it right through the 1980s and into the 1990s and were revalidated by letters from the foreign minister, the Prime Minister and personal representations by the foreign minister to those likely to form this current Chirac government. Those views were obviously ignored.

I think it is a great pity that the very good work that France has been able to achieve in the Pacific since the Matignon accords in 1988 have all been dealt a major and destructive blow by this one decision. It is true that its role in the Pacific has been much more up-beat in the last seven years. It has involved assisting other countries in the region, cooperating with countries in the region for the economic protection of Pacific islands and much better domestic relations in those territories that it currently occupies in the Pacific. All those things are put at risk by this particular decision.

The actual motion goes to a variety of areas. It condemns the decision of the government of France to resume nuclear testing. It is most appropriate that the Senate should carry that particular one. It also calls on the French government to reverse that decision. The motion states that the Senate shares the resentment of other South Pacific countries to nuclear testing. It is here that Australia does have a pivotal role. Many of these countries do not have the resources or the standing in the world to make their voice known. It is up to Australia—supplemented and sometimes joined by New Zealand—to reinforce those views in all international forums where we can.

I was particularly pleased to see that the European Parliament carried a resolution very similar to the one that has been put forward today. It is not just a matter of Australia, New Zealand and the other Pacific Islands raising protests on these issues. It is absolutely essential that other leading countries in the world make their views known and make them known strongly. It is essential that Australia protests the carrying out of such tests not only in the Pacific but also where they occur in China less we be regarded as hypocritical. There is a distinction between the two. China carries out nuclear testing in its own soil. That does not make it any better or any more justifiable, but in some ways the thought that France will be using territory 12,000 or 13,000 miles away is obnoxious to us all.

The point has often been made to France that if nuclear testing underground is so safe and causes no damage, why not do it in metropolitan France itself or Corsica or somewhere like that. The only response we get from the French government is that it has already spent the money on the infrastructure in the south-west Pacific. That is an extremely inadequate response by the French government.

However, some of the hysteria that has been whipped up on this issue is a bit Francophobic. Some of today's notices of motion reflect that they are concerned that Australia's reaction should be a sensible reaction. I join with Senator Knowles, Senator Kernot and others who have moved motions saying that our protest should be sensible and non-violent because the reaction in France to those sorts of events that occurred in Perth and elsewhere will not improve our chances of a reconsideration. The thought of people running around and putting signs up over French restaurants, mostly owned by people who have never been to France in their life, does smack of a bit of McCarthyism and we would not seek to encourage that form of activity. This in no way negates the ability of people to protest peacefully and assertively. No-one is trying to discourage that, but we are trying to encourage people to do it in a way that will at least reinforce the case with the French government and not have it react blindly and say it is some sort of Francophobic thing and nothing to do with the issue.

Senator Gareth Evans and a delegation of South Pacific Forum nations will be visiting the French foreign minister at about 3.30 a.m. Australian time, which is about 7.30 p.m. French time, to make those views known. Senator Evans will then come back to Australia and report to the Australian government on what further action may have to be taken regarding this particular issue.

It is difficult to know what steps Australia could adopt to effect a reversal of the French policy or, indeed, to set up the circumstances that would inhibit any further decisions along these lines. We welcome the fact that, on indications so far, the French government—post these tests—will sign up for a comprehensive test ban. Some indication has been given that it may be on board for the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone. Those are the positive things that we will have to enforce.

It is difficult when it comes to penalties. Some have been suggested in notices of motion today. This is a difficult area to disentangle, especially in the commercial area where contracts are already signed. The Australia government did decide to freeze the defence relationship between Australia and France at its current level—not a particularly high level as it turns out. There are areas that it is suggested be protected. I do not think it is desirable for the surveillance activities in the Pacific—basically fishing matters—to come into this, because the only people who will be punished are Pacific islanders. There is also a strong case for medivac and similar humanitarian or United Nations contact to continue.

Apart from that, Australia has very little defence contact with France, other than in those French companies sometimes set up as Australian companies that bid in the defence equipment area. That is an extremely difficult area to disentangle as there are existing contracts or tenders currently out. Apart from that, contacts are mostly occasional officer, ship or plane visit between the countries. We have made it quite clear that no ship or plane visit will be allowed if it has any connection with the testing of nuclear weapons in the south-west Pacific.

This motion may go through in its current form or it may be amended. It would be a pity if it were amended, especially if that merely reflects product differentiation or political partisanship. But everyone is entitled to hold views and senators may seek to change the motion. I think it would be a good thing—even though I do not think it likely—for this chamber and the House of Representatives to pass the same motion. As the numbers are different, that may not transpire.

It will be a strange message to the French government if both houses of the parliament send a different message. Most people would agree that the time today to sort that out is very limited. Consultation is also limited—and I understand that. I will not comment at any length on the amendment proposed in another place other than to say that some of the matters will be considered when Senator Gareth Evans returns to Australia and reports to the government. Each of the points can then be given consideration.

In conclusion, the Australian government reiterates its condemnation of the French government for resuming nuclear tests in the south-west Pacific. This government has a track record of opposing such tests wherever they occur around the globe. In this instance, Australia feels a special imperative to represent those small Pacific island nations that find it hard to have their voice heard around the world, to articulate not only their concerns but ours, and to try to get the French government to reverse its decision. This will not be an easy task; the French government was well aware of the reaction many countries around the globe would have when it took this decision.

I reiterate that I hope the debate and the general discussion on this issue around Australia remain focused on the basic issues and do not get into the emotive, hysterical and sometimes Francophobic atmosphere that leads to events such as that in Perth over the weekend. I hope that does not occur because as a nation I think we can deal with these issues maturely and, hopefully, get a result.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —We also deeply regret the decision of France to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific. We will be supporting the motion moved by the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray), a motion which condemns the decision of France to resume such tests and which adds some associated sentiment. But we will be seeking to take it a step further. I will move an amendment in the same terms as was moved in the House of Representatives. It will add to the government's motion. I move:

PARA.TAB: At end of motion, add the following word and paragraph "and

SPEECH.PARA: (h)calls on the Government to:

TAB.TAB: (i)join with New Zealand and suspend military cooperation with France, except for surveillance, United Nations and humanitarian activities,

PARA.TAB: (ii)cease refuelling all French non-humanitarian military transit flights,

(iii)recall the Australian Ambassador to show the depth of Australian concern and to develop, in association with the South Pacific Forum, a regional plan of action to embarrass, and if possible hinder, French nuclear testing, including action in the United Nations condemning French nuclear testing as a gross abuse of colonial power and (along with similar tests by the People's Republic of China) as gross violations of the world environment, and
(iv)discuss with the United States of America the possibility of data-sharing to remove the public French excuse for the tests.".

SPEECH.PARA: In the same spirit that Senator Ray showed, my contribution is not designed in terms of product differentiation. I am trying to avoid being unduly politically partisan, to use his expression, because it is important on this occasion that a united voice be expressed by the people's representatives in this place. It is a pity in some ways that it does not seem to have been possible for the parties to have achieved a consensus motion in this regard.

PARA.TAB: I guess the distinction between what the government is moving and what we are seeking to add is that we are calling for more positive action to be taken to demonstrate how appalled all Australians are at the decision that has been taken by the government of France. It was a totally unnecessary decision in this post-Cold War environment, a decision which is particularly regrettable in terms of its impact upon small Pacific island states, states with which we have a very close relationship.

It is so easy to simply call—as the government does—upon the French government to reverse its decision and say we share the resentment of South Pacific countries at this decision to resume nuclear testing, to express our outrage and to urge France to sign the CTBT without reservation in autumn 1996. There is no real pain in that as far as we Australians are concerned. In no way does it put any pressure on our relationship with France. Traditionally it has been close and important to us and, we would like to see, important to France.

But in terms of the motion of the government being put in such soft terms, its impact—regrettably—is likely to reflect the tenor of the government's sentiment. Regrettably also, it is likely to have little effect. That is why we think it is important, in terms of seeking to apply some real pressure—not in an effort to get product differentiation—that the government go further in this instance.

When we talk about such things as suspending part of our military cooperation, ceasing to refuel French non-humanitarian military transit flights, recalling our ambassador or involving the United States in the sharing of data, we are trying to put forward positive suggestions of action that this government could, and we believe should, be taking to apply some real pressure on France in this regard. Unless the Australian government is prepared to do that and take the risks associated with it, it is very difficult for the Australian people to take seriously the response that the government has made.

I will put this into context. We on this side of the chamber have to say how disappointed we are with the response of our Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) when the decision of France was announced. Although, as Senator Robert Ray said in question time today, aspects of his statement expressed our outrage, nevertheless he sent a clear message to France that we do not really take the decision seriously when he said, `The decision to resume testing was not as bad as it could have been.'

We understand what he means. France has announced a limited number of tests over a limited time. We presume that that is what he was referring to. But in diplomatic speak it was also clearly intended to send another message to France, which is that we are making a form protest but that we do not treat it all that seriously. That is what we were distressed about. That is why our spokesman and my leader, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard), responded strongly to the disappointing statement made by Senator Evans. That is why we in question time today tried to get the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate to repudiate the statement of Senator Evans and say that, in effect, it did not reflect the position of the Australian government. But he refused to do so. He would rather talk through the issue than suffer any short-term political embarrassment that might flow from repudiating a statement which has clearly sent a message to France that the Australian government does not regard this matter all that seriously.

It is not surprising that the government today was reluctant to take that action, because the earlier signals sent by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) also demonstrated that the Australian government did not see this matter as one of major consequence. I refer to the endorsement by the Australian government—post the decision of France to resume its testing in the South Pacific—of France's bid to join the Pacific Economic Cooperation Council in September. PECC is a regional organisation involving states of the Asia-Pacific. It seems to us that if the Australian government, through our Prime Minister, is at the time that we claim to be protesting so vigorously the resumption of these tests in effect inviting France to join us in regional bodies, again France can only get one message, which is that the Australian government is not really serious about its protest.

It was interesting that, when the endorsement of France's bid to join PECC was put to a spokesman for Mr Keating last week, the response of that spokesman was, `No consideration is being given to withdrawing the letter.' Even as of last week, the government was again sending a message to France that the decision of France has to be put into a wider context of regional cooperation. The Australian government was not placing great weight upon the decision to resume the tests.

Our concern is that it is really all too late for the government to be responding in the parliament or publicly if it really is interested in doing its best to join with other states to dissuade France from this course of action. The time that the government should have been acting was before the decision of President Chirac was announced. Jacques Chirac, during the presidential campaign in France, made clear that this was one of the policies upon which he was standing for office. Upon his successful election, there was considerable and continuing press speculation that he was about to make the announcement to implement this policy decision. The best that the Australian government could do during that time—when there was a chance of influencing some different course of action—was for Senator Evans to write a letter to his counterpart in the French government.

Everyone knows that a letter of that type would have no real influence. If a delegation were to be sent, the time for that to happen was before the decision was announced whilst there was some chance of influencing France in a different direction. Discussions and dialogue could have commenced and effort could have been made to bring the United States and other major powers into a dialogue on the issue. But the Australian government simply did not show interest in the matter at that time. As I said, after the decision was announced, it did not show a great deal of interest, if we look at the words of Senator Evans. Only since the outrage of the Australian people has become evident to the Prime Minister has there been any real effort by the Australian government to be seen to be acting in this matter. Senator Evans and a low-level delegation have gone to France to make the point.

Again, if the Australian government were serious, would not Senator Evans be accompanied by senior ministers and heads of government of the states of the South Pacific? It has all the trappings of a low-level delegation. It sends a message to France that we are going through a form protest. We as a nation will express the point that we will really not take seriously our reaction to this decision by France to renew these tests.

The response has been disappointing to date. As I said, we are prepared to support the motion in the terms that the government has brought to us. We add our amendments to add some substance. Again, the terms of the government's motion really do not demonstrate any real commitment to the cause that it is purporting to support.

I take this opportunity to make those points on behalf of the coalition. We express our outrage and disappointment that a friend of Australia, France, should have acted in this way in this postwar environment at the time of the new world order. We believed that the days of nuclear testing and the development of further nuclear weaponry were behind the international community. I take this opportunity to say that, in the eyes of the opposition, this government should have done more. It should have done more prior to, and since, the announcement of the resumption. It should have brought to this parliament today a much stronger motion than it has. I have moved the amendment in the terms I put a little earlier.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to give my absolute support to the motion that has been put by the government and to add some comments. It is outrageous, as Senator Hill has said. Many words have been said about this, and many words will be said. The condemnation of the French government is to be overwhelmingly endorsed.

PARA.TAB: I want to say a couple of other things. I think it is the French government—and this point has been made again and again, but it cannot be made enough—that is to be blamed, not the French people who live in Australia and who have been subject to not only adverse action in the sense of outright hostility but snide remarks and the sorts of innuendos that are sometimes put towards them. I think it is a great pity that we should take out on citizens or residents of this country something that has been decided by people overseas. So I put on record my support for all of those good French people in Australia—people who have a French background and are citizens of Australia and whose forebears may have been French. We realise, as a nation, that they are people who are very welcome here, who have made a great contribution to this country and who will do so in the future.

There is only one other matter that I want to deal with, and that is this. Senator Ray, when he introduced this motion, expressed the fond hope—and it is a fond hope—that we as a parliament might endorse this motion and then get to politicking later on. Senator Hill, with complete sincerity—and I accept him on this, and there is no doubt that this side of the chamber does—has joined in expressing the outrage of the opposition about this matter. The pity of his speech perhaps is this: when it is looked at, the amount of time he has spent condemning the French government will be far outweighed by the amount of time he has spent in condemning the Australian government.

It was not the Australian government that proposed setting off this bomb in the Pacific; it is not the Australian government that is going to set off the bomb in the Pacific; and the Australian government will never set off an atomic bomb in the Pacific. I simply say that it is a pity that it was the Australian government that was condemned primarily in the speech that came from the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill).

Other senators will be speaking after me. I hope that the content of their speeches will be directed more towards condemning the real culprit in this matter rather than the government. I think Senator Bob Collins might agree with me on this. If what happens today is that there is a continuation of the condemnation of the Australian government rather than the French government, even someone so open-minded and so free of suspicion as Senator Collins might start taking on board the thought that what really interests people is not so much the outrageous setting off of a bomb by the French in the Pacific, but the opportunity that that has presented for a political play against the present government. I know you would not do it, Senator Collins, but you might be tempted to do it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The nuclear testing subject is one that the National Party does not often get itself involved in—there are many more concerns in the wider area of the National Party constituency that do cause worry—but today I wanted to speak about the motion moved by the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) and the amendments put by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill). I wanted to lend the support of the National Party in the Senate because I too believed that we were entering the end of the Cold War and we were looking forward as a nation—and the world was, too—to the end to nuclear testing.

PARA.TAB: I think it was maybe four or five years ago, or even a shorter term than that, that there was a world agreement on nuclear testing. That agreement has, I suppose, a year to run before it becomes official. The new President of France, Jacques Chirac, has wounded the spirit of that agreement, if not the agreement itself. He maintains that the eight planned tests to take place between 1995 and 1996 are entirely irrevocable, so I do not believe that Senator Gareth Evans's deputation to him will have a lot of effect, although I agree that Senator Evans should do all in his power—and the Australian government should do all in its power—to change or to turn around the decision of the new president. President Chirac has made this part of his policy, and I believe he is trying to be very hairy chested on this and show the way, but what he is doing is exposing his weakness to the rest of the world.

He further holds that he should be congratulated rather than being condemned because he has said there will be no more tests after 1996. I think he should show some concern for the French Polynesians; the Tahitians; the New Caledonians; the Micronesians; and the people of Guam, Western Samoa, Nauru, Tonga, Vanuatu, Fiji, Papua New Guinea, Australia, New Zealand, Tokelau and Tuvalu—all dwellers in the Pacific Ocean on small islands that could be affected by these tests.

I have been to New Caledonia, and I know about the money that the French pour into those small South Pacific nations and the influence that they want to extract from those Pacific island nations. I can think of nothing more harmful than to have that influence denigrated and rejected by exploding a nuclear bomb in someone else's backyard. The point is being made that the Chinese do it, but at least they do not do it adjacent to French Polynesia and some of those other island nations.

I, too, want to deplore the violence. I do not think that achieves a great deal, except that it would probably harden France's attitude and shut off any back door that it could try to escape from. But I do want to say that this action does underscore the concern that has been held by a great many Australians. We have seen demonstrations take place in all major cities, including Canberra.

President Chirac's first major decision was to break his nation's three-year self-imposed moratorium on nuclear testing which France made in 1992 with the US, the UK and Russia. France was one of the 178 nations that agreed recently to an indefinite extension of the 25-year-old nuclear non-proliferation treaty that was signed in 1970. Under the terms of the treaty, five acknowledged nuclear power nations—Russia, the USA, France, the UK and China—could retain their weapons while pursuing disarmament policies. As I said, France is technically allowed under that agreement to conduct tests, but it certainly has breached the spirit of that agreement.

I do not know what a parliament can do other than to express, through the motions moved by the Acting Leader of the Government and the Leader of the Opposition, its utter condemnation of such an action. I want to associate the National Party with that condemnation, as I know that every party, including the Independents, will support part or all of that motion. I certainly join with Senator Hill and Senator Ray in expressing, on behalf of the National Party, condemnation of this action.

TALK.START.PARA: —Despite what France's President Chirac has said in attempting to defend his decision to recommence nuclear testing in the South Pacific, the reality, as probably everyone in the country would agree, is that there is absolutely no justification whatsoever for the resumption of nuclear testing by France or by anybody else, and that includes China, which is still doing it. France has claimed that such testing is completely safe—ha!—carries no danger to the environment and that it is necessary to maintaining its nuclear deterrent capability. That is complete and utter nonsense!

PARA.TAB: Safe nuclear testing is the great oxymoron of modern life. There can never be safe nuclear testing. The sooner France realises that, the better. Any nuclear test is one test too many. France and China should realise that the time to cease testing forever is right now.

Of utmost concern is the fact that this decision clearly undermines last month's decision in New York by the international community to extend indefinitely the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. We would have preferred to have seen a time frame on the extension but there was not one. The treaty has been extended and this decision by France has undermined what was behind the treaty.

At the time of the extension, the Australian government welcomed it as a significant achievement in bringing about a world free from nuclear weapons—something we all want to see. If France were serious about its legal obligations under the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, it would be respecting the terms of that treaty right now. As it happens, France is now totally out of step with the majority of international sentiment on the subject of nuclear weapons.

The reality is that there is already an oppressive weight of nuclear arsenals. The 50,000 or so nuclear weapons in the world's nuclear stockpile represent overkill in the most obscene manner. What possible justification is there for France's decision to conduct nuclear tests?

Instead of further nuclear testing, France has a special responsibility, as a nuclear state, to pursue policies directed at reducing the potential of nuclear weapons ever being used in a military conflict. This latest decision will not help to stop that. The decision to recommence nuclear testing effectively means that France has abandoned its special responsibility as a nuclear power state to refrain from testing. Its adherence to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty was crucial to enhancing the possibility of preventing nuclear war by helping to preclude the spread of nuclear weapons to the current non-nuclear weapons states. That is why its decision to recommence nuclear testing in the South Pacific is such a terrible disappointment to us all.

What possible incentive is there for non-nuclear power states to refrain from becoming part of the nuclear club when countries which are already part of that club, such as France and China, display such total disregard for international treaties? Surely privilege entails responsibility, and members of the UN Security Council have a special responsibility to adhere to all the rules.

What possible reason can France have to carry out eight more nuclear explosions, to further contaminate the earth's crust, and probably the Pacific Ocean, for thousands of years to come? Does it expect a nuclear war before it finally stops testing in June next year? Will we have a nuclear war before June next year? I would say probably not and, even if we did, what does it matter how many times over they can kill each one of us? Isn't once enough? These are the most destructive weapons on the face of the earth. We already know that. France does not need to prove it to anybody any further.

As honourable senators will remember, Australia and New Zealand took France to the International Court of Justice, the ICJ, in 1972 to try to stop French atmospheric nuclear tests in the Pacific. We were successful; the ICJ found in our favour. Of course, the French did not stop; they simply carried out their tests underground. So, instead of immediately contaminating the air and sea around Mururoa and very close to Australia, instead of immediately destroying the lives of thousands of Tahitians and other South Pacific Islanders, they did it in the long term by carrying out these tests underground. The French should have stopped in 1972. They should never have started, of course, but they should have stopped completely then. They have not done that.

The first thing that this new French government did on the international stage was to throw away any right to public approbation for a new government. This is obviously a very bad government. We cannot say anything other than that of it.

However, let us keep in mind that it is the French government which has taken this decision; it is not the French people. There was no mandate to do this. It has not been done by anybody in Australia. In particular, it has not been done by anybody in Australia with a French name, or who owns a restaurant with a French name or who has a French accent. These people are completely free of this decision and no retribution should be directed to any single one of them. I think every member of this Senate would agree with that.

I well remember marching in the massive anti-nuclear rallies in the 1970s and 1980s. I well remember the feeling of hopelessness and frustration that led us all to march. I well remember feeling the massive arrogance of the French government that led us all to march in those enormous rallies. Those were exactly the same feelings that I have now—exactly the same.

The Australian Democrats believe that this motion, in many ways, is a good one. As Senator Kernot will mention a little later, there are a couple of things in it that we would like to change. In particular, we believe that Australian uranium is not innocent in all of this and we would like to see more emphasis put on that matter. We will be looking at Senator Hill's amendment, which we have just received, and Senator Kernot will also talk about that.

I finish by saying that the Democrats join with, I am sure, every member of this parliament in condemning the French government, in condemning the Chinese government, and in condemning any government which is still testing nuclear weapons. It is totally unnecessary.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Greens (WA), I would like to give some words of support to the government's proposed resolution on French nuclear testing, but with some provisos. Yes, it would be a good thing if the wording passed in the House of Representatives were to be the wording of the proposal presently before the Senate. However, that does not mean that the proposal could not be added to and improved so that the message could be strengthened.

PARA.TAB: I want it put on the record that we have serious reservations about point 5. Those reservations relate to the nature of the agreement. It seems somewhat hypocritical for Australia to be now saying that France's decision undermines the outcome of the treaty on non-proliferation of nuclear weapons review. I remind honourable senators that this treaty was being renegotiated during the lead-up to the French election with M. Chirac running on a platform that included being definitely in favour of resuming tests in the Pacific.

The nuclear powers wanted indefinite extension to the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Senator Gareth Evans presented to this chamber as someone who was busy saving the world by using every possible influence to obtain that indefinite extension. A lot of people would have preferred to see five-year rolling extensions with commitments to weapons destruction because, even though requirements for nuclear control have been in place for many years under the nuclear non-proliferation treaty, nuclear weapons have continued to proliferate. There was a concern that unless there was a specific rolling back of the nuclear arsenals under this commitment, negotiated specifically as part of this rolling extension, the signal would be going to the nuclear states that, in reality, they were able to carry on business as usual.

Nuclear weapons states have used extreme but undefined pressure to bring the non-aligned movement into place on this issue. There was no consensus, despite the kinds of statements that have been made; there was simply an agreement not to go to a vote.

Australia was right in there up to its ears because our role was to get the non-aligned nations onboard. Australia gave a special dinner. Heaven knows what it was that Australia promised or Australia was obliged to do to assure the non-aligned nations and bring them onboard. I believe that there was a much stronger agreement. If any country signed the nuclear non-proliferation treaty Australia, along with other countries, assured them that they would have access to uranium. It did not matter whether or not the nuclear non-proliferation treaty actually delivered disarmament and non-proliferation. It did not matter whether or not the countries which signed the nuclear non-proliferation treaty were actually using uranium—whether from Australia or elsewhere—in their weapons program, or reselling reprocessed material, as France has been doing for years and years, and proliferating that material. Was part of this deal a guarantee of access to uranium without the sovereign right of countries to make a choice or make a judgment as to whether or not that country was doing the right thing?

That is the seething question. Whilst we have not blocked the consensus in relation to this motion, we want to put it on record that we are very unhappy with point 5 because of the hypocrisy that is encompassed in it. We do not want to be associated with appearing to be happy with the agreement that was reached and Australia's role in delivering that agreement.

We said at the time that we thought immediately the agreement was signed there would be a breakdown in the good vows or good words expressed. That is exactly what happened. We had the Chinese testing immediately and we have planned tests by France. We also have a media suggestion that the United States will need to test as well. There have been suggestions in the media that other nuclear states may use this as an excuse to test. How could France go to a treaty for a comprehensive test ban with other nuclear states and say, `We have done ours. Now you have to sign on the bottom line.' The other states will say, `We are not going to sign on the bottom line until we have had our eight tests or our 10 tests.'

It is hardly an argument to say that Australia can be pleased that France will sign the comprehensive test ban treaty after it has had these tests and expect that other countries which may have withheld their testing will suddenly say, `Yes, isn't this a good idea. We will let France have tests and we will sign on the bottom line after France and China have completed their test programs.'

The opposition was not the least bit interested in contributing much in relation to our concerns about the nuclear non-proliferation treaty. Perhaps if the opposition had taken some interest in some of those concerns the government would not have felt so confident that we would all believe that it was going off to save the world. Perhaps we will get more considered debate in the future. We will listen to and watch the government rather than wait and see what the consequences are a few months down the track.

I have had a brief look at the amendments proposed by Senator Hill and the Greens are inclined to support them. We join with the Australian Democrats in looking for a further amendment to recognise the cause and effect of uranium mining and the continued sale of Australian uranium to France. We take that view in consideration of all that we know and have known for some time and especially in relation to the current decision. We signal our support for the amendments proposed by Senator Hill to strengthen this resolution. It is our belief that this resolution would not be complete without calling for the cessation of the supply of uranium to France—uranium which can be used in France's weapons program and which can be used in the South Pacific for nuclear testing.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion before the chamber and the amendments that have been moved by my colleague Senator Hill. We have been told to keep our remarks fairly brief and I will try to do so.

PARA.TAB: There is massive concern in Australia and in France about the resumption of testing at Mururoa Atoll. AAP has reported the concerns expressed by eminent people in France about the resumption of nuclear testing at the atoll.

We have been told that the official reason for this testing is to make sure that the technical advantages of France's nuclear arsenal are kept up to date and in combat readiness. That particular reason does not convince some leading French newspapers, which argue that, rather than there being a technical reason for the testing, the reason is essentially political. I read from the editorial of Le Monde:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision by Jacques Chirac, the first of any great importance he has made by himself, surprised no one.
Apparently with the sole exception of Senator Evans.

The decisive arguments to justify the breaking of the moratorium respected by four of the five members of the "nuclear club" are not at all technical, they are principally political . . . It remains to be seen if it will be a good decision for Chirac and indeed for France.
The editorial in the Liberation says this:
Chirac needs a symbol, which grabs attention. Nuclear arms . . . have a type of mystical inheritance for Chirac. The announcement also has a little anti-American theatrics to it (take that Clinton).

I regret to say that this testing is not being done to advance world peace. It is not even being done for the reasons which have been stated officially by the French government. I suspect that the principal reason is that France has another round of municipal elections coming up. President Chirac sees it as important to attract votes from extreme right groups, and what better way to do it than to announce the recommencement of testing.

PARA.TAB: I suspect that the French government has not calculated the widespread detestation of this decision in the South Pacific arena. We can only hope that that message is coming through loud and strong. There is no completely safe way to test nuclear weapons. I suppose some ways are safer than others but they all involve risks. In the climate of the post-Cold War phase the risks involved with testing are not acceptable in our part of the world. It is a cliche, but nonetheless it is a persuasive argument, that if this testing was so safe and if, as the French argue strongly, people in our region should not be too concerned about it, why should this not be done on mainland France? The French have not answered that question. It is not sufficient to say, `Years ago we managed to invest all this money in building up our testing facilities in the South Pacific'. If the French government believes in the safety of this testing, it seems to me that it has failed to answer the most obvious question.

I suppose from an environmental point of view there are at least four particular things that we can point to which cause concern about the resumption of French testing. The first one involves the possibility of wholesale leakage of lagoon sediments into the ocean which of course has been affected by the nuclear testing. A cyclone, for example, may cause that particular problem.

It is interesting to note that in 1987 the respected Jacques Cousteau and his group went to the atoll and found what were thought to be large unnatural cracks and fissures in the reef. This would certainly seem to be alarming. Of course, the French claim that the integrity of the coral does not really matter. The French have said that the basalt where the explosions took place is without large fissures, but even they admit that the basalt rock can be fractured up to 400 metres around the bomb site. So there is concern about possible future leakages, some of which may be brought about by unnatural occurrences such as a cyclone or an earthquake in the area which could release to the wider environment the nuclear-affected materials.

The second matter relates to my earlier comments. There are doubts about the long-term integrity of the underlying basalt rock. There have been some 130 underground tests in the area over the last 20 or so years, and there has been widespread concern about the drilling which is involved as well as the overall effect that this massive degree of underground testing is having on the rock.
Also, one has to accept that there can be accidents with nuclear testing. There has been at least one rather major accident in the area. I quote from a newspaper report:
On July 25, 1979, a 120-kiloton weapon was being lowered down an 800m shaft when it became stuck at about 400m. The authorities could not dislodge the weapon and decided to explode it anyway.

SPEECH.PARA: The newspaper report goes on:

PARA.TAB: The result was a major underwater landslide of at least 1 million cubic metres of coral and rock. The underwater landslide produced a tidal wave comparable to a tsunami, which injured people on the southern part of Mururoa Atoll.

SPEECH.PARA: People say that they have learned from that particular accident and that that type of accident will not happen again. Nonetheless, I think history shows us there is always a risk, and that certainly causes concern.

PARA.TAB: There are serious reasons why we are concerned about the testing on the atoll, and the reasons include health aspects. I know some Australian doctors have raised particular health concerns about what they believe are the effects of previous testing on the atoll. As I have just indicated, there are continuing environmental concerns, despite the assurances we have been given by the French government.

So I join with my colleagues in urging the French government to think again about these tests and to recognise that the advice that it may well have received on the political effects of this decision may have underestimated the strength of feeling throughout the Pacific region regarding the resumption of French testing. It is certainly our hope that the message which will be sent forth from this parliament to the French government will have an effect, and hopefully President Chirac and his ministers will, for good political reasons and, I hope, strong environmental reasons, decide not to proceed with these eight tests.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened to and I understand Senator Robert Ray's comment about why it would be a good thing if we could show solidarity by both houses of this parliament passing a common resolution. I understand why he made the comments about it being nice if we could resist the opportunity to engage in some product differentiation. But the fact of the matter is that, while we might be able to agree with the majority of the government's motion, that motion is quite deficient in not mentioning the cause and effect and in not mentioning the connection between the mining and the exporting of Australian uranium and the resumption of French testing, which we are all expressing our outrage about. That is why I need to move the revised amendment circulated in the Democrats' name.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator McGauran)—Senator Kernot, you are foreshadowing the movement of it. I have another amendment in front of me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, Senator Hill's. I thought he moved his.
—Therefore you can only foreshadow your amendment and move it later on.
—I foreshadow the revised amendment which seeks to add at the end of the motion:

SPEECH.PARA: resolves to recognise the cause and effect relationship between the mining and export of uranium and the resumption of French nuclear testing in the South Pacific and refrain from any further sales of Australian uranium to France.'.

I concur with the comments that Senator Margetts made with respect to part 5 of the government's motion. I share her reservations. Nevertheless, the Democrats intend to vote for those seven points, subject to certain qualifications.

PARA.TAB: We need to ask a couple of questions. What is it that encourages France to use the South Pacific rather than other areas of the world? It comes back to government and opposition policy. It is because of the ambivalence of this government towards the nuclear industry ever since large quantities of uranium were discovered here. But we can also go back to 1987, with the decision to reverse the banning of uranium exports to France and the signing of the lengthy contract between France's EdF and ERA Ranger. This made us particularly vulnerable.

This says to France that Australia is a bit of a soft touch. It also says that Australia is prepared to put financial gain before world peace. If the government had not taken this action in 1987, I think we would have sent to Mr Chirac and his ilk the sort of powerful message that we needed to send. But, unfortunately, what it means now is that we are vulnerable, we are up to our eyeballs in the industry and we are supplying a material which has the capacity to find its way indirectly to the production of nuclear weapons.

We are one of about 12 countries with uranium. We have some of the largest deposits. We are in the middle range of exporting countries. Our appropriate response should have been to simply say, `No, we are not going to export.' That response is as timely now as it was in 1988, when the Canberra Times on 24 June pointed out for all of us in a response to a report by the Australian Safeguards Office about proliferation and its effect, `You can no longer say that Australian atoms of uranium have a high probability of not going into bombs.' At the time, the then minister Kerin said, `The Australian Safeguards Office has advised that the plant in producing low enriched uranium does process both obligated nuclear material which remains in civil use and non-obligated nuclear material which can, after further enrichment, be used for military purposes.'

As the experience with the large German uranium broking company recently showed us, flag or label swapping is an accepted and common part of the industry. The 1988 flag-label swapping episode proved conclusively that by swapping the label `Made in the United States', in which country enrichment to weapons grade is okay, for the label `Made in Australia', it is possible to bypass Australia's written approval requirement for enrichment above 20 per cent. It is okay to have safeguards, but it is so absolutely easy to bypass those safeguards that I wonder what use they are. I would argue that they are rendered useless by quite easily swapping the flags on a shipment of usable Australian uranium and an amount of useless uranium from a country with less strict conditions. Because this is constantly a possibility, the only way we can avoid our responsibility for being a part of this chain and a part of this process is to cease the mining and export of uranium.

I can signal that the Democrats would support Senator Hill's amendment. But I raise the point that the last part of the amendment about discussing with the United States the possibility of data sharing to remove the public French excuse for tests—it raises the matter I raised in question time—we would want to first ascertain from them why they are now talking about testing as a response to the French action.

Finally, as I said, I am mindful of Senator Ray's comments. I would not expect—although I am happy to be surprised—the government and the opposition to vote for the Democrats' amendment, because I understand that they would wish to avoid product differentiation. They would wish to avoid public comment on their own public policy positions, which they have in common, where they have refused to acknowledge the cause and effect linkage. But they cannot keep avoiding acknowledgment of cause and effect forever because, as has happened in so many other important debates in this country—the woodchip issue is a contemporary example—the facts catch up with them.

The Australian people understand that sometimes trade arguments and economic arguments are no substitute for moral arguments. That is why, in supporting the government's motion, we do not believe it would have been appropriate to let the discussion go without raising that one fundamental point: if we were not involved in the export of uranium, then we would not have to wear any moral responsibility for our role in the cause and effect in assisting the resumption of testing in the South Pacific. That is an important point to make.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have made a number of statements over the years with regard to nuclear testing. It appears that when a country embarks on this nefarious project truth tends to go out the window. Certainly there is regularly only limited and less than frank disclosure about what in fact is occurring. I believe, from personal knowledge, that that is precisely what occurred when the British were engaged in their nuclear testing at Maralinga. I have access to the details which were mapped by a relation of mine in the particular area as to the direction of the wind when it was being publicly suggested that the wind was blowing in another direction.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to digress in respect of these particular areas because I know that this is an underground nuclear testing operation. Nevertheless, the French government has been insistent over many years in its quest to perfect its nuclear arsenal, without proper regard to the effect that that is having on people in the South Pacific and on other nations which may indeed see this as an excuse for attempting to perfect—again, if that is the correct word—their nuclear arsenals.

It all boils down, in my view, to a fundamental disrespect for human life. Of course, that is not the only area where the French are not upholding the dignity and inestimable value of human life, let alone other forms of life in the environment. For example, when Roussel Uclaf was developing and testing the abortion drug RU486, there was a great deal of outcry against that for the simple reason that that was chemical warfare against the smallest human being; it also was based on a dreadful assertion that the tiniest of human beings was to be regarded as a disease for which a chemical destruction was required.

The French government took charge of that and, because of its shareholdings in Roussel, insisted that those tests go ahead and they are continuing to go ahead—in Australia! It all boils down, in my view, to an attitude on the part of the French government which fails to see the importance and the preciousness of human life. And that is so in regard to its attitude on nuclear testing in the Pacific.

I have been able to look at the motion and the amendment before us. I have no objection to these proposals that have been put before the chamber. I am half inclined, actually, to support the foreshadowed amendment by Senator Kernot. The difficulty with that, of course, is in the effect that it would have on those industries in France and the workers in France who rely on those industries which in turn rely on the export of our uranium. To suddenly cut that off would, or may, have unfortunate effects. I heard what Senator Kernot said and I have not been given anything from what has been said which would indicate that that would definitely not have a very substantial effect on innocent persons, particularly workers in French industries reliant on our export of uranium.

I welcome this debate. I welcome the bipartisan attitude that is developing on this matter and the clear indication by all sides of politics that this is a matter on which we must take a united stand not only in the interests of Australia, not only in the interests of the people of the South Pacific—and we have a very special interest in them—but also in the interests of the people of the world, including the people of France. Because if we do not stand united on this threat of this proposal to resume nuclear testing, what will we stand firm on?

I would like to say to the Senate that I am not going to repeat what I have said before. I make no bones about it: so far as the French President is concerned, he says it is a passionate response. Yes, it is a passionate response, but I believe that it is also a logical response. There is no necessary dichotomy between what may be a passionate response and what may be a logical response. We are human beings. After all, I would have thought that the French, of all people, might have understood a passionate response. I am probably the most unpassionate person in this chamber, but I do feel very strongly about this matter. I congratulate the leaders of all the parties concerned for taking a view which is almost, if not totally, unanimous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —A moment ago, Senator Harradine posed a rhetorical question: if we do not feel passionate or strongly enough about this to take some action, what do we feel strongly enough about? I will be debating another motion about this matter later this afternoon, so I do not want to transgress onto those areas except to pick up on that point—that, in doing what the French are about to do, they are undermining the very important process which many of us hoped would lead not just to a test ban treaty but to a total ban on the use of nuclear weapons.

PARA.TAB: The French have actually turned that process around. They have taken us back. For that reason, I certainly feel very passionate about this matter. We have already seen that, following their decision, the US is talking about possibly resuming tests. We know that the Chinese are thumbing their noses at the test ban treaty. Bearing in mind that the use of nuclear weapons is so horrific, bearing in mind that if nuclear war should ever begin and there is a bilateral use of nuclear weapons in a war, we are really threatening the future of humankind and all the other species on the planet, as Senator Harradine has just pointed out.

This is the paramount issue on which we must become both logical and very passionate. We must object in the strongest terms to this decision, which is not a decision by the French people or even by the French government, but by the French President. One cannot help contrasting this with the AAP report of what was said by the member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Campbell, who said that one should not get too upset about this. He said that this is not going to cause any great troubles, so why were we becoming concerned? He said, `I am concerned about politicians who raise absolutely groundless fears in the community.'

This is not a groundless fear. This is a very well-based fear because the French would not be testing these weapons if they did not intend possibly using the weapons. They would not need to test them if they did not have that as at least a back-up possibility. Given that that is their intention—to have nuclear weapons with a possibility that they might actually use them—this is not a groundless fear at all. This is a very well-grounded fear, a very serious fear, and it extends to all those other nations which possess nuclear weapons, particularly those that continue to test.

Senator Harradine was talking about French workers. He is evidently unaware of the fact that some years ago the two unions in France which work in the nuclear industry raised serious questions about cracks in French nuclear reactors. Senator Harradine evidently is not aware that those two unions were actively suppressed by the French government from releasing that information to the French community. Senator Harradine perhaps is forgetting that in Australia the decision to go ahead and export uranium was taken—wrongly, in the view of the Democrats; nonetheless the decision was taken—after very extensive inquiries. There was the so-called Fox inquiry, otherwise called the Ranger inquiry, a very extensive inquiry begun by the Whitlam government and completed under the Fraser government. It was surrounded by a very intensive and extensive debate in Australia regarding the pros and cons of uranium mining and export and of all things nuclear.

France, however, made its decision to go nuclear in the aftermath of the death of President de Gaulle. There was no public debate in France at all. The French are largely ignorant of the dangers of things nuclear. For those sorts of reasons—the suppression of the French unions, the failure of France to encourage the sort of debate which went on in Australia during the 1970s and which has continued ever since—I think the concern over French workers who may be displaced by a ban on uranium exports from Australia is itself misplaced.

There is also significant evidence that French workers have been exposed to high levels of radiation, particularly in the reprocessing industry, and particularly in the attempts by France to develop a breeder reactor. In that respect I think Senator Harradine would be better advised to look to the longer term health of French workers and support the move being made by the Democrats to add to this motion—and Senator Kernot gave notice of this—an amendment which would seek to ban the export of uranium to France. Of course, we would support the banning of the export of uranium to all countries.

I pick up a point made by Senator Margetts during her speech. One of the things that we objected to very vigorously during the 1970s, before the Fox inquiry and then later before the Flowers inquiry in Great Britain, the sixth report on nuclear pollution, was that the non-proliferation treaty is compromised in that it requires not only that there be non-proliferation in terms of nuclear weapons, but also that nations possessing nuclear technology, nuclear information and nuclear materials share those materials for so-called civilian purposes with other nations.

As Senator Margetts and I would certainly agree, there is no clear line to be drawn between the civilian nuclear program and the military nuclear program. That is one of the fundamental reasons why, since 1977, we have strongly objected to the export of uranium. One cannot be sure where that uranium finishes up. I guess the most recent proof of that is the observation of the strong objections by the US to the provision by Russia of nuclear power stations to Iran. Iran will say, `We want nuclear power. We want a source of electricity energy which is not based on oil. When our oil runs out, we need nuclear energy.'

I am sure the Americans do not believe that the signing of the NPT by Iran is a sufficient guarantee that they will not divert some of that technology into weapons. Why else would they object? Similarly, one has objections—and I think Australia should have taken this position—to the Americans and South Koreans providing nuclear reactors to North Korea. I do not think the Japanese are particularly happy. I think the evidence is that, when nations are really pushed on the NPT, they are not happy with the guarantees of nuclear safety.

Turning specifically to the motion which the government has moved this afternoon, I have no great difficulty with the first five paragraphs. I do not think they go far enough but one accepts them and one can support them. However, paragraph (6) asks that the Senate, including all its members—and I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: (6) notes that Australia will do all in its power and . . .

I am certainly not confident that the government either has done all in its power or will do all in its power. I certainly cannot support those particular words. The government is presuming too much. If the opposition is minded—and I believe it is—to support my urgency motion which will be debated immediately after this one, then the opposition is not prepared to accept that the government has done all in its power or will do all in its power.
