More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The weak and inadequate response of the Government to the resumption of French nuclear weapons testing.

SPEECH.PARA: The response of the Federal government to the announcement that the French will resume nuclear testing in the Pacific has been and continues to be totally inadequate. It is not commensurate with the outrage felt by the majority of Australians or the many people scattered through the Pacific region. New Zealand has responded in a much more forthright manner to the arrogance of the French. Perhaps if the French had blown up a nuclear protest boat in an Australian harbour, the reaction of our supine government may have been stronger, but given the appeasement approach that this government has shown to Indonesia and other nations that have committed heinous crimes against humanity, one cannot be too sure.

PARA.TAB: The French action threatens all humankind. It does so directly through the release of further radioactive material, which will pose a hazard not only to this generation but to many future generations. This is because of the long lived nature of many of the radio nuclides which their tests will release. Of more immediate concern is the threat to the processes of banning forever the use of nuclear weapons. This must start with a total ban on the testing of nuclear weapons. The French action undermines this process in many serious ways. It makes more difficult to argue with nations such as China that it also should stop nuclear testing. The US is now talking of resuming testing.

But there is a more important flaw in the French claim that it is committed to a test ban, but only after it has conducted another eight tests. The test ban is only one of the steps on the road to a total renunciation of the use of nuclear weapons. Clearly, the French are reserving the right to use nuclear weapons. Why else do they want to ensure that they have the latest and best nuclear weapons in their armamentarium? The French decision thus threatens the very security and survival of all humankind. It puts back the nuclear clock to five minutes to midnight. The weakness of their claim that Polynesia is French territory and that this is the reason they do not conduct tests in France is too transparent to require an answer. If the underground tests are so safe, why not conduct them at home in a similarly deep hole? Economically, it would be much cheaper, but what would the French people say about that?

One ex-Navy man rang me with a response which is typical of the many very strong and unanimous objections that I have received. The arrogance of the French seems to have been particularly remarked upon. This man, who had offered his life in the Second World War to defend France and rescue it from Nazi occupation, was so irate that some of his comments would be struck from the Hansard should I use them here. He was particularly furious at the weakness of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Gareth Evans, likening it to one of the excretions of a young female person. He was and is especially incensed at the disregard shown by the French for the thousands of Australians and people of other nations who gave their lives fighting for France in the war and the thousands more who still suffer as a consequence of injuries sustained in that war. Who is threatening France, he wants to know? Why do we not offer assistance to French colonies in the Pacific to gain their independence, he wants to know? This is the sort of extreme annoyance felt by virtually every Australian person.

What has our government and the opposition done? This government of ours has tied its own hands in relation to trade sanctions. It has had the support of the opposition at every stage. The French could be murdering their children, mincing them up and turning them into pet food and we could not stop the import of that pet food into Australia unless they were trying to sell it on the Australian market at a price less than the price on the French supermarket shelves. Such is the arrangement that our government has assented to under the GATT and the World Trade Organisation that no amount of moral justification can discharge our overriding obligation to free trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is absolutely untrue.

—You're the one, minister, who is so committed to trade at all costs. The French, through their actions, can threaten the future of humankind yet we may not ban the import and sale of French goods lest we offend the obligation to free trade under the World Trade Organisation. As the Democrats have consistently argued, this is putting too high a price on the sacredness of unfettered market forces.

PARA.TAB: There are a number of other considerations that should be taken into account when determining whether and to what extent we should trade with other nations. Trade is not a paramount good. The Australian Democrats have argued vigorously against the mining and export of uranium ever since our formation. This was based on both the Ranger report and the UK report on the nuclear industry. Both major independent reports found close links between the civil and military use of nuclear technology. For pragmatic reasons, the Labor Party, which initially endorsed a ban on uranium mining, has had its policy role ignored by a pragmatic Labor government which has replaced the light on the hill with a faint glow of radioactive contamination. In this it has again had the pragmatic support of the opposition. The Australian Democrats urge the government to review its policy and ban uranium exports, starting with exports to France.

The claim that trade boycotts should not be used because trade between Australia and France is small compared with the totality of French trade and that therefore such boycotts would be useless is a morally bankrupt assertion. This would be true of many small nations. Individually they may be small but together they add up to a sizeable part of French trade. The claim is similar to the claim that Australia should do nothing about its greenhouse emissions because we contribute less than two per cent to total world emissions. If this line of reasoning is accepted, it becomes an excuse for doing nothing at all about anything, even in the face of the most serious threat.

It is also claimed that such a boycott would harm some Australian businesses and workers dealing in French goods as well as French workers. It is said, `These are innocent bystanders. Any attack on the resumption of nuclear tests must be aimed at the French government.' But who put Mr Chirac into the position in which he can independently commit the world to more nuclear tests? It is the citizens of France. They are the ones who can change the decision if enough pressure is brought to bear through trade sanctions.

As to the Australian end, just as our government can suddenly increase the sales tax on recycled paper and severely and adversely affect an important industry in Australia, so too can the government change the trade arrangements in ways that have adverse influences. As a nation we do not fail to do a thing because it may have some adverse effects. Almost every law passed through this parliament has benefits and costs which are borne by different sections of the public in different degree. We pass these laws believing that the benefits outweigh the costs and that the laws move Australian society in a better direction. In a similar way, if we believe that a strong protest against the French nuclear tests is sufficiently important, we will consider trade sanctions recognising the greater good is thus served. Just as the capital now invested in recycled paper may be forced to relocate into other areas so the capital invested in businesses importing and selling French goods may find its way into other, perhaps Australian, manufactures. The effect of this, just like the increase in the sales tax on recycled paper, will be long term and more likely to effectively reverse the French decision.

One could paraphrase Gareth Evans in his book Australia's foreign relations in the world of the 1990s and substitute nuclear weapons for apartheid and France for South Africa. I quote with some licence:

SPEECH.PARA: We live in a world of many injustices and it may be questioned why a country like Australia should commit so much to an issue so little of our making. But the system of nuclear testing, based as it is on an assertion of French arrogance over the security and welfare of the whole of humankind stands so far beyond the pale that it simply cannot be regarded as just another unpalatable regime. If we in Australia wash our hands of nuclear testing, on the comfortable but indecent justification that it is too far away or too intractable a problem, we would not only have failed in our humanitarian duty, but have debased the very values which are at the core of human survival.

The response of both the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the foreign minister to this most alarming French decision has been pathetic. A trip to Paris and a weak slap on the wrist will not deter the arrogant French. We have seen that with the response today. Much stronger action is needed. The Australian people want much stronger action from our government. In this urgency motion today, the Senate censures the government for its weakness so far and calls on the government to stiffen its response.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes, at the end of a long day in the Senate, I think it must in some ways be comfortable to sit on the crossbenches. I must admit I am never tempted to think that it would be comfortable to sit in the opposition but, now and again, because you can advocate everything and not have to implement anything, it is a tempting thought. That is a luxury which governments do not have. It is a luxury which oppositions should not have but which they do sometimes have, and I will come to that in a moment.

PARA.TAB: Government is in fact about making hard choices and difficult decisions, not just about asserting a loosely inter-related series of things which you wish might be true whilst not having to be concerned about the consequences. I have to say that I was going to and will still acknowledge, notwithstanding Senator Coulter's speech, that the Australian Democrats at least have had the virtue of consistency in their opposition to nuclear testing. That is at least a virtue which should be acknowledged in this debate because others here do not have that virtue. Also, in these matters the Democrats have the consistency of advocating more than whatever is being advocated. Whatever might be said, they say that it should be one thing more because they will never have to implement those things which they seek to do.

I was extremely disappointed to find some untrue statements included in some of the attributions Senator Coulter referred to regarding values and attitudes to the government and ministers in particular, probably including me, which I found morally unacceptable, although I do accept the point that trade is not an end in itself. No-one has ever asserted that it is or should be but I do not think it is very healthy, constructive or pleasant to make untrue assertions about what others might do in catastrophic situations.

I was also disappointed to hear the enthusiasm with which Senator Coulter was prepared to fight to the last drop of other people's blood. He was prepared to advocate that other people should lose their jobs because it might be in the greater good. Sometimes governments have to make decisions where the benefit of the whole has some disadvantage for the minority. In those circumstances the government's obligation in the normal circumstance is to compensate those people: the beneficiaries should compensate the losers. I listened for the faint echo of that principle, but I missed it.

This is a very serious question. I am not particularly referring to the motion before us because the collective view of the Senate has been reflected in many irrelevant ways over a long time, and I suspect that this might be another. But the issue at the core of French nuclear weapons testing and the way in which Australia, the region and other countries around the world which are being mobilised against this should most effectively express that concern are important. It is not helped by allusions to the effect that, `If only we think of another cleverer thing we will suddenly get the French to reverse this decision'. It is a question of asking what is the appropriate response for a government in the region which is very strongly opposed to this decision, which has consistently opposed French nuclear testing in the Pacific—and nuclear testing by other countries—and which will consistently continue to oppose it. How should this be reflected? At least, as I said, the Democrats and, for the period they have been here, the Greens in their attitudes to the issue of nuclear testing have consistently been opposed to it, and that is to their credit.

Those opposite have not always been opposed to testing. There has been a large amount of recitation of the history of their criticism of this government when we sought to take measures to limit nuclear testing in the Pacific. They criticised us for in some ways seeking to undermine the situation of the United States, the French and others in the region. That is very telling but I suppose people are entitled to say, `Look, that was 10 years ago; we are wiser now; we have an alternative view.'

Let us be benign and say, `Of course people are entitled to learn, improve and change.' But this change has been a little more dramatic because on Wednesday the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was saying in a very responsible way that the government's response was appropriate. Yet, within 48 hours he was advocating change. Those opposite are now at fever pitch with a desperation for more urgent measures.

If what we were doing on Wednesday was appropriate, how in 36 hours can it be a fundamental requirement that this response be changed, that now we are to take action that is not appropriate—that goes beyond what was acknowledged to be an appropriate response? It was appropriate at the time when the interpretation of the decision was much weaker than the reality. The public had not perceived all the elements of the decision but, even so, the Leader of the Opposition was prepared to say it was appropriate.

There is no doubt why this change has taken place. It is the very opposite of leadership; it is the perception of a political opportunity because of public concern or what Senator Coulter called extreme annoyance—which I am not sure captures the spirit but, for consistency, I will use that phrase—at the arrogance of the French government reflected in this decision, at the complete denial of the rights of people in this region and about the commitments the French government made to exercise utmost restraint in the agreement on the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and its recent extension.

A political opportunity was seen. All leadership and responsibility was abrogated, in a 36-hour switch, to pursue enthusiastically where a vote might lie. The government's position has been clear from the very start. It was always clear and we have always delivered an unequivocal message to the French. We delivered it, contrary to the inaccurate assertion by Senator Hill at question time, before President Chirac was elected president and after he was elected president, in an attempt to influence the decision-making process before it was made.

It is always easier to do that than to change decisions after they have been made. We set out to seek to influence that decision. I do not know of any other country that was doing it; as far as I know, we were the only one. Let us not pretend that even if there had been 10 countries supporting us we would have changed President Chirac's mind. The comments he made during the election seemed to be inexorably leading to this conclusion.

But it was appropriate to seek to do that, to point out the commitments that had been entered into, the concerns of Australia, the implications for the region and the implications in the region for France—not that the implications for France are our concern, but we hoped that might be an effective way of persuading the French government that it was not in its interests to act in this way. Since the decision was made there has been an initial statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the decision—which is always brushed aside when it does not suit, but which is not unimportant—to call in the ambassador and to send our ambassador in to deliver the protests.

TALK.START.PARA: —When did you do that?
—On 14 June. That is a matter of public knowledge. It was on television. I will send you a copy, if you like. The pictures were quite big; you would probably understand them.
—Why didn't you do that before they announced it?

—How could we call someone in to protest before the French had made the decision? This is preposterous. Please take this person outside, slap him on the cheeks, wake him up and send him back in so he can make a coherent contribution to the debate. We made it clear to the government in Paris—
—Did you tell them what retaliatory action you would take?

—We made our opposition absolutely clear. All the detail of what was said by the Prime Minister, the foreign minister, the defence minister and me—among others—was necessary. We did not have some illusion that the French would fall over but it would have been a dereliction if we had not done that. It was a necessary part of the attempt which needed to be made.

PARA.TAB: Since that time we have made protests and taken the initiative in mounting a South Pacific protest. On day one we could not say that because it is not for us to announce unilaterally what the South Pacific Forum will do, although we were very confident what it would do. We said on day one that we would be approaching the other countries of the South Pacific. Within 24 hours we were able to announce the detail of the proposal and the details of the delegation—and it is proceeding. It will be meeting tomorrow morning, Australian time, with the French foreign minister, seeking to do those things which we asserted in the resolution carried by the House of Representatives today.

We said we would do it and we initiated it immediately; we have frozen defence cooperation and we have made it clear what potential implications this French activity has for defence procurement contracts. We have ruled out quite clearly any assistance to the French in their testing preparations. We have put in place effective measures to ensure there is no accidental or incidental support of that kind.

We have been urged to do more in multilateral forums. Let me say in which multilateral forums we have already taken initiatives and received support in condemning the resumption of French nuclear testing: the Atomic Energy Agency, the conference on disarmament, and the United Nations. That is not a bad start. Those are the three most appropriate forums. The first two have been in session; the UN is not yet. This has been done in concert with the South Pacific nations and is part of the process of trying to mobilise the maximum international opinion.

This issue is not new; we have been discussing it with other countries for a long time. Other countries have been forming their views over a long period and they do not need Australia to tell them the implications of this issue. We set out to seek to mobilise them, but to pretend that if we do not scurry around and talk to them they will not understand what is taking place is absurd.

The Japanese government is one of the major influential governments in the world. It made its views clear very forthrightly to the French government in terms very similar to our own. It did that not because we asked, but because it is the appropriate and sensible policy of the Japanese government. That it was not successful does not mean we do not appreciate that that government did it. That we were not successful does not mean that the Japanese do not appreciate the fact that we did it. We both think it is the appropriate course of action, as do other countries in the South Pacific.

We have set out to be consistent in advocating the policy of the Australian government with regard to this matter but have set out to do so in a way that deals with concerns of France and is directed towards the interests of France, not towards punishing Australia or South Pacific nations, the innocent parties. If, for example, we were to cut all defence ties with France, we would no longer be able to provide the humanitarian assistance and surveillance which are of great value to the countries of the South Pacific. We intend to continue to provide that—and they want us to. Nor are we going to take action on the trade front that will cost jobs in Australia.

This is not a matter over which it is appropriate to punish Australians. We have no intention of doing so; we have never had any intention of doing so. If Australians wish to take action by direct protests within the law, we support that. If they wish to take action by mobilising their consumer power, we support that. We will continue to provide leadership in terms of a balanced, appropriate response that comes from a government with a long and consistent record, since 1983, of opposing French nuclear activity in our region. Their action throws into question the whole legitimacy of French involvement in this region. We will continue to raise those issues and speak up for the interests of Australia, but not in a way that jeopardises the interests of Australia and Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the opposition to support the proposition, although not the argument, presented by Senator Coulter. In the other place today, the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) moved this motion:

SPEECH.PARA: Join with New Zealand and suspend military cooperation with France; except for surveillance, United Nations and humanitarian activities,
Cease refuelling all French non-humanitarian military transit flights;

Recall the Australian Ambassador to show depth of our concern, and to develop in association with the South Pacific Forum a Regional plan of action to embarrass and if possible hinder French nuclear testing; including action in the United Nations condemning French nuclear testing as a gross abuse of colonial power and (along with similar tests by the PRC) as gross violations of the world environment.
Discuss with the USA the possibility of data sharing to remove the public French excuse for the tests;

That certainly goes a lot further than the government's position at the beginning of today. While I welcomed and supported the proposal that the Senate recently passed, the fact is that this government had a wishy-washy, half-baked response to the quite improper proposal of President Chirac.

PARA.TAB: It is worth looking at some comments made by Mr Padraic McGuinness in last Saturday's Sydney Morning Herald:

What President Chirac of France has done is to indulge in a supremely cynical exercise in domestic politics, using nuclear testing in the same manner, though on a much greater scale, as Paul Keating uses republicanism to bolster his own support.

SPEECH.PARA: It is just as cynical and just as disgraceful. He continues:

Just as Paul Keating has taken over the Left of the Labor Party by his cynical exploitation of the republican issue, so Jacques Chirac is bidding to take over the Right of French politics by giving the French an issue which will swamp their racism and their fear of European federalism.

I agree with Mr McGuinness. There is no doubt that President Chirac's action is a supremely cynical exercise. It does relate to domestic politics. I do not think it has any significance in terms of France's nuclear power. Senator Coulter is jumping at shadows in suggesting that. This is a domestic political stunt just like the republican matter of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating)—I almost said `President Keating'—is a domestic political stunt.

PARA.TAB: I was intrigued to hear today the Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Robert Ray) say that the opposition is expressing a much stronger view about nuclear testing now than it did 10 years ago when the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Howard) was previously our leader. It is interesting that in those days there was a cold war. There was a stand-off between the major nuclear powers. Times have changed a lot since 1985. I remember that in 1985 someone called Mr Paul Keating favoured a GST. So times have definitely changed since then. It is all right for the Labor Party to change its position, even though the facts have not changed in that case, but it is quite wrong for the Liberal Party to change its position when the world scene has changed dramatically. Let us hear no more of that sort of nonsense.

Let us recognise that we should be demanding, not just seeking, an unequivocal assurance from France that it will sign the nuclear non-proliferation treaty without reservation in autumn next year. That should be central to what the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) is supposed to be doing on his little trip to Paris. I have not heard that that is central to his trip. It simply ought to be. I have to acknowledge that this justification by the French that it is only exploding eight more nuclear devices because they will soon be signing the treaty and will no longer explode any bombs is a concession about which we ought to demand reassurance. I will be very disappointed—it will be clear evidence of his failure—if Senator Evans does not come back with an unequivocal assurance of that kind. I will not hold my breath.

However, I am concerned about the levels of over-reaction by some people in Australia. Terrorists have burnt a consulate and so on. People who talk about fears of an adverse effect on health in the region, for example, really overstate the issue in order to create some kind of hysteria. This was pointed out in the Weekend Australian editorial:

SPEECH.PARA: Scientists at the Australian Radiation Laboratory say there is no danger from the type of tests proposed to those living in the immediate vicinity, either directly or from the contamination of seafood.

I was interested in another public response. Dr Stephen Birrell from Flinders University in South Australia says that he at last understands why Senator Evans has made such a half-baked response to this disgraceful behaviour by the French. I quote:
Gareth, you have sold us out, the true believers, and we know why—the UN beckons and you know how powerful the French are in international affairs. Shame, Gareth.
I wonder whether Senator Evans is going to give up his French lessons, which I understand are a public expense, in his endeavours to become the next Secretary-General.

PARA.TAB: Another problem—I think Michelle Grattan pointed this out—is this:

The publicity and public backlash to the French tests contrasts interestingly with the much more muted response to the latest Chinese testing. Keating's statement on Wednesday recalled the Chinese had conducted a test on 15 May, immediately after the test ban treaty negotiations. This prompted a strong protest from Australia at the time and another reprimand in the Keating statement. But it did not generate anything like the public outrage the French tests have.

SPEECH.PARA: We have double standards. There should be a much stronger and more rational response. But it is ludicrous that Melbourne restaurants are being vandalised and so on.

PARA.TAB: The vehemence of the public response is because the government's response has been so inadequate. The public response has almost replaced the government response in terms of strength, with the result that it has gone over the top. Senator Coulter made an absurd remark that the opposition and the government would not object if the French minced up children and sold them as pet food. That generating of hatred is really quite ludicrous and is counterproductive in this kind of debate. I hope that this will be a much more positive debate than what Senator Coulter made it at the beginning.

TALK.START.PARA: —I, like my colleague, disassociate myself completely from the over-the-top remarks Senator Coulter made in speaking first in this debate. Like Senator Baume, I agree with the sentiments of the motion moved by Senator Coulter, if not his arguments. It really is a question of too little too late. Senator McMullan tried to give the best spin to what he says the government could possibly have done and what it has done. But, like most things the Labor Party does, nobody really believes him. It is a shame it is the case with this government that nobody believes anything it says nowadays.

PARA.TAB: There seems to have been this flurry in the last few days since the announcement was made. The Labor Party has suddenly realised that this is a major political issue in Australia, and it then determined that something needed to be done. There are many things it could have done before the announcement was made. Senator McMullan and Senator Gareth Evans and most of those people should have realised that, once the French made the public announcement that these testings were to continue, it would be very difficult for anyone to change the minds of the French people and the French government.

Had Senator Evans been interested in this, had he focused on it before that announcement was made, maybe the sorts of things that he is doing now could have been done at that particular time. If he had taken the Australian public into his confidence, maybe then the Australian public could have demonstrated, before the decision was made, just what their views were. Maybe something could have come out of that that would have assisted in having the French not make that formal announcement. So my concern is that this government, the Labor Party, has done far too little, and it has been far too late that it has done it.

I note that my colleague Senator Baume has mentioned that there is, of course, no point in pursuing and propagating theories and fears that will not eventuate. He mentioned, in particular, the health concern. Whilst I acknowledge what Senator Baume says, I say to you, Mr Acting Deputy President, that in the north of Queensland, where I come from, along the northern coastal area there is a real concern—perhaps it is not scientifically based—that in some way the French testing underground will affect weather patterns in North Queensland. This may be irrational. It may not be based upon any scientific fact, but it is a matter that does concern many people who live upon the North Queensland coastal area.

Constituents have reminded me—and I have not had the opportunity to look into this and refresh my memory on the actual facts, but you, Mr Acting Deputy President, as a Queenslander, might recall the facts—that on the Atherton Tableland 10 years or so ago there was some evidence of some nuclear fallout that got into the grass and was eaten by the dairy cattle and ended up in the milk supplies that Milanda milk was distributing at that time. This is going back quite some time. What the factual basis and the scientific basis of that was, I do not know. I have not had the opportunity of researching it, but it is something that has been raised with me quite a number of times in the last two to three days, particularly in that part of Far North Queensland.

So people are genuinely concerned. They would have hoped that their government could have done something about this before the French got themselves into a position where I do not think there is any resiling. Once that decision has been made, once the face has been shown, it is very difficult for them to change their position.

I am also very concerned that, as it turned out from question time today, Senator Ray—although he was so equivocal about it that it was difficult to find out just what his position was—seemed to dissociate himself. It seems that the government does not share—I think this was the final stage it got to—Senator Evans's view that, `Oh, well, it could have been a lot worse.' To me, it seems that that sort of insensitiveness is something that really the government or Senator Evans should apologise for—he is not here; he is overseas—that complete insensitivity of suggesting, `Well, it could have been a lot worse than it is.'

I do not want to hold the Senate up. I know that there is a lot of important legislation that we want to proceed with. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating today the government response to the resumption of French nuclear weapons testing. And yes, it is both weak and inadequate, but it is interesting to see today that both of the major parties are responding to the quite clear public response.

PARA.TAB: A representative from a magazine rang me a few days ago and asked me if I would write down the answers to 10 questions put to me in relation to the proposed resumption of French nuclear testing in the Pacific. They said, `What we usually do is get one person on either side of the argument to provide answers to these questions.' They said, `We're having a lot of trouble, however, finding anyone who will provide the other side of the argument.'

That is exactly why we are here today. We are not here today because either of the major parties has suddenly discovered a conscience about nuclear issues. We are here today because it is accepted that it is a very strong electorate issue, and that is very important. Some people think, because the anti-nuclear movement has been small in resources, that it has gone away and that, in fact, the issues have gone away. The reality is no, the issues have now become mainstream; and the trouble is that the government failed to recognise them.

France is the major reprocessor of plutonium from nuclear reactors. The primary function of reprocessing is to build nuclear weapons. Countries do not need to reprocess plutonium for their nuclear reactors: they can use uranium. Whichever way Australian uranium is sold to France, it can be used to produce plutonium in nuclear reactors which is enriched in reprocessing plants in France and which may be shipped overseas. The reality is that the nonsense I have been hearing—`Well, it's only a little drop in the ocean. We don't have to take responsibility. It might hurt a few jobs.'—is actually closing your eyes to the fact and saying that there is a small amount of morality—a bit like being a bit pregnant. We are going to be either moral or ethical in this, or we are not. It seems that the government is not.

Australia is a major contributor to the spread of nuclear weapons in France, the nuclear weapons states and nuclear powered countries with nuclear weapons aspirations. Giving a country nuclear technologies is akin to giving it nuclear weapons potential.

Over the last eight years, the federal government has given permission for enough plutonium of Australian origin to be separated for the construction of 250 nuclear weapons. This figure is based on figures in the annual reports of the Australian Safeguards Office, which show that since 1986 the Australian government has given permission for spent fuel containing 327 tonnes of Australian origin uranium to be reprocessed. This has allowed for the separation of approximately 2.88 tonnes of weapons-useable plutonium, which is enough to construct at least 250 nuclear weapons. If all spent fuel containing Australian uranium were reprocessed, the amount of plutonium separated would rise to a massive 14 tonnes.

The separation of plutonium from reprocessing does not go into reactors. Greenpeace has estimated that by the year 2010 stockpiles of commercially separated plutonium by reprocessors, including France, will be greater than the plutonium contained in the world's nuclear weapons and military stockpiles; that is, in excess of 500 tonnes.

Australia has consent mechanisms in place to allow the retransfer and reprocessing of Australian origin uranium and nuclear materials. These are bilateral agreements with countries, including France. They are treaty level documents and are tabled in parliament only after signing. The working detail is contained in separate administrative arrangements, which are kept secret at the request of customer countries.

Why has Australia not withdrawn its commitments to allow reprocessing of Australian origin nuclear material? It is because Australia hides behind the fallacy that the International Atomic Energy Agency safeguards will prevent countries from using Australian nuclear material for non-peaceful purposes. It allows customer countries, such as Belgium, Finland, France, Germany, Japan, the Netherlands, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, the UK and the United States, to reprocess Australian nuclear material under so-called safeguards claiming that reprocessing is `associated with efficient energy use'.
Safeguards, however, clearly do not work. Their inadequacy was spelt out clearly by Hans Bliz, the Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency, in 1982, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: My 140 IAEA inspectors cannot possibly keep track of the 16,000 tons of nuclear material housed in 350 sites world-wide. You cannot stop proliferation by safeguards.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the world of foreign affairs and in the art of diplomacy, words are bullets and timing is absolutely everything. Our Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) boasts of having both skills but, in representing this government, he has failed in both. This government has failed to lead Australia and failed to lead the region, and that has been detrimental to our standing in the region and within the international community.

PARA.TAB: The government should not believe that its response to the French nuclear testing will not be noticed by the international community because the inadequacy of its response is a recognised pattern of this government in many other issues. That is why my colleagues and I support the urgency motion moved by the Australian Democrats condemning the weak and inadequate response of the government to the resumption of French nuclear weapons testing.

I should add that the parliament is united in condemning the fire bombing of the French consulate in Perth. Thankfully, no-one was injured by that act of terrorism, but in condemning it we must remember the attack on the Rainbow Warrior and make the following distinctions: the attack here was not government inspired; there was no loss of life; it has been soundly condemned by this parliament and all Australians; and no hero status has been given to the terrorists.

As outlined in question time today by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Hill, Australia had timing on its side but we failed to take advantage of it. When the government sent its letter par avion to the French foreign affairs office some months ago it had timing on its side because it knew this decision was coming. However, instead of taking advantage of that timing, it clearly signalled to the French government its inadequate and weak response.

The delegation that is now in Paris—we wish them well—should have gone weeks if not months ago, particularly with the knowledge that this decision was coming. That is the point, Senator McMullan, that we are making: you do not wait for the decision; you lay down the strongest possible protest and outline the actions that you will take. If the French think you are not going to take any action, they will ride roughshod over you, which is exactly what they have done.

Interestingly enough, simultaneous with the posting of that letter to the French government, meekly protesting the possibility of resumption on nuclear testing, the Australian government sent a very warm invitation to the French to join the South Pacific forum which, ironically, will occur at the same time as the first nuclear test at Mururoa. That would be a marvellous, hot-headed meeting if the French, at Australia's invitation, were to turn up to that forum, just when the first bomb is going off.

In the light of the government's very weak and meek words prior to the French government announcement, is it any wonder that when we pick up the papers today we read that the French government has dismissed the protest and that the delegation led by Senator Evans is to be snubbed as outrage grows. The French government knew exactly how to respond to the Australian government and any delegation after its announcement of its decision because Australia never set out clearly enough its possible course of action. The French were pre-warned of our reaction.

On the latest Sunday program there was a very interesting documentary about the health effects of years of nuclear testing in the vicinity of those South Pacific islands, particularly Tahiti. We heard tragic stories of child deformities and, while we cannot prove for certain a connection with the testing, there is a very convincing argument for doing so. If, over some 20 years, you are exploding bombs 10 to 20 times more powerful than the bomb dropped on Hiroshima, there are grounds for linking certain of the health problems suffered by the Tahitians and other islanders directly to the nuclear testing, regardless of the French scientists' propa ganda.

The Australian government's timing was out. The wording used by Senator Evans will probably go down as the most memorable, most infamous statement ever by a foreign minister—`It could be worse'. For all his experience, for all the time that he has been in this job, for all his boasting, for all the books he has ever written, not only did this minister mistime the protest but his words also failed him. He said, `It could be worse'. He has intellectualised himself into a most comfortable position.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe that this debate is far too important to allow it to degenerate into a point scoring political exercise. I really have to pick up the previous speaker, Senator McGauran, on the comments he made about a `meek' protest. I do not think anyone on either side of the chamber would accuse Senator Gareth Evans of being meek, if that is what Senator McGauran was suggesting.

PARA.TAB: Essentially, we are all agreed that there is no place for the resumption of French nuclear testing in the Pacific. I agree with many of the concerns that have been expressed in the chamber today. By and large, there has been some very positive debate. But while I agree with a number of the concerns that have been expressed by speakers in the debate on Senator Coulter's urgency motion, I cannot support that motion.

The motion suggests that the Australian government's actions are of no use in getting President Chirac to change his policy. It is quite inaccurate. Clearly, we must be united. I know that it is always tempting for those of us in this place to score political points. That is the name of the game and that is the role of those in opposition. However, something as significant as this subject—a subject that has seen unprecedented unity from the electorate—requires us to be a little more tolerant of each other's views and a little more aware of the difference between being in government and not being in government instead of trying to point score over what actions the government may or may not have taken.

Is it weak, for example, to lead a top level delegation of South Pacific nations to formally lodge a united protest from our region? I am sure Senator Coulter does not think that that is weak. Is it really inadequate to call for a boycott of French products, to freeze defence ties, and to refuse refuelling of aircraft facilities for those involved in the tests?

Yes, Senator Coulter, you would like to see us go further—and probably so would I. But it is inappropriate to use this as an occasion to pass a motion of this kind. The Australian government must continue to be pro-active in trying to get a reversal of this decision. In their arrogant way the French regard the Pacific as their own property—to do with as they will. As many people have said throughout the past few days, if this testing is so important why are the French not doing it on their own shores? Indeed, why are the French not taking up the American offer to use the facilities in Nevada?

It is appropriate to mention some of the many responses that have occurred over the last few days. I have three pages of them, but I am not going to attempt to cover them in my final few minutes. I want to single out a few. The Australian Medical Association has stated that increased incidence of thyroid cancer in Australia could be directly linked to French tests in the Pacific and has urged French doctors to lobby the Chirac government to reverse its decision to resume testing. That is very significant. The Australian Medical Association does not lightly take such action. Similarly, the Pacific Asia Travel Association has called for a protest.

I believe that there are other measures that the Australian government should be taking and I would like to mention them. We should be considering the recall of our ambassador. We should be considering calling an emergency meeting of the South Pacific Forum. We could refuse to enter into defence contracts with the French. We could refuse to allow French corporations to tender for government contracts. Most importantly, we certainly should be reviewing existing uranium contracts with France.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I want to answer Senator McMullan. In his assertion he said that the Australian Democrats can advocate anything because we never have to implement it. I think he indicated that that comment extends to the opposition. Let me point out that government has the power and the responsibility to implement. That is the very point we are making. The government is abrogating its responsibility. The government has the power; it should be acting; it has failed to act; and its response is inadequate to the resumption of these tests and for that it should be condemned.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs: Evaluation of Commonwealth Funded Programs.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Standing Committee's report examines some of the complex issues spanning the full range of the Commonwealth Government's involvement in social policy broadly defined. Due to the wide ranging scope of the inquiry the Committee identified a number of salient issues on which attention could be focused and targeted two key Commonwealth departments—the Departments of Social Security and Human Services and Health. The report provides a synoptic view of recent developments and reforms within these Departments in relation to these issues.
While the report does not make specific recommendations, it draws a number of conclusions about:
.consultation with the community;
.planning processes;
.service delivery models and the needs of the community; and
.development of a regional focus.
The report provides a useful summary of the progress of reforms in these Departments and identifies some issues that need further consideration.
The Government notes that the Committee's report complements the more focused and in-depth inquiries conducted into related issues by other parliamentary committees.

The Government regards effective community consultation as an essential step in ensuring that service delivery is more flexible and responsive to clients. Significant advances have been made in recent years in the adoption of a client-focused approach to the planning and delivery of services.
Recent developments include establishment of a national network of Older Australians Advisory Councils to provide advice on matters relating to the care and well being of older Australians.

These new Councils have replaced the Consumer Forums for the Aged which finished operation at the end of 1993. The role of the Advisory Councils is to consider the needs and concerns of older people and the effectiveness and relevance of Commonwealth government services or funding in meeting those needs. They will also examine the roles that older Australians play in family and community life, including their roles as carers and as active citizens.
The Councils will put the views of older people to the Minister, and will also report back to older Australians and their organisations on the deliberations and activities of the Councils.

Widespread community consultations have also recently been carried out to inform the Strategic Review of the Disability Services Program. The consultation process will lead to changes in the quality of outcomes for people with a disability. Information gathered from the consultations has fed into an interim report which recommends a package of structural reforms for the Disability Services Program focusing on providing choice and meeting individual needs.

The Ngaanyatjarra Pitjantjatjara Yankunytjatjara Women's Council Project, funded under the User Rights Initiatives Program, is an example where the expertise, experience and local knowledge of a community based organisation has been used to examine the aged care needs of a particular community.
The Women's Council has received a grant to undertake a project to identify and examine the needs and problems facing the aged in member communities and Homelands of the Pitjantjatjara Council.

The Council employs a research team to undertake the project. The project officer is an anthropologist who has worked for many years on the Pitjantjatjara Homelands and she is assisted by an Aboriginal worker/interpreter. The field work involves visiting all member communities of the Women's Council to hear from the older people what aged care services they need.

In the Human Services and Health Portfolio, the Aged and Community Care Program's strategy for improving the provision of aged care for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities was developed in co-operation with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, Australian Hearing Laboratories and other Government agencies. This followed consultations with Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations and communities across Australia.

The strategy stresses the importance of thorough needs assessment, including obtaining the views of potential clients and their families, and communities' involvement at all stages of service planning, development and delivery.
More generally, community consultations on a regional basis are becoming a more frequent part of ongoing program operations.

The Government recognises the utility of needs-based analysis and planning as a framework for identifying client needs, in particular, special needs and emerging forms of need, and how those needs vary from region to region and from client group to client group.

Since the mid-1980s, needs-based planning has been used as the basic framework for identifying client needs for community services programs. More sophisticated program-specific needs-based planning processes are now being developed.

The Government's Family and Children's Services Program uses a nationally consistent statistical data base on the supply of and demand for child care services, supplemented by additional information gained from State Planning Advisory Committees and local consultations, in its needs-based planning of child care.

The Disability Services Program is developing a data collection on ethnicity and culture to assist in the provision of appropriate services—the National Information Management System. The implementation of the System in funded services over the next twelve months will enable the Program to collect good quality statistical data, allowing it to undertake a more detailed analysis of the Program's clients and their needs. This will inform and assist in the development, implementation and monitoring of the Program's access and equity strategy.

The importance of collecting ethnicity data is also recognised by the Aged Care Program, which is currently developing new data collection methods. These will improve the level and quality of information, enhance planning and monitoring, and ultimately lead to better service provision.

Such program-specific needs-based planning processes are complemented by regional needs analyses. The development of regional needs analyses provides a mechanism for building a regional perspective into program-planning processes.

Integral to the success of this process is improved community consultation and a more widespread regional presence. Instead of looking at needs and priorities for individual programs in isolation, needs and priorities across a whole range of responsibilities are examined across regions. In the Human Services and Health Portfolio, the regions are supported by a growing network of regional offices which builds on earlier regionalisation experiments in Queensland and the Northern Territory.

Regional Needs Analyses will help ensure programs are able to equitably meet the needs of all members of the community including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples, women, people in rural and remote areas, people from a non-English speaking background, and those with a disability.

The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Recruitment Strategy in the Human Services and Health Portfolio is particularly complementary to the development of service models which are more responsive to the needs of these communities. The Strategy was developed by indigenous staff in 1991 and has provided a range of opportunities that have enabled indigenous people to access employment within the Department. It is envisaged that as more indigenous people gain access to the Department, they will increase their input to the delivery of the Department's programs to ensure cultural appropriateness and equitable access for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

Recommendations coming from the Strategic Review of the Disability Services Program will also see a focus on providing consumer choice and meeting individual needs, and the achievement of outcomes as the primary measure of service delivery performance. These will result from the introduction of portable, individualised, funding for consumers, a greater range of support services, better wages and employment conditions, and a greater emphasis on the provision of quality services.

A further example is the National Child Care Strategy on cost-sharing arrangements with State and Territory Governments. Under this arrangement, some child care places are being delivered through innovative arrangements which best meet the needs of families in rural and remote areas. Extensive consultation has been undertaken in developing appropriate service-delivery models. A further initiative in the 1995-96 Budget to develop innovative community managed places in remote communities provides increased flexibility of funding arrangements.

Other current initiatives to address barriers to more responsive service delivery include revision of legislation administered, to reduce its complexity and make it more accessible to service providers.

For example, the Law Reform Commission is reviewing the Department of Human Services and Health's program legislation and has issued two discussion papers on Aged Care and Child Care and one report on Child Care. The first of the new legislation is expected this year on Aged Care.

Ways of overcoming administrative and legal barriers to more flexible funding arrangements are also being examined, particularly for small or isolated communities. This will enable the range of services provided to be more responsive to community needs.
A review of administrative arrangements, particularly in relation to contracting of services, is underway to ensure value for money whilst maintaining accountability and service quality.
Home and Community Care Program
The Government is keen to ensure that guidelines for programs are sufficiently flexible to enable service providers to deliver services in a flexible manner.
The report is critical of the Home and Community Care Program's inflexible guidelines, which are considered to hamper service provision by local community-based organisations.

These issues are being addressed through the current Efficiency and Effectiveness Review of the Home and Community Care Program. The Review is addressing the need to increase the flexibility of the Program in responding to community needs, while improving accountability between levels of government.

However, the Home and Community Care Program is further complicated by the nature of the relationship between the Commonwealth and State/Territory Governments, as joint partners in the Program. Any change in the Program's administrative structure, consultation process and service-delivery practices must first be negotiated with, and agreed to, by the States and Territories. This is often a difficult and time-consuming task, made more complex by the very real differences that exist between States/Territories in terms of their consumer and service provision profiles.
Different approaches to regionalisation have been adopted by the Departments of Social Security and Human Services and Health.

The extensive decentralisation/regionalisation of Department of Social Security offices has gone hand in hand with a devolution of responsibilities to regional office managers, to allow them to allocate resources and prioritise operations according to local needs.
In 1992, the Department of Human Services and Health commenced a service planning and delivery strategy with the aim of improving access to, and the responsiveness of, its programs.

As part of the regional focus strategy, a number of regional offices were established throughout Australia. The regional office network now comprises 18 offices, the majority of which are located in rural and remote areas.

A major evaluation of the regional focus strategy was completed in February 1994. The evaluation found that a regional presence by the Department made a significant and positive difference in the areas of planning, service development and service support.

An examination of the Department of Human Services and Health's office structures is currently in progress with a view to further consolidating its regional presence to ensure equitable geographic access to funded services, clients, service providers and administrators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the second report of the Senate Select Committee on Matters Arising from Pay Television Tendering Processes. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Government's response to the report of the Senate Select Committee on matters arising from the Pay TV tendering processes [Second report—Terms of Reference Part (1)(b)].

In its second report, tabled in Parliament on 16 December 1993, the Committee has reached a number of conclusions, and has made three specific recommendations. The conclusions recognise the action that had been taken reforms which had been introduced by the former Department of Transport and Communications to address the issues rectify the problems identified in the Pearce Reports. Subsequent to the administrative changes which involved the separation of the former Department, progress in implementing the changes has continued in the Department of Communications and the Arts, and in the Department of Transport. The Committee's recommendations form the basis for building on the improvements to date.
The Government accepts the conclusions drawn by the Committee in its second report, the main thrust of which were to the effect:

.Specific problems were identified in respect of the Satellite Pay TV and MDS tendering processes, as a result of certain shortcomings in some of the (former) Department's operations and procedures at that time

.An integral part of the responsibility and accountability issues considered in the Committee's first report was the need to take action to rectify these problems, and to ensure that systems were enhanced in order to prevent their recurrence. The remedial and preventative measures the former Department has taken have sought to address all aspects of its management, and these actions do address the problems identified. The Committee believes that in these terms, the Minister has properly discharged his responsibilities through the action he and the Department have taken to rectify the problems.
.Valuable lessons have been learnt from these events, and the Committee recognised the potential for the service-wide application of the remedial material developed.

.The effectiveness of the action which has been taken must, ultimately, be judged over a period of time, and in this respect, the Committee notes the importance of the evaluation and review mechanisms which have been put in place. In developing the longer-term gains envisaged, the Committee made three recommendations for building on the improvements to date.
The three recommendations are accepted, and further to the Government's statements in the Parliament, actions taken to date to address the recommendations are as follows:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Department continue legal awareness training for its staff through the conduct of seminars and workshops on a regular basis. Provision should be made for more intensive legal training for staff at the ASO 4 and above levels and particularly for the Senior and SES officer levels.

SPEECH.PARA: Training programs to this effect are now an established element of the routine training calendar of both Departments (Communications & the Arts and Transport).

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Department expedite the finalisation of the Guidelines for Price-based Allocation Processes and revise these if necessary when the satellite and MDS tendering processes are finalised.

SPEECH.PARA: The draft guidelines, provided to the Committee and published in its second report, remain appropriate, with no need for further amendment, following finalisation of the tendering processes for Satellite Pay TV licences and MDS transmitter licences in metropolitan areas.

PARA.EMPHASIS: That the Management Advisory Board and the Public Service Commission be made aware of the Guidelines and seminar programs developed to meet the problems identified by Professor Pearce. These bodies should consider the application of this material for service-wide use.

SPEECH.PARA: The Management Advisory Board (MAB) has considered the four sets of Guidelines. They are as follows:
.Guidelines for price-based allocation processes;
.Guidelines to staff on obtaining legal services;
.Guidelines on documenting the business of the Department on files; and
.Guidelines on the preparation of advice to Ministers.
The Chairman of MAB forwarded copies of the Guidelines to all Portfolio Secretaries in July 1994, suggesting that they adapt the contents to their specific needs.
The Board also initiated two projects during 1993, aimed at raising the awareness of public servants about legal issues in their day-to-day working lives.
The first project, Consideration of Legal Issues in Policy Development and Administration, aims to assist public servants:
.To understand better the legal context within which they work;
.To identify legal issues relevant to their work as early as possible;
.To understand the potential implications of legal issues; and, most importantly
.To integrate the consideration of legal issues into policy development and program administration.
The second project, Delegated Authority, aims to assist public servants:
.To understand the relevant legal principles applying to the delegation of authority;
.By raising awareness about the design of administrative systems in the light of accountability consequences arising from different options for delegating authority; and
.By helping delegates to understand better various aspects of the exercise of their power
Both projects were completed by the end of September 1994, and the resultant reports were distributed to senior management and Departmental libraries across the APS in November 1994.

The legal awareness seminars developed by the Public Service Commission (PSC) for the former Department of Transport and Communications have since been made available for Service-wide use. Seminars have been conducted on thirty six occasions in thirteen Departments and agencies to date and further seminars are planned.

After the MAB paper Consideration of Legal Issues in Policy Development and Administration was released, the PSC and the Attorney-General's Department continued to promote the legal issues and awareness seminars to agencies.

SPEECH.PARA: The Department of Defence and the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, in cooperation with other agencies and industry, develop a comprehensive description of both defence industry and defence exports;
This description be used as the basis for data collection and collation activities by all relevant agencies;
