Agreed-in-principle. In spite of the fact that there is a general consensus on the broad aspects of the nature of Australian defence industry and the value and composition of Australia's defence exports, general agreement as to a definition for defence exports is a vexatious issue. Following earlier less fruitful attempts, the question was addressed and widely consulted in the Defence Policy and Industry Report of November 1992 (The Price Report). The Government will work to improve on some distortions identified in Chapter 2 of the Committee report. However, the effectiveness of any control regime depends in part on the ability of industry to manage and comply with its procedures. So setting too complex a series of procedures and definitions could be self-defeating. In fact, any extension of the current basis of data collection could well impede, by virtue of additional documentary requirements, industry's abilities to ensure timely delivery of exports to highly competitive international markets. Finally, it is recognised that the definition of what constitutes a defence export is evolving. Goods exported for military use are becoming increasingly, perhaps predominantly, commercially useful, often at the leading edge of technology. Goods used for defence purposes are increasingly `civilian' in nature, ie. not made to military specifications. On the question of control of defence services, see the response to Recommendation 12.
Both matters of national and regional security be of primary consideration when decisions regarding defence exports are taken.

Agreed. As indicated in the White Paper 1994, "Defending Australia", the Government accords a high priority to considering matters of national and regional security in the exports decision making process. It will continue to do so. In fact, these matters are clearly identified as criteria to be considered in the Australian Controls on the Export of Defence and Related Goods—Guidelines for Exporters. When weighing up the implications of defence exports, particular emphasis will be placed on assessing their potential impact on our planning for the Defence of Australia.

The Australian controls on the export of defence and related goods be reviewed every five years by the committees responsible for defence exports in consultation with representatives from defence industries and non-government organisations responsible for conflict resolution; and

Agreed-in-principle. The Government currently undertakes periodic reviews of Australian export controls in accordance with its international obligations under a number of multilateral control regimes. We are an active, well-reputed, member of the international export controls community. Defence and DFAT already provide opportunities for consultation with defence industry and non-government organisations respectively and endeavour to take account of the views received as far as practicable. In March 1994, the Department of Defence published new "Australian Controls on the Export of Defence and Related Goods—Guidelines for Exporters". These guidelines revised earlier policy published in March 1992 and June 1989.
The Auditor-General list:

PARA.TAB: (a)the operation of the guidelines,
(b)the defence export control process, and
(c)all defence export facilitation activities, for an early performance audit.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed. The Australian National Audit Office has agreed to audit the defence export guidelines, control processes and facilitation activities beginning in early 1995/96.
All applications for defence exports automatically be referred to the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade for consideration;
An appropriate computer link be established between the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and the Department of Defence's computer system that processes the export applications; and
The Government provide the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade with the additional resources necessary to achieve the linkage.

Not agreed. The Standing Inter-Departmental Committee on Defence Exports (SIDCDE), established in 1989, purposefully has a widely based cross representational make up, including DFAT. Individual members are expected to table their Departmental positions in the course of SIDCDE deliberations which are not expected to be of one accord given the disparate Departmental roles and responsibilities. DFAT has the opportunity to review the more sensitive export applications for defence goods and bring to bear their perspective in the course of SIDCDE deliberations. In addition, informal consultations occur between Defence and DFAT officials on a range of export control cases on a daily basis. The interdepartmental Committee on Defence Materiel Cooperation and Exports advises Ministers on the array of policy issues arising from proposals to export advanced technologies and services and to engage in collaborative ventures with regional countries. The Interdepartmental Committee on defence Materiel Cooperation and Exports is a valuable additional safety net, as its main objective is to develop an integrated approach for handling collaborative projects and `big ticket' and potentially sensitive exports.

The Government does not agree with the Committee's conclusion that DFAT will "benefit" from reviewing all export applications, nor does it see the value added in such proposed review. This would, on the contrary, institutionalise duplication of work across two Departments as the proposed computer link would not convey sufficient information with respect to individual applications to DFAT officials. For a meaningful review , transmittal of complete dossiers, as is done on Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Exports cases, would be required. Additional regulatory mechanisms would add complexity to the export control regime by increasing the number of bureaucratic checks on defence exports. Resource requirements will increase, as will the level of ambiguity for industry applicants.

The Department of Defence's Annual report: Export of defence and related goods be improved and expanded consistent with the definitional recommendations previously made and it include information such as details of the export, its value and its country of destination, the number of licences and permits approved and denied, and for the next annual report only, the time taken to process each defence export application. The Minister for Defence should table the Annual report in Parliament within six months of the conclusion of the period under scrutiny.

Agreed-in-part. Subject to improving the details of defence export reporting, the Government will investigate making the Annual report even more informative. This must be balanced against recipient nations' desires for confidentiality in their defence import activity. As an example of an improvement, details on the time it takes to process applications can be included. The Annual report will be tabled within six months.

The Minister for Industry, Science and Technology take immediate action to rectify the deficiencies in Australian Custom Service's performance in the defence exports control process as outlined by this Committee.

Position Reserved. In making this recommendation, the Sub-Committee acknowledged that, " to its credit, the ACS had recognised the problems in this area and had initiated a review of the whole export control process" . The review has now been completed and is currently being considered by Customs senior management.

While defence exports are obviously an important category of restricted goods, Customs would use the same strategies for controlling them as it would for any other type of restricted exports such as native fauna, illicit drugs, etc. These strategies include using risk management techniques which involve targeted physical examinations based on intelligence reports and post-shipment documentary checks to confirm the accuracy of data being supplied to Customs electronically.

The ACS is in a period of significant change following the Government's decisions in regard to the Conroy Review. Customs senior management is currently examining the report of the review of exports controls in the context of these changes. The concerns expressed by the Trade Sub-Committee will be taken into account in deciding what measures will be implemented to significantly improve the ACS's performance in this area.

The Government develop the policy on the controls on the export of defence services and that policy be included in an expanded version of the next issue of Australian controls on the export of defence and related goods.

Agreed-in-principle. The Commonwealth already controls the export of some defence services. For example, under the Crimes (Foreign Incursions and Recruitment) Act 1978. The Weapons of Mass Destruction Bill, recently presented in Parliament, proposes to cover services provided for WMD programs of concern. Overseas practices, including those agreed to in multilateral fora, will be researched with a view to implementing complementary controls over select defence services when appropriate. The definitional question about what constitutes a defence service, as well as the concern about extraterritorial application of Australian law, remain issues the Commonwealth will consider in its on-going deliberations on defence exports.

The Department of Defence make public its Implementation Program on the Defence Policy and Industry Report and the six monthly progress reports on implementation and the Department direct its resources to make the Defence Export Program fully operational;

Not agreed. The 1994 White Paper, "Defending Australia", is now the key document describing the Government's defence industry policy, one aspect of which is defence export facilitation. The White Paper outlines the Government's current and future policy intentions with respect to defence exports. Future reports on the Defence Policy and Industry Report will not be made.

The Department of Defence give a priority to endorsing appropriate Australian defence products and services particularly those developed and used by the Department of Defence and the Australian Defence Force;

Agreed. The practice of endorsing products is generally consistent with Commonwealth procurement policy including the reforms announced in "Working Nation", the White Paper on employment and economic growth. In this paper, the Government stated it intends to use its purchasing power as a means of promoting Australian industry development and the endorsed supplier approach is one element of this policy.
The integration of defence exports and procurement activities in Defence be completed within six months of the tabling of this report;

Agreed-in-principle. In the context of the procurement process, defence exports are tied to a broader range of industry issues. Defence is working on an on-going basis to improve its processes in this area. However, because of the complexity of many of Defence's procurement activities, especially in relation to major acquisitions, it would be impossible to identify a clear point at which it could be said that Defence's export and procurement activities were integrated. Assessment of export considerations in the procurement process will continue to be made on a case-by-case basis in the context of consideration of broader industry issues as well as national and regional security issues.

The Department of Defence consult with Austrade and DIST to establish what additional export facilitation services and activities it might need to develop to assist small and medium sized defence export businesses and then implement those facilities; and

Agreed. In light of the recent Burgess Review of business programs and the establishment of Aus Industry, the Government believes it is appropriate to improve its interdepartmental coordination of export and enterprise improvement programs for SMEs in the defence industry sector. Defence, DIST and Austrade will work together to improve the coordination and delivery of existing programs to smaller sized defence firms before any decisions are made on additional programs.
Any charging for services under the Defence Export Program remain on a cost recovery basis.

Agreed-in-part. Cost recovery is a complex issue. Many factors, such as strategic value, and the ability of the stakeholder to pay, need to be considered. In Defence services , which are in a broad sense, supportive of exports, are delivered by a wide number of players across the entire Departmental and ADF spectrum not just by the area called the Defence Export Program. Defence, in delivering services to industry, will seek to have industry and Defence share the costs according to the benefits accruing to each party. Increased support capabilities for the ADF, capital savings, reduced maintenance costs and production economies of scale are a few examples of benefits which Defence takes into account. Neither Austrade nor Defence operate on a cost recovery basis where other factors mitigate against so doing.
The Department of Defence, in consultation with other agencies and industry, establish an appropriate mechanism for coordinating industry input to the defence export facilitation process; and
Agreed.
Commonwealth and State agencies maintain close contact on defence facilitation activities and if necessary meet once a year to address more formally areas of overlap and coordination.
Agreed.

The Department of Defence, in association with other agencies and industry, identify performance information and standards needed to assess the success or otherwise of the defence export facilitation activities and implement systems immediately to collect the necessary data for future evaluation of the system.

Agreed-in-principle. Defence will implement a performance evaluation system for export facilitation activities on a consultative basis with other agencies, State governments and industry etc. Defence exports and materiel cooperation are part of our strategic interests and enhance our defence relationships. In this respect performance often has to be measured qualitatively rather than quantitatively. It is anticipated there will be some difficulty in always quantifying the performance information for assessment purposes.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Government's Response to the Additional Report by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.PARA: 3.7It would be appropriate at this time to extend the definition of "defence exports" to include the full range of exports useful in aggression and repression. This is the case regardless of whether the end-user or goods-exported approach is adopted. End users should include all disciplined services, while goods classified should be extended to deal with other goods used outside a strict military/lethal context. This should include support for moves to similarly extend the UN Arms Register to include conventional small arms, non-lethal weapons, and the tools of repression.

3.8It is recommended that a Joint Parliamentary Select Committee be set up to define exactly what areas should be included under customs regulations for examination as defence and related exports. The definition should be clear enough to cover the range of goods requiring regulations, while broad enough to include categories of related goods without specifying every item.
7.8While supporting the recommendations at paragraph 2.17 of the majority report, it seems clear to me that guidelines cannot be written until the definitions are sorted out.

PARA.TAB: It is recommended that the regulations and guidelines governing defence exports be comprehensively redrafted in the light of the definitional review recommended at para 2.17 of the majority report.

SPEECH.PARA: Agreed-in-part. See response to Recommendations 1, 2 & 3 of the Majority Report. The November 1994 guidelines for exporters called the "Australia's Controls on the Export of Technology with civil and military applications" include a new category of controls listing some products of potentially repressive use. On the issue of possible expansion of items listed on the voluntary UN Arms Register, it should be noted that signatories have failed to concur on further extended coverage. The Government notes the concerns of some Australian interest groups that current export controls are not considered as stringent as they would like. Definitional problems are vexatious and it is unlikely that all societal interests will be satisfied with efforts to classify goods for export control purposes. The Commonwealth does not believe a Joint Parliamentary Select Committee is the appropriate mechanism or has the relevant practical expertise to deal with definitions of defence exports. As indicated in earlier replies to the Majority recommendations, the Commonwealth aims to improve the transparency of the defence export control system but does not intend to substantially overhaul the current approach. The Government is committed to reviewing practices of statistical reporting on controlled goods to more accurately reflect export levels. Improvements will be made before and after the audit by the Australian National Audit Office, where indicated. Officials are investigating what other information currently available from existing export control permits may be made available in summary format.
It is recommended that:
i.DoD should remain the only point of contact for those seeking export approvals: applications should be submitted to DoD and responses to applicants provided by DoD;

ii.DoD should be required to provide information on each application to DFAT and indeed, the Customs Service. DFAT should be able to flag any item it wishes for consideration by SIDCDE. Both DoD and DFAT should hold independent veto power on any item.

iii.The present Guidelines set out eight criteria [(a)—(h)] for export applications of military goods (Schedule 13, categories 1 and 2). Responsibility for these criteria should be divided between DoD and DFAT, such that DoD has responsibility for criteria (a), (c), (d), (g) and (h) and DFAT for (b), (e) and (f). Similarly, for non-military lethal goods, there are six criteria [(a)—(f)] given. DoD should have responsibility for criteria (a) and (f), and DFAT for (b), (c), (d) and (e). In all cases an application would succeed if the appropriate criteria were assessed positively by the relevant Department, so that all criteria were satisfied. Defence would then convey the outcome to the applicant.
4.21.i Agreed.

4.21.ii & iii. Not agreed. The Government does not agree, on the contrary, consideration of any specific criteria should not dominate the export application approval process. We emphasise that the Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Exports provides a forum for consultation and DFAT input on policy and process developments for defence export applications. Reviewing every application in two separate departments has no added benefits and could unreasonably delay exports to competitive markets, to the point that the regulatory process renders exports commercially not viable. In circumstances where sensitive exports are under consideration Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Exports provides a mechanism of checks and balances and, also, establishes a forum where a broad range of Australian interests are weighed against specific export proposals. All member Departments participate actively in the process and DFAT expertise in relevant areas is recognised as a matter of long-standing practice.

The list of nations classified as sensitive in accordance with the guidelines should be published, a proposal also forming a part of coalition policy. The area(s) of guideline contravention should also be published. A system of public input should be developed and the decision-making process should be transparent, particularly in relation to human rights issues and regional security The list should be reviewed annually. Nations should also be able to be reclassified rapidly in the event of dramatic changes, either being included in the event of gross abuses or being normalised in the event of rapid positive political change. While the regulations do not block all exports, when a nation is classified, the onus of proof should be reversed, with exporters arguing why exports will not aggravate the situation.

Not agreed. Currently the Sensitive Destinations List is reviewed biannually and is not published so as not to harm wider diplomatic, economic and/or strategic relationships. There are provisions for rapid change to the current list in response to positive or negative developments internationally. It is not practical to allow formal public input into these confidential procedures. But this does not mean public opinion is ignored. Currently established procedures are thorough and sensitive to wider Australian interests.

It appears that part of the problem is that ultimate discretion rests with the Minister of Defence, while most of the problems occur where exports are contrary to the objectives of diplomacy, international harmony and the assurance of human rights, all objectives falling into the Foreign Affairs area. We therefore believe that authority and responsibility be shared between DoD and DFAT, with the former remaining the "shopfront" organisation and each holding independent veto power over any application. DFAT should receive sufficient resources to allow adequate performance of its duties.

Not agreed. Shared responsibility for controls on certain sensitive defence exports is already in place in Australia. Defence is the point of contact for export control applications although sensitive applications are considered by the SIDCDE. See response to Recommendation 5.17 (below).

The regulation of services and of components is an area requiring close examination and a clear set of guidelines. This should be accomplished as a matter of urgency. Services should be defined and regulation proposed. Of particular concern is the regulation of services relating to defence-related computer software. Means should be developed of assuring that components do not end up as weapons in the wrong hands. No area of defence exports, including transfers to associated companies, defence cooperation, or defence aide should be immune from the regulatory regime, including end-user certificates.

Agreed-in-principle. See Recommendation 12 of the Majority Report. The question of regulating services is an important and complex new endeavour for the Commonwealth in the context of both defence and other industry sectors. As guidelines for the control of services are developed they will be promulgated. While components are covered by the existing export controls, the Commonwealth recognises that in the international arms market place, there is a growing shift towards technology transfer and transfer of components rather than shipment of complete weapons systems. This trend may be expected to increase as production continues to globalize and companies operate in joint venture, teaming and other partnerships to compete in the decreasing market place. The trade in components, especially those produced for civilian applications , but useable in military systems, is a growing area which will be addressed.

The implementation part of the process of regulation is the weakest area. We recommend that action should be taken to implement all the existing guidelines, especially those designed to guarantee human and civil rights, and those designed to minimise conflicts (internal and external) and to avoid aggravating international tensions, and that progress towards these goals be reported to the Parliament within six months. Extension of the guidelines to strengthen these considerations should also be investigated, and recommendations included with the progress report.

Not agreed. The premise of the Recommendation is that the Government has failed to implement its current guidelines and regulations . The existing process does adhere to existing guidelines and regulations, and therefore the Government does not accept this premise.
It is recommended that:
i.Customs set up a system of cooperation with the Customs agencies of other nations, and international police networks, to monitor defence trade;

ii.military intelligence work closely with the UN arms register and other intelligence organisations, customs and police organisations to assure that there is a truly international and open system for monitoring all aspects of defence trade from manufacture to disposal or use.

4.38.i. Not agreed. Customs already has intelligence links with many other Customs agencies and with international police networks. The principal purpose of these links is to exchange information to assist in detecting breaches of Customs legislation. While Customs is confident that it would receive cooperation from other agencies in detecting breaches of legislation relating to defence exports where the other country maintains similar legislation, it doubts that it would receive assistance from countries which do not. Customs has greater doubts that it would receive any cooperation in monitoring legitimate trade in defence goods, even from countries with similar export controls, as there would be no legitimate reason to request information in these circumstances.

4.38.ii. Not agreed. Australia's intelligence cooperation with other countries is a complex and sensitive matter. The Australian intelligence community works closely with intelligence organisations and government agencies of friendly countries in monitoring arms transfers of potential significance to Australia, but the sensitivity of intelligence sources means that much of this information cannot be made public. However, it should be noted that very comprehensive information on arms transfers is available from public sources, in particular the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute, the International Institute for Strategic Studies, and Jane's Information Group. The UN Register of Conventional Arms is a database maintained by the UN Office for Disarmament Affairs in New York. It is based solely on information voluntarily provided by states on their own defence imports and exports. The UN does not seek the cooperation of national intelligence agencies to monitor the arms trade, and indeed such cooperation might be seen to compromise the neutrality of the Register and thereby reduce its effectiveness as a confidence-building measure.
SIDCDE and IDCDMCE have so far failed to guarantee the international, political, and human rights implications will be considered, and adequately incorporated into decisions under the guidelines.
We recommend that:

i.In the current situation, the only way to achieve these objectives will be through the formation of a Joint Parliamentary Select Committee whose primary brief is to guarantee consideration of these issues. It may also be appropriate to include advice from human rights NGOs or some similar community representation to such a committee.
ii.All applications should be notified to DFAT, which should itself determine which ones it will further consider through SIDCDE.

Not agreed. The Government does not accept the premise of this Recommendation that the defence export committee system fails to guarantee that international, political and human rights are considered and adequately incorporated into decisions. The wide range of Departments involved in the process ensures that all aspects are comprehensively considered, both in informal discussions and within the committees. The operation of the defence export decision making process will be monitored, and improved whenever possible, but the Government does not agree to the proposal for the establishment of a Joint Parliamentary Select Committee as proposed in this Recommendation. In relation to the notification of applications to DFAT, please refer to the response in relation to Recommendation 4.21.ii and Recommendations 7, 8 & 9 of the Majority Report.

It is now past time to assess those policies of non-market support for domestic defence enterprises, and we recommend that the policy of "defence self sufficiency" be included as one of the aspects of defence exports listed with the Auditor General for assessment. Part of the consideration should explicitly be an analysis of the cost of support for different sectors of the defence industry, and of their separate security implications.

Not agreed. Government support for selected indigenous defence industry capabilities is a key element of Australia's defence policy. Export activity, over time, may reduce the need for Government support for such industry, however, the requirement for these specific indigenous capabilities is quite discrete from any export consideration. There is no Government policy espousing defence `self-sufficiency'. The policy of defence self-reliance relates to the security of the nation and therefore involves wider interests than just economic considerations.

A collateral conclusion is that the Government's active involvement, both as owner of defence enterprises, and as a facilitate of exports, appears to run counter to its regulatory role, and leads to a situation where the Government is producer, salesman, government export program provider, involved in Government-to-Government and military-to-military diplomacy, and is regulator. The Minister for Defence, as was noted, has ultimate discretion on regulation, and is also responsible to actively promote export, particularly from companies where Government is commercially involved. There are a number of contradictory elements here, both ethically and commercially. It appears necessary to clearly separate the various functions of Government, and set up a situation where the Minister is directly involved only as a last resort, and not as a proactive agent.

Not agreed. The Government has actively sought to dispose of Defence-owned enterprises since the mid-80s and continues to divest itself of those enterprises where appropriate. As well, the Government expects Australian firms to take the lead in marketing and exporting defence products. The Government supports and encourages the export of defence products from Australia only within carefully enforced guidelines which are consistent with our national interests and objectives. Companies will base their commercial activities in the defence sector on commercial viability. They would cease to do business in the sector if it were no longer profitable. There is no conflict of interest for the Minister. Only through Australia's commitment to the highest standards of export controls and regulation are we seen as a reliable and trustworthy recipient of foreign defence technology and weapon systems. It makes sense, therefore, for responsibility for defence materiel cooperation (whether acquisition, R&D, technology transfer or exports) to be consolidated in one Department under the Minister for Defence.

In this situation the only sensible path appears to be the wind-down of expenditures designed to develop export capability. Such money is unlikely to see a return for a very long period if at all, and both economics and real security would suggest that it would be better spent assisting non-defence-related development with our neighbours and domestically.
Not agreed.

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters entitled The Conduct of Elections: New Boundaries for Cooperation. I seek leave to incorporate the document into Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: THE GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS ENTITLED "THE CONDUCT OF ELECTIONS: NEW BOUNDARIES FOR COOPERATION"

On 10 September 1992 the then Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, Mr A Bevis MP, tabled the Committee's Report on resource sharing between the Commonwealth and State electoral authorities.

The Committee, in acknowledging the substantial infrastructure costs associated with the dispersed nature of the divisional network, considers that regionalisation/collocation in metropolitan and major provincial centres should proceed and recommends accordingly.

Not supported. The Government considers that there should be no change from the existing office network without first establishing that electoral services for the community and the Parliament can be fully maintained under an alternate structure. Accordingly, the Minister for Administrative Services will further consider options for the AEC structure and in particular a trial of an alternative in a suitable location.

The Committee further recommends that decisions relating to the number of divisions to be regionalised/collocated should not be limited to three as contemplated by the 1990 AEC study, but be considered in the light of costs, and of benefits and convenience to electors.
Not applicable—see response to Recommendation 1.

In implementing regionalisation/collocation proposals, the Committee recommends that the AEC determine, in consultation with the Australian Public Sector and Broadcasting Union, the most appropriate staffing structure for regional collocated offices, based on operational requirements and workload in each separate office.
Not applicable—see response to Recommendation 1.

The Committee recommends that the AEC in its consideration of regionalisation options also consider the extent to which head office costs can be reduced through the devolution of responsibility to regional personnel.
Not applicable—see response to Recommendation 1.
The Committee recommends that the Government review, with the Australian Public Sector and Broadcasting Union, the appropriateness of maintaining separate election allowances for AEC staff.
Supported. The functional allowances, including AEC election allowances, will be reviewed in the context of the full review of the organisation and resources of the AEC.
The Committee recommends that the AEC review its current procedures for overtime and casual employment, particularly in periods of high demand such as election times.

Supported. After each electoral event, the AEC investigates overtime and casual employment expenditure in each Divisional office, including variations between Divisions. This information is used to assess and review the relationship between workload and required staffing resources.
The Committee recommends that the AEC approach the State/Territory Commissions with a view to making pre-poll and postal voting for all State/Territory elections available at all AEC offices.

Supported. Some States already ask the AEC to provide a limited service for some elections. Full implementation of this proposal would result in greatly improved voting facilities for the public at State elections. Financial arrangements would be a matter for negotiation between the AEC and the State/Territory Commissions.
The Committee further recommends that pre-poll and postal voting for Commonwealth elections be available at State/Territory Electoral Commission offices.

Supported. Similar considerations apply to those outlined in recommendation 7 above. It should be noted, however, that State capacity to reciprocate is limited to one office in each State/Territory. For the 1993 federal elections pre-poll votes were issued from the Victorian State Electoral Office. The AEC paid for two casual staff to be employed in that office to help with enquiries and the issue of pre-poll votes. As the AEC office in the Northern Territory is in the same building as its Territory counterpart, and the AEC has offices in Adelaide, Perth and Hobart very close to the respective State Commissions' offices, pre-poll votes were not issued from those offices.
The Committee recommends that the Commonwealth and State/Territory Commissions take steps to standardise procedures and forms for pre-poll and postal voting.
Supported. However, it is noted that standardisation with each State/Territory may be difficult to achieve given the need for national uniformity within the AEC.

The Committee recommends that, at future Commonwealth and State/Territory electoral events, the Commissions devote resources to make electors aware of the enhanced facilities for pre-poll and postal voting.
Supported. The costs of advertising should be carried by the Commonwealth for Commonwealth elections and the States/Territory for their elections.

The Committee recommends that the AEC approach the State/Territory Commissions with a view to AEC staff being authorised and trained to respond to queries from the public about State/Territory elections. The Committee does not consider that payments from the State/Territory Commissions to the AEC should be necessary for this service.

Supported. AEC staff already provide extensive information to the public about State/Territory elections. At the last State election in Victoria AEC Divisional offices received about 70,000 phone calls and counter enquiries and AEC head office received about 20,000 phone calls and counter enquiries. In the last State election in Western Australia, Divisional offices handled about 15,700 telephone and counter enquiries and the AEC head office handled about 13,600. The bulk of such enquiries is of a routine nature for which formal training would not be required. Complex enquiries would need to be referred to the State/Territory. As to payment for this service the workload in some cases would be such that additional staff would be required to handle the number of enquiries. If this is the case, the State/Territory Commission concerned should bear the cost.

The Committee recommends that similar arrangements be made so that State/Territory Electoral Commissions can respond to queries from the public about Commonwealth elections. The Committee does not consider that payments from the AEC to the State/Territory Commissions should be necessary for this service.

Supported. If, as is already the case in some States, State Commissions are prepared to participate, the AEC will provide information relevant to common, routine questions. It should be noted, however, that State capacity to reciprocate is limited to one office in each State/Territory. If additional staff are required, the AEC should bear the cost.
The Committee recommends that the AEC and the State/Territory Commissions standardise polling place locations wherever possible, in order to avoid public confusion.

Supported. In most cases the same polling places are already used. With the occasional exception resulting from differing Commonwealth and State electoral boundaries, the Government and the AEC consider that further standardisation should be possible.
The Committee recommends that the AEC and the State/Territory Commissions set up a working party to investigate the practicability of standardising polling place procedure and layout.
Supported.
The Committee recommends that electronic scanning be used as widely as possible and the AEC and the State/Territory Commissions negotiate a standard rate of reimbursement for the use of the system.

Supported. The AEC system of electronic scanning of electoral rolls has already been successfully used by all State and Territory Commissions. The AEC is willing to discuss its standard rates and charges with users, and in fact the Australian Joint Roll Council has commenced discussions on the issue.
The Committee recommends that the AEC and the State/Territory Commissions investigate the practicability and advantages of exchanging information about non-voters.

An investigation is supported. However, the AEC would only implement such a system if there were significant benefits to be obtained and if the Privacy Commissioner was satisfied that the information exchange meets the requirements of the Privacy Act.
The Committee recommends that the AEC approach the State/Territory Commissions with a view to introducing joint panels for conducting audits of State/Territory and Commonwealth elections.
Supported. Since 1984 the AEC has developed comprehensive programs for the auditing of Commonwealth elections. The AEC is happy to share its experience and procedures with the States.
The Committee recommends that programs of electoral education conducted by the AEC or the State/Territory Commissions include material on all three levels of government.

Supported. The Government and the AEC consider that wherever possible programs of electoral education in particular States should be jointly organised and jointly funded. A financial contribution from local government may also be possible but the Government considers that joint organisation and funding with the States/Territory should be the first objective.
The Committee recommends that the AEC and the State/Territory Commissions investigate the possibility of establishing jointly funded electoral education centres in each State/Territory capital city.

Supported. The AEC funds wholly the centres in Canberra and Melbourne, and contributes to the centre in Perth. Jointly funded centres in other capital cities would be feasible provided that the State/Territory governments were prepared to provide funding and the AEC was given supplementary funds. As an example of the costs involved, the Melbourne Electoral Education Centre's budget for the 1992/93 financial year, including salaries, was $127,000.
The Committee recommends that the AEC and the State/Territory Commissions investigate the desirability of joint research projects.
Supported.

The Committee recommends that the AEC approach the State/Territory Commissions with a view to developing a program of staff interchanges between the AEC and State/Territory Electoral Commissions for periods of say, six months to one year.
Supported.

The Committee recommends that the AEC propose to the State/Territory Commissions that at the time of a State/Territory election, AEC staff might be seconded to the State/Territory Electoral Commission concerned and that at the time of a Commonwealth election, State/Territory staff might be seconded to the AEC.
Supported. For the 1993 federal election, State/Territory staff were seconded to the AEC in Melbourne and Darwin.
The Committee recommends that in addition to exchanges with AEC State/Territory head offices, secondments of State/Territory staff to the AEC's central office also be considered at election time.
Supported.
The Committee recommends that secondees be given duties commensurate with their qualifications and experience and be exposed to appropriate new areas of work.
Supported.
The Committee recommends that the AEC guarantee to provide an agreed number of staff to act as State Returning Officers.

Not supported. Such a guarantee cannot be given in view of the difficulties which would arise if Commonwealth and State elections were held in close proximity. The AEC's first responsibility is for Commonwealth elections and ongoing Commonwealth electoral administration. Thus, while a guarantee as such cannot be given, the Commission is happy to discuss with State electoral administrations making AEC staff available to provide assistance with State election timetables where AEC work commitments make this possible.
The Committee recommends that where the AEC's offices are made available for use by State Returning officers the States/Territory reimburse the AEC accordingly.
Supported.
The Committee recommends that the AEC approach the State/Territory Commissions with a view to establishing joint storage facilities in each State/Territory.
Supported, subject to cost effectiveness. Questions of cost sharing would need to be explored.
The Committee recommends that staff of both the AEC and State/Territory Commissions be encouraged to work as polling staff at elections for the other level of government.
Supported. This already occurs in most States/Territories, and occurred again in the recent Victorian, Western Australian and federal elections.

The Committee recommends that the AEC approach the State/Territory Commissions with a view to developing a program of local exchanges of staff for scrutinies where proportional representation is involved.

Supported. Exchanges have already occurred in a number of States and the Northern Territory, including at the time of the 1993 federal election. Such exchanges assist in ensuring that a high level of expertise in such scrutinies is maintained.
The Committee recommends that the practice of exchanging information about suitable polling officials be adopted between the Commonwealth and State/Territory Commissions.
Supported, subject to privacy considerations.
Where the performance of polling staff is satisfactory, the Committee recommends that the same staff be used for Commonwealth and State/Territory elections wherever possible.
Supported, subject to privacy considerations. The same staff are already widely used.

The Committee recommends that the AEC invite staff of the State/Territory Commissions to attend training sessions for divisional staff and polling officials and that the State/Territory Commissions make a similar approach to the AEC.
Supported. State electoral staff attended AEC polling official training in a number of States and the Northern Territory for the 1993 federal elections.

The Committee recommends that the AEC and the State/Territory Commissions set up a working party to investigate the practicability of using the one computerised system for the payment of polling officials.
Supported.
The Committee recommends that negotiations to conclude the current round of joint roll agreements should proceed without delay.

Supported. The negotiations were deferred by a number of States pending the outcome of this inquiry by the Joint Standing Committee. With regard to the Privacy Commissioner's concerns about notification of disclosures by States, the AEC is not in a position under the joint roll arrangements to control State use of Roll data, although they will press through negotiations for State acceptance of Information Privacy Principles contained in the federal Privacy Act.
The Committee recommends that negotiations occur between the Commonwealth and the State/Territories to determine an agreed formula for calculating direct costs of roll maintenance.
Supported. The Commonwealth has previously asked the States to pay half the "direct costs" of roll maintenance. Costs such as the salaries and accommodation of Divisional staff are not included.

The Committee recommends that the AEC approach the State Commissions in Victoria, Western Australia and Tasmania with a view to having the AEC align electors to wards and/or ridings or appropriate local government subdivisions.

Supported. The AEC already aligns electors to wards and ridings in New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia and the Northern Territory. The possibility of the AEC performing the same task in Tasmania is currently under investigation. AEC staff could undertake the work in Victoria and Western Australia at little or not extra cost.

The Committee recommends that the use of CCD boundaries should be considered as an aid in the redistribution process, but notes that the requirement of relevant Acts demand that other criteria will be the determining factors.
Supported.
The Committee's recommendation reflects the current situation.
The Committee recommends that, subject to satisfactory arrangements regarding timing and funding, the AEC run the programs for the removal of duplications before all State/Territory electoral events.

Supported. The AEC has already decided in principle to implement this proposal and will raise it with the Australian Joint Roll Council (AJRC)(see Recommendation 43). A certain amount of removal of duplications already takes place. Where a State election is announced suddenly and unexpectedly, there may not be time for further removal of duplications.

With regard to the errors brought to the attention of the inquiry, the Committee recommends that the AEC conduct a thorough review of its procedures giving particular attention to quality controls for the output of RMANS.

Supported. The Government notes that the Committee found that the electoral rolls were generally of a high standard. With respect to the errors referred to by the Committee, the AEC has already implemented a number of changes including the establishment of a client services unit within the Central Office enrolment section, and is appointing account managers for particular States. The AEC is currently conducting a review of its procedures to determine whether any further changes are needed.
The Committee recommends that the AEC approach the State/Territory Commissions with a view to setting up a joint management committee in each State/Territory.

Supported. This recommendation accords with approaches which the AEC has been making to the States for some time in relation to the electoral rolls. A joint management committee currently exists in Queensland and there are comparable meetings in the other States.
The Committee recommends that the terms of reference of the joint management committees include roll maintenance, resource sharing and the conduct of elections for the State/Territory concerned.
Supported. There is a strong case for not confining consultative arrangements to joint roll matters.

The Committee recommends that the joint management committees consist of the Electoral Commissioner and the Deputy Electoral Commissioner or their respective nominees, and the Australian Electoral Officer and the Deputy Australian Electoral Officer or their respective nominees for the State/Territory concerned.
Supported. However, to accommodate local needs, the membership of the committees should be individually negotiated.
The Committee recommends that the AEC approach the State/Territory Commissions with a view to establishing an Australian Joint Roll Council (AJRC).
Supported. The consultative Australian Joint Roll Council was established on 5 February 1993, and usually meets quarterly.

The Committee recommends that the AJRC consist of the Electoral Commissioners from each State and Territory, the Australian Electoral Commissioner and the Deputy Australian Electoral Commissioner and the Assistant Commissioner responsible for enrolment in the AEC.

Supported. However, the Government and the AEC consider that, in view of their particular operational perspective, one of the Australian Electoral Officers should also be included on the AJRC. This has been agreed by the State electoral authorities, and the AJRC is so constituted.
The Committee further recommends that, when an issue affects one State/Territory only, the Australian Electoral Officer concerned be co-opted to the AJRC for that agenda item only.

Not supported, because of the amended membership referred to in Recommendation 44 above and because matters affecting one State only would more usually be dealt with by the relevant joint management committee referred to in Recommendation 40 above.

The Committee recommends that the terms of reference of the Australian Joint Roll Council include the development and maintenance of the joint roll and other electoral matters which have significance for more than one electoral administra tion.
Supported and agreed by the AJRC.
The Committee recommends that the Minister for Administrative Services approach his State/Territory colleagues to propose the establishment of a Ministerial Council on electoral matters.

Not supported. In the light of Council of Australian Governments (COAG) decisions with respect to Ministerial Councils, it would seem inappropriate to adopt this recommendation at this time. The desired level of interaction between Commonwealth and State interests should be fully met by the Australian Joint Roll Council (Recommendation 43), the Joint Management Committees (Recommendation 40) plus the existing Senior Commonwealth and State Electoral Officials' Conference and the ongoing contact between the AEC and the State/Territory Commissions.

The Committee recommends that the Ministerial Council considers the desirability of an extra appointment to the Australian Electoral Commission to be filled by State/Territory Commissioners in rotation, and reviews this matter from time to time.

Not supported. Evidence was received by the Committee in support of the separation, for reasons of political and practical reality, of the electoral functions of the Commonwealth and each State/Territory. In concluding that it should not recommend a single body to conduct all federal and State elections, the Committee appears to have accepted the weight of this evidence. The Government does not consider that it would be appropriate to appoint a State Commissioner to the Commonwealth Commission and thereby give the States an influence over Commonwealth matters including the conduct of Commonwealth elections. Such an appointment would also have the potential for conflict of interests—eg. in the area of the AEC's charging policy. Further, no equivalent input is proposed for the Commonwealth to move into the workings of State electoral bodies—nor is such an input suggested by the Government.

The Committee recommends that the AEC approach the State/Territory Commissions with the view to setting out the arrangements for the provision of roll products to the States/Territories in formal contracts. These negotiations should occur in the context of a review of the Joint Roll Agree ments.
Supported. The AEC has already begun to explore the possibility of negotiating formal contracts with the State Commissions.
The Committee recommends that the AJRC undertake an inquiry into the advantages of a centralised as against a decentralised database.
Supported. The inquiry should proceed if a majority of the members of the AJRC consider that it is desirable. The States would also need to be prepared to pay half the costs of the inquiry.

The Committee recommends that the AEC make arrangements with State/Territory Commissions and State/Territory local government associations to ensure that completed electoral claim cards received by those authorities are delivered expeditiously to State/Territory AEC head offices or DROs.
Supported.
The Committee recommends that Section 92 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 be amended to allow more flexibility in the timing of Electoral Roll Reviews.
Supported. The Government and the AEC consider that Electoral Roll Reviews should be timed so that the rolls are most accurate for Commonwealth and State electoral events and redistributions.
The Committee recommends that where a review is timed to meet Commonwealth needs (for instance, an election or redistribution) the cost be carried by the Commonwealth.
The Committee recommends that where a review is timed to meet State/Territory needs (for instance, an election or a redistribution) the cost be carried by the State/Territory concerned.
The Committee recommends that where a review is timed to meet Commonwealth and State/Territory needs the cost be shared equally between the Commonwealth and the State/Territory concerned.

Recommendations 53-55 not supported. Irrespective of the timing of Electoral Roll Reviews, they benefit both the Commonwealth and the States. There are benefits for State electoral rolls, local government electoral rolls, products for State members of parliament and State jury lists. Accordingly, the cost of all Electoral Roll Reviews should be equally shared between the Commonwealth and the State/Territory concerned.
The Committee recommends that consideration of alternatives to habitation reviews be undertaken by the proposed Australian Joint Roll Council (AJRC).

Supported. However, the Government and the AEC note that previous work in this area does not lead to optimism that an effective alternative to Electoral Roll Reviews can be found. Nevertheless, subject to privacy considerations, it may be possible to use alternative sources of information which would supplement Electoral Roll Reviews.
The Committee recommends that a review of joint roll allowances be undertaken by the proposed Australian Joint Roll Council in consultation with the relevant union.
Supported as to there being a review. The functional allowances, including joint roll allowances, will be reviewed in the context of the organisation and resources of the AEC.

The Committee recommends that the AJRC give early consideration to the use of AEC facilities for the production of all rolls for State/Territory and local government election requirements throughout Australia, and that it advise the States/Territories of the results of its investigation.

Supported. Provisions exist for the preparation of rolls for local governments by the AEC in three States and the Northern Territory. Steps are currently being taken which are likely to result in the AEC providing local government rolls for Tasmania. Local government rolls could be readily provided in the other two States. However, the Government's view is that this is more appropriately a matter for bilateral negotiations between the Commonwealth and the States concerned.

The Committee recommends that the AEC approach the South Australian Electoral Commissioner with the view to interlinking RMANS and EAGLE so that interstate transfers can be adequately checked, matched and effected.
Supported. However, the alternative of transferring the joint roll to RMANS needs also to be considered. Either way it would be necessary for South Australia to pay half the costs of the linkage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters entitled Ready or Not: Refining the Process for Election 93. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: THE GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT OF THE JOINT STANDING COMMITTEE ON ELECTORAL MATTERS ENTITLED "READY OR NOT: REFINING THE PROCESS FOR ELECTION 93"

On 17 December 1992 the then Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, Mr A Bevis MP, tabled the Report entitled "Ready or Not: Refining the Process for Election `93". The Report was the result of the Committee's Inquiry into the Conduct of the 1990 Federal Election, Part II and Preparations for the Next Federal Election. As amendments to legislation permitting the implementation of procedures for the counting of House of Representatives votes on polling night were then before the Senate, the Committee released an Interim Report on 24 November 1992 entitled "Counting the Vote on Election Night", which dealt only with counting and transmitting the vote on election night. As the recommendations of the Interim Report are reproduced in the main Report of the Committee this Response treats both Reports as one.
Recommendation 1
That the Government respond to the Report on the 1990 Federal Election.
Response
The Government tabled its response to the Report on the 1990 Federal Election on 8 December 1992.
Recommendation 2

The Committee recommends that the AEC instruct DROs and Polling Officials to arrange any queues which may form on polling day, so that as many voters as possible are provided with shelter, with particular consideration for those with special needs.
Response

Supported. The problem of queuing at polling places was the subject of a detailed study within the Australian Electoral Commission, which resulted in revised policies on polling place resources and procedures being developed. The Divisional Office Procedures Elections Manual carries an instruction that queues should wherever possible be formed within the polling place to provide voters with protection from the elements. The Polling Place Control Manual issued to all Officers in Charge (OICs) of polling places carries a specific instruction to maintain queues within polling places, as does the Polling Place Procedures Manual issued to all polling staff. The training video shown to polling place OICs also carries that message. The experience of the 1993 elections was that the Commission's revised polling place policies have generally been successful. Further refinements are now being targeted to individual polling places to address specific local problems.
Recommendation 3

The Committee recommends that the AEC adjust its polling premises policy in order to minimise the use of dual polling places, and following the 1993 election, report to the JSCEM on the number of dual polling places used and any problems which may arise at such polling places.
Response

Dual polling places are created close to Divisional boundaries with convenience to the voter as the main consideration. They enable voters to cast an ordinary vote as opposed to the completion of a declaration vote at a convenient polling place, and help reduce confusion arising from electoral boundary changes. Accordingly, this part of the recommendation is not supported. The Australian Electoral Commission's National Polling Place Resources Policy includes in the criteria for the appointment of a dual polling place that such a polling place must take at least 240 declaration votes for an adjoining Division. This is the point past which a dual polling place becomes most effective and economically viable. For the 1993 election there were 125 premises housing shared polling places. The Commission included a report on the operation of dual polling places in its submission to the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters to assist its Inquiry into the Conduct of the 1993 Federal Election.
Recommendation 4

The Committee recommends that the Minister for Administrative Services seek an opinion from the Attorney-General on the application of s.44(iv) of the Constitution to employees of government enterprises who are not employed under the Public Service Act 1922.
Response

Supported. Advice has been received from the Attorney-General's Department. A copy of that advice has been referred to the Department of Industrial Relations. Over the past decade, the thrust of public sector reforms affecting government business enterprises and statutory authorities has been to devolve responsibility for day-to-day operational matters to the management of those organisations. Accordingly, those organisations are free to manage their industrial relations without reference to the Department of Industrial Relations for endorsement, other than in a limited number of matters. In keeping with this policy, advice will be provided to government business enterprises and non-Public Service Act authorities regarding the legal issues associated with employees and other office holders seeking election to Parliament; and the approach adopted in respect of Public Service Act employees standing for election to Parliament. Consistent with the emphasis of the abovementioned reforms, that advice will also encourage government business enterprises and non-Public Service Act authorities to develop, if they have not already done so, a policy on the matter.
Recommendation 5

The Committee recommends that the proposed approach to the States Attorneys-General regarding uniform re-employment provisions for public servants resigning to contest federal elections, be made as a matter of urgency, and that the AEC make the responses available to intending candidates.
Response

Supported. At its meeting on 24 June 1993 the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General (SCAG) considered some model provisions for public servant reinstatement rights, on which both federal, State and Territory jurisdictions could draw. SCAG recommended that Ministers endorse the model, and referred the provision to the appropriate State and Territory Ministers with a recommendation that it be enacted, while recognising that it is a matter for each jurisdiction to decide what approach they adopt. The matter is currently in the hands of the State and Territory Ministers.
Recommendation 6

The Committee recommends that the AEC review its Candidates' Handbook and Nomination Checklist to include information on the implications of the recent High Court decision and the possible need to take steps to establish their eligibility under s.44 of the Constitution.
Response

13. Supported. This recommendation was based on the Handbook and Nomination Form provided to intending candidates at the 1990 election and the voided 1992 Wills by-election. Both the Candidate's Handbook and the Nomination Form were revised prior to the 1993 election to provide material on the implications of the High Court's decision in the Sykes v Cleary case. A Nomination Checklist and the wording of section 44 of the Constitution were both included on the Nomination Form.
Recommendation 7
The Committee recommends that information about the proposed provisions on evidence of authorship or authorisation of material, if enacted by the Parliament, be included in the Candidates' Handbook.
Response
Supported. Material on evidence of authorship was included in the Candidate's Handbook prior to the 1993 election.
Recommendation 8
The Committee recommends that the AEC conduct an evaluation of its enrolment program in remote areas and provide a report on the evaluation to the Committee.
Response
Supported. The Australian Electoral Commission will begin this review in early 1994, following the completion of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Regional Council elections.
Recommendation 9
The Committee recommends that the AEC review the procedures required for finalising the Senate count, with a view to having the writs returned at the earliest opportunity following the election.
Response

Supported. At the 1993 federal election, the AEC trialled the use of a computer program designed to speed the calculation of transfer values and other arithmetic processes necessary in a Senate scrutiny. While the trial identified that time was saved by using the program, the most time consuming tasks, involving the conduct of the formality check of the ballot papers and the need to physically allocate papers to candidates at each count, remained unaltered. For the 1993 election, the number of counts necessary and the period from polling day to the return of the Senate writ varied from 1 count in the ACT and the Northern Territory to 253 counts in New South Wales, and from 24 days in Tasmania to 46 days in South Australia, respectively. This compared with a high of 197 counts and 51 days for New South Wales at the 1990 election. Factors such as the number of candidates, size of the ballot paper, total number of ballot papers and a number of `non-ticket' ballot papers impact on the time required to conduct the scrutiny. In an attempt to further improve the speed of the Senate count, the Commission is developing an automated Senate scrutiny system. Early evaluation trials with proportional representation ballots indicate that the speed of the Senate scrutiny could be vastly improved while maintaining a comprehensive audit trail. The Attorney-General's Department has advised that an amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 will be required to allow such a system to be used. The Commission has recently lodged a submission with the JSC suggesting that the Committee may wish to consider recommending such an amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918.
Recommendation 10
The Committee recommends that divisional maps produced by the AEC name all streets and roads within the Division.
Response

The purpose of these maps is to delineate clearly and precisely all Divisional boundaries. The maps are produced by the various State/Territory mapping authorities. They are very costly and the detail and presentation varies in accordance with the data held by the respective mapping authorities. It is assumed that this recommendation refers to metropolitan divisions primarily. The Australian Electoral Commission is investigating the practicality and cost of meeting this recommendation in those cases where all the metropolitan streets are not already named.
Recommendation 11

The Committee recommends that the AEC identify the two candidates to whom preferences are to be provisionally distributed on election night using all relevant objective data including historical results.
Response
Supported. This was implemented for the 1993 election.
Recommendation 12

The Committee recommends that the names of the two candidates identified for receipt of provisionally distributed preferences be kept confidential until the close of poll. Each DRO should be informed in confidence so that the relevant checks can be made before polling day. An exception can be made for those individuals employed by the media to program their election night computer systems, in which case the names of the candidates can be divulged in strict confidence and on a need-to-know basis no earlier than the morning of the election. The names of the two candidates should be given to the OIC of each polling place in a secure manner in a sealed envelope. The envelope should be opened in the presence of scrutineers and polling staff.
Response

Supported. This was implemented for the 1993 election. However, the Australian Electoral Commission believes that it would be preferable for polling place OICs to have access to this information, on a confidential basis, before polling day so that they are not placed under undue pressure at a critical time.
Recommendation 13

At all stages of the count full and reasonable access should be provided for scrutineers and all polling staff should be informed of the scrutineers' rights of access. The access should ensure adequate scrutiny of the formality of the votes in the count of first preferences, opportunities to observe the preferences of minor candidates during the two-candidate preferred distribution, and opportunities to analyse all ballot papers as required after the results of the House of Representatives count have been transmitted. Access to the Senate count on election night should be adequate to monitor the formality of votes, with more comprehensive access to Senate ballot papers being afforded to scrutineers in subsequent counting of the vote. The AEC should consult the political parties and candidates regarding access for scrutineers.
Response
Supported. This was implemented for the 1993 election.
Recommendation 14

The result of the first preference vote count should be transmitted immediately from each polling place to the Divisional Office, and from there immediately for each polling place to the National Tally Room.
Response
Supported. This was implemented for the 1993 election.
Recommendation 15

The result of the provisional two-candidate preferred distribution should be transmitted as soon as possible from each polling place, and transmitted in at least three batches from the Divisional Office to the National Tally Room with information about the polling places included when approximately 10 per cent, approximately 40 per cent and the final count for the night is collected by the DRO.
Response
Supported. This was implemented for the 1993 election.
Recommendation 16

The AEC should prepare an information kit for the use of the media involved in broadcasting the election results. Opportunities should be provided to media representatives to discuss the procedures for transmitting election results.
Response
Supported. This was implemented for the 1993 election, as in previous elections.

DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO EGYPT AND ISRAEL AND THE 93RD INTER-PARLIAMENTARY CONFERENCE

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present the report of the Australian Parliamentary Delegation to Egypt and Israel, and the 93rd Inter-Parliamentary Conference which was held in Madrid between 26 March and 1 April 1995. I have much pleasure in making a few comments on this particular delegation. As the minister would know, we usually get on very well on a bipartisan basis on these particular occasions.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to say that this delegation was led by the Speaker, the Hon. Steve Martin. The delegation of members from both chambers of the Australian parliament visited Egypt and Israel at the invitation of those respective parliaments and we attended the 93rd Inter-Parliamentary Conference held in Madrid. As an added bonus, we were very fortunate to have a stopover in Rome and the delegation was received by his Holiness the Pope at a Papal audience on Saturday, 11 March. He made comment about what a wonderful place Australia was. The Speaker pointed to the fact that when the Pope was in Australia it started to rain and that perhaps he might have to think about stopping at a few places.

When we visited the Middle East it was potentially unstable. It still is, of course. There are certain moves towards peace in the region, particularly since the signing of the declaration of principles by Israel and the Palestinian Liberation Organisation. The members of the delegation were the Hon. Steve Martin, who was leading the delegation, me, the Hon. Leo McLeay, Clyde Holding, who was a member at the 93rd Inter-Parliamentary Union Conference, as was Senator Cheryl Kernot, who joined us there, and Mr Rod Sawford MP and Mr Alex Somlyay, who were part of the delegation that visited Israel and Egypt.

We were accompanied by Anne Hazelton, who was secretary to the delegation. On her return she received a very honourable move to the Parliamentary Relations Office. We are very pleased to see that. Bill O'Brien, who was Counsellor from the Holy See, His Excellency Mr Colin McDonald in Cairo, His Excellency Mr Peter Rodgers in Tel Aviv and Mr Warwick Pearson in Madrid were very good in their organisation for when we visited there. Those posts were also excellent.

The bilateral visit to Egypt was of great importance. As honourable senators would know, Egypt is playing a key role in the peace process in the Middle East. It was the first Arab country to sign a peace treaty with Israel in 1979 and it is playing a leading role. Egypt is an important trading customer for Australia. Most of our trade is wheat. Senator Panizza is not here, but Senator Crane is and he would know how important Egypt is as far as our wheat trade is concerned.

The Speaker of the Egyptian parliament, Dr Fathi Sorour, is also the President of the Interparliamentary Council and was elected so at the previous Inter-Parliamentary Union. There was a lot of discussion about the nuclear non-proliferation treaty and the non-signing of it by Israel. We put forward the Australian position in relation to the NPT. It is interesting to note that that matter is being debated here today.

We had the opportunity to see some of the new industrial cities being developed by Egypt and we visited Ramadan City, which has something like 2,000 industrial businesses of varying size. As far as the Egyptian visit was concerned, it was one characterised by great warmth and hospitality. I was amazed. It was the first time I had been to Egypt. Cairo itself is a very thriving city to say the least. The warmth and hospitality from the parliament right through to the people who drove us was most impressive.

We moved on to Israel. We had some very interesting discussions in Israel. The most interesting and impressive discussion was in our meeting with the President of Israel, Mr Ezer Weizmann. We had a three-quarter of an hour discussion with him. We had discussions with the Speaker of the Knesset, Professor Shevach Weiss. We were also honoured to have some discussions with the Deputy President and Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Shimon Peres, along with some very important briefings from the Department for the Peace Process and Middle Eastern Affairs.

While we were there we raised the subject of Australia's involvement in the multinational force and observers program on the border between Egypt and Israel. The foreign minister took on board that the success of that particular operation was something he would keep in mind if and when the peace arrangements could be made with Syria. While we were there we took the opportunity to visit the Golan Heights. I can assure the Senate that I can understand Israel's point of view of wanting to control the Golan Heights. On the other hand, since my return, it has been interesting to see that they may be willing to return the Golan Heights to Syria in their quest for peace. It is quite obvious, to us anyway, that the peace process, regardless of how slow it is moving and the immense difficulties that there are, is irreversible, even though it might be a highly complicated and complex one.

We had some very interesting discussions with the Australia-Israel Chamber of Commerce. It was interesting to note that they were particularly interested in processed food. The Minister for Trade (Senator McMullan) probably has the same impression. I think he visited Israel a couple of weeks after we were there. They know that processed foods from Australia are basically disease free and chemical free. I pricked up my ears to that when I started talking to them about Tasmanian salmon, which is, at the present time anyway, disease free and certainly chemical free.

One person we met at the chamber of commerce told us that the best building products in the world he imported were from England and Australia. On returning to Tasmania I made some inquiries of a local brickmaking concern. They were investigating exporting bricks to Israel. Interestingly enough, I think the freighting costs to freight a container load of bricks from Hobart to Melbourne was $1,300 and from Melbourne to Israel was $1,500. The Israelis were also very interested in our telecommunications and our scientific, medical and surgical markets.

We were very impressed with Israel's attitude towards Jordan. A peace treaty was signed between them in 1994 and we were assured by everybody we spoke to that very good relations now exist with Jordan. We were also interested to hear from Mr Shimon Peres about his idea of involving joint ventures on the border between the two countries.

We visited the multinational force in the Sinai where we have a contingent of 27 personnel. We were most impressed with the work carried out by Major General David Ferguson, who is the head of our force there. We are very proud of the fact that he is controlling some 2,000 combined troops from all around the world—Fiji, Colombia, France, Holland, the United States and Canada.We visited Gaza. I do not know whether the minister had the opportunity visit Gaza.

TALK.START.PARA: —I went to Jericho.

—Right. The same sort of story, I guess. Australia has contributed $14 million in aid to Gaza. The overwhelming impression we gained was that the administration is tackling an enormous task. Infrastructure is almost non-existent. The uncontrolled disposal of waste water into the sea leading to degradation is a problem and waste water is also disposed of in the streets of Gaza—we drove through it! I thought they were short of water and made a comment to that effect. We found out afterwards it was raw sewage. Solid waste collection is almost non-existent.
