SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of this Bill is to enable the `telecommunication standardisation' component of Australia's contribution to the International Telecommunication Union (ITU) to be recovered through carrier licence fees payable by telecommunications carriers from 1 July 1995.

The ITU is a United Nations specialised agency which is concerned with international cooperation in the use of telecommunications and the radio frequency spectrum. It establishes agreements and recommended world standards for telecommunications and radiocommunications services.

Currently, telecommunications licence fees only recover the public-interest regulatory costs incurred by the Australian Telecommunications Authority (AUSTEL), and the total fees payable by the carriers must not exceed the appropriation provided to AUSTEL for the previous financial year. Carrier licence fees are payable on 1 July 1995. Inclusion of the ITU contribution in carrier licence fees is in addition to AUSTEL's appropriations and will exceed the amount able to be collected under the current legislation. An amendment to the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Act 1991 is therefore necessary to enable the full recovery of the `telecommunication standardisation' component of the ITU contribution from carriers from 1 July 1995.

Australia's ITU contribution for a given calendar year is paid prior to the commencement of that year. The amount of the ITU contribution is likely to change every year. The amount to be recovered from carriers for telecommunications sector activity will depend upon the level of the total ITU contribution (which is set in Swiss Francs and is subject to exchange rate variation) and the share ascribed to the telecommunication standardisation sector of ITU activity.

The Bill provides for an amount to be determined under the regulations as the proportion of the Commonwealth's contribution to the total budget of the ITU for a calendar year that is attributable to matters relating to telecommunication standardisation.

It is proposed to amend the Telecommunications (Carrier Licence Fees) Regulations to prescribe a procedure for determining the additional fee before 1 July 1995 in order for the ITU contribution to be included in the carrier licence fees due on that date and on 1 July of each succeeding year in respect of a general telecommunications licence or a public mobile licence.
Financial Impact

The financial impact of the proposed amendments on carriers will be to increase the annual amount payable in licence fees by a total of approximately 1 million dollars. The cost will be shared by carriers on the basis of their share of telecommunications traffic.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak tonight on the National Media Liaison Service. I am delighted that Senator McMullan is in the chamber. In fact, the National Media Liaison Service, more commonly called aNiMaLS, is a political hit squad.

PARA.TAB: In the estimates hearings we have been trying to better ascertain the work of the National Media Liaison Service and the role of Mr David Epstein. Senator McMullan has been in the chair at the estimates hearings on two occasions and he has seen fit to put his own reputation on the line to defend the work of the National Media Liaison Service.

You will be aware that one of the issues that Mr David Epstein has consistently argued, despite overwhelming evidence to the contrary, is that he is not the director of the National Media Liaison Service, but that he is the director of the Ministerial Media Group. In other words, when he appears in the press gallery, he says he does so as a member of the Ministerial Media Group and not as the director of the National Media Liaison Service and, therefore, cannot be subject to detailed questioning.

We have had evidence of how he has described himself in directories. We have had evidence of how he has described himself in letters. We have had evidence of how he has been described by Mr Beazley in letters—all of which include the title Director, National Media Liaison Service. But each time we have raised this issue, I am sorry to say that Senator McMullan has strongly supported Mr Epstein in alleging that this title—Director, National Media Liaison Service—is not a title which Mr Epstein wears.

For example, on 9 February, Mr David Epstein told estimates, `My contract of employment is Director, Ministerial Media Group'. The evidence that Mr Epstein wanted us to rely on was that his contract of employment said he was Director, Ministerial Media Group. On 9 February, Senator McMullan told estimates:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Epstein has made it clear that his contract of employment says that he is director of the Ministerial Media Group,—

What we were describing to you is the correct description of Mr Epstein's employment.—
and these are the key words:

His contract makes it very clear that he is employed as director of the Ministerial Media Group and such responsibilities as he has for day-to-day supervision of NMLS under the delegation from the minister, which has been referred to from time to time, do not make any difference to the fact that his contractual status is—and the letter and the contract make it clear—solely as director of the Ministerial Media Group. I wonder if the committee could be provided with a copy of Mr Epstein's contract.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the last sitting week I tabled two photographs of marlin being unloaded from a longline tuna fishing boat in Cairns operated by a Mr Mike Rowley. These fish, I am informed by Mr Rowley's former manager, Mr David Armstrong, came from TEC 4, area E. This area was set aside from longline tuna fishing in 1980 to protect marlin stocks in the area from depletion. In 1986, at the first meeting of ECTUNAMAC, the East Coast Tuna Management Advisory Committee, three longline permits were issued upon strictly limited conditions, one being the return of all billfish to the water, whether dead or alive.

PARA.TAB: In the intervening period the number of permits on issue in the area has risen to 13. But Mr Rowley has now put a proposal before ECTUNAMAC which would effectively allow open slather longline fishing in TEC 4 area E. He seeks an increase in the number of hooks from the current 500 hooks to 1,500 hooks, an increase in the number of licences and a reduction in the size of the zone protected to half what it currently is. Mr Rowley is a member of ECTUNAMAC and so sits in judgment on his own proposal.

In answer to the criticism that this would lead to unacceptable slaughter, Mr Rowley proposes a closure of the fishery to longliners for three months at the end of the year. Mr Rowley says this is the best protection which can be given to the marlin, but unfortunately the truth is somewhat different. For nine months of the year there will be no protection at all for the marlin, nor for the tuna on which they depend. An increased longline effort, and especially an increase in the number of hooks used by longline operators, can only lead to one consequence, and that is an increased bycatch of marlin in the other nine months of the year.

Let me return to the photographs which I tabled. Mr Rowley claims these are not black or blue marlin, but striped marlin. He also claims that these fish were taken outside TEC 4 area E. Unfortunately, Mr Rowley's track record with the truth is so poor that nobody believes him. Tonight I intend to expose a litany of lies and half truths disseminated by Mr Rowley, as well as his motives for doing what he has done.

In relation to the photographs, I have had these examined by a number of experts, not one of whom believes they are of striped marlin. At best they say it is difficult to tell, and the reason for that is that Mr Rowley has his crews cut the heads off the fish. This not only helps hide the way in which the fish have been killed, but also hinders identification of the fish. I add that this practice is illegal in Queensland waters outside TEC 4 area E, as all billfish must retain their heads to allow easy identification.

As to Mr Rowley's claim that the fish did not come from the protected area, not only is this contrary to Mr Armstrong's advices but also it is contrary to what was contained in a letter written by Mr Rowley to the Cairns Post on 10 June when he wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . you may remember that I told you we had not fished in area E from September 1994 to May 1995. My vessels are now fishing in area E from time to time and will continue to do so . . .
I seek leave to table a copy of the letter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. At any rate, these photographs and Mr Rowley's admission that he has taken marlin give the lie to Mr Rowley's claim to ECTUNAMAC, which I referred to last week, wherein he stated that the industry was observing the ban on the taking of marlin almost 100 per cent. While that may be the case for other operators, it is clearly not the case for Mr Rowley, who considers himself above the law.

PARA.TAB: Let me turn to some of the claims Mr Rowley has made in the media about what he is doing, and about himself. In a newspaper story that appeared in the Cairns Post on 10 June 1995, Mr Rowley claimed that he is a third generation fisherman, that his family pioneered longline fishing in Australia and that he is only seeking to win back market share from the Japanese for the Australian industry. All of this is intended to give the impression that Mr Rowley is a struggling Aussie battler. Now let me get to the facts.

Mr Rowley may be a third generation fisherman, but he was not born in Australia. Returns to the Australian Securities Commission show that Mr Rowley was born in Middlesborough, England in June 1933. But that is nothing compared to his grossest untruth. Company searches were conducted last week on three companies with which Mr Rowley is or has been involved. They are Seafood Management Pty Ltd, Fortuna Seafoods Pty Ltd and Sandgate Sashimi Pty Ltd. I seek leave to table these documents.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seafood Management is a vehicle of which Mr Rowley had been a director from shortly after incorporation in 1991 until late 1994. Mr Rowley's wife remains a director. This is also the company which sold some, if not all, of the marlin unloaded from Mr Rowley's boats. Many people believe this company is owned and controlled by Mr Rowley. However, the principal executive officer shown on the company's files at the ASC is Mr Jin Tyan Chen of Kaohsiung, Taiwan.

PARA.TAB: Turning to the details of shareholders, one can see that there are 10 shares on issue, five of which are beneficially owned by Mr Jin Tyan Chen, four shares are owned by other Taiwanese and one share is owned by Mr Rowley. Mr Rowley does not have the beneficial interest in the share, though, and it is not known who does. Seafood Management is not an Australian owned company but a Taiwanese owned company.

The next company associated with Mr Rowley is Fortuna Seafoods Pty Ltd, which is shown in the records of the Queensland Department of Transport as being the owner of the vessels Fortuna II and Sarah Jay. This company has two shareholders, Mr Rowley and his wife, but the company is a trustee company for unnamed beneficiaries.

The third company associated with Mr Rowley is Sandgate Sashimi Pty Ltd. This company is the owner of a vessel called the Cygnet Bay. This vessel is important because it is the holder of a non-active permit to fish in TEC 4 area E, as well as another entitlement to fish for tuna elsewhere on the east coast of Australia. This company's records show that the shareholders are Mr Richard Richmond and Mr Kenneth McEwen. However, both gentlemen have resigned as directors, and in their place are Mr Rowley and the same Taiwanese gentleman I referred to earlier, Mr Chen.

Apparently the share transfer form has not yet been processed. The reason for this share trading is to permit a transfer of a permit to fish in TEC 4 area E into the hands of Taiwanese fishermen and to flout the law relating to permits.

The obvious strength and passion of feeling that Senator Cook had against New Zealand and New Zealand's policies was extremely denigrating and of great concern to any New Zealander listening to his answer. In terms of the New Zealand policies and the way that they have gone, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . in my view it is not a route that any civilised government would want to take. It is too brutal and too socially divisive.

The latter words, `brutal' and `socially divisive', were used by the Treasurer, Mr Willis, a few days earlier and were echoed by Senator Cook. They were very critical comments. In effect, Senator Cook is saying that New Zealand is not a civilised government. I think it is a disgrace for any senior minister of the Australian government to level that against our Anzac colleague.

PARA.TAB: What concerned me even more than the vitriol that Senator Cook poured on New Zealand and its policies, which policies have had an extraordinarily beneficial effect on New Zealand as a whole and its prospects in the world—it is now an internationally competitive economy that leaves Australia way behind—is that, amongst other things, in his response to me Senator Cook said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . several thousand New Zealanders in Australia are benefiting from our social welfare and unemployment benefit. If they returned to New Zealand you would have an unemployment rate of around 20 per cent and not the current level.

The statement that unemployment in New Zealand would be 20 per cent, compared with the existing figure of about 6.6 per cent, if the unemployed New Zealanders in Australia went back to New Zealand and failed to get work there is a monstrously inaccurate statement. No wonder the New Zealand High Commission in Canberra picked up that statement—that gross and monstrous inaccuracy.

PARA.TAB: Very understandably, the New Zealand High Commissioner, Mr Fortune, wrote to Senator Cook the following day, 6 June, to point out the inaccuracy of his statement. The High Commissioner went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: A rough calculation shows that if these people returned to New Zealand the level of unemployment in New Zealand would rise from 6.6% to around 7.6%.

(3) DAS does not keep records of the total annual contributions paid to deduction authorities back to 1988. A computer report for the amount of superannuation contributions made to AMP is available for 1993 and 1994. The amounts are as follows: 1993—$1,311,892.77; 1994—$1,038,195.64.

(4) AMP appear to have experienced some administrative difficulties in reconciling the `group' cheque issued by DoF with details of contribution amounts set out in the accompanying printed statement. This has led to delays and some errors in the crediting of contributions and interest to at least one individual electorate staff account. The problem was not identified until AMP was queried by the Insurance and Superannuation Commission (ISC) following a complaint by an electorate staffer. The ISC notified the Government after it commenced investigating the matter with AMP (see part 13 below).
(5) One electorate staff member has been identified as having experienced shortfalls in calculated superannuation payments by AMP. The relevant account has been rectified.

(6) DAS has written to all staff employed under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984 who are members of private superannuation schemes. It was suggested that they may wish to check their records for possible irregularities in their superannuation accounts.

To supplement this, the ISC has written to all twenty life offices/superannuation funds which receive superannuation contributions through the Commonwealth payroll system by and on behalf of electorate staff, requesting that they perform a person by person—or where this is not practicable, a sample—manual reconciliation of the contributions of past and present electorate staff to ensure that their account balances are correct.
In addition, the ISC will follow up with funds which appear to have weaknesses in their systems to ensure that these systems are suitably upgraded.

(7) AMP have undertaken to manually check (to the extent records are available) and, where necessary, correct the accounts of other electorate staffers who have or have had superannuation contributions paid to AMP by way of DoF `group' payroll deductions.

(8) The group payment scheme for electorate staff with private superannuation arrangements has not been disallowed and the AMP product involved is still operating for existing members. However, since July 1990 new electorate staff have been required to join the Public Sector Superannuation Scheme and staffers in personal superannuation arrangements will therefore decline over time. AMP has indicated it may wish to offer existing members the option of transferring to another product.

AMP have advised the ISC that the product concerned was not originally designed to be used in the way it now is for these Parliamentary staffers. In particular, it is a personal superannuation product which would normally receive contributions direct from the employee and/or employer, and not via a group payment mechanism. The product became more difficult to administer for Parliamentary staffers in 1988, when differential tax treatment of employee and employer contributions was introduced.
(9) See answers to part 8 above. AMP has not formally proposed an alternative scheme; the current scheme remains operational for existing members.

(10) Under the `group' superannuation payment system for Ministerial and electorate staff, DAS passes information including each payee's name, superannuation policy number and amount of employer contribution, together with the total employer plus employee contribution, to DoF through a direct computer link. Under DoF's standing-amount-variation system, the same contribution amounts will be sent to AMP automatically each fortnight, unless and until DAS process a variation on notification from the electorate staff member.

DoF processes the information as part of the Commonwealth payroll system and issues a group cheque to the relevant life office/superannuation fund through the regional office in the State in which the employee is domiciled. The cheque covers the total amount of all contributions (employer and employee) that are administered by that life office/superannuation fund (ie a `group cheque') and is accompanied by a printed statement which sets out a list of all the employees involved, a reference to the paying agency, the amount of the employer contribution, the gross amount of the contribution for each employee, the policy number and any variations.
DoF and DAS are satisfied with the integrity of their systems and procedures.

DoF has confirmed that fortnightly group superannuation cheques sent by its regional offices to life companies/superannuation funds are generally received and cashed on the due date. The money is then available to be allocated to each individual employee's account. Some life offices/superannuation funds initially place the cash into a `suspense' account, pending reconciliation of the moneys with the details; however, interest credited to individual accounts in these circumstances is backdated to date of receipt of the `group' cheque.

The timing of superannuation payments by DoF to AMP is well within the maximum time frame allowable under section 64 of the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) (SIS) Act 1993. Section 64 provides that employers who deduct moneys from the salaries or wages of their employees for the purpose of making superannuation contributions must pay to the trustees of the relevant superannuation funds those amounts before the end of the 28 day period beginning immediately after the end of the month in which the deduction was made. An employer who intentionally or recklessly fails to observe this requirement is guilty of an offence.

(11) The SIS Act 1993 does not impose any direct legal responsibility on trustees to ensure that employer contributions are paid to the fund by the appropriate date. As mentioned in relation to question (10) above, the regulatory framework places responsibility for the prompt remittance of contributions on employers rather than trustees. This reflects the fact that it is the employer, not the trustee, that has funding responsibilities in respect of the scheme. However, this does not absolve the fund trustees from seeking to ensure that contributions received are properly identified and promptly processed; and member accounts are required to be correct and current at each balance date, or when a member leaves.

(12) The Trade Practices Commission (TPC) made preliminary enquiries into the complaint by the specific electorate staff member who had problems with the AMP. When these enquiries established that the problems stemmed from administrative and accounting problems rather than misrepresentations, the TPC and ISC agreed it was more appropriate for the ISC to have carriage of the investigation.
The TPC participated in subsequent discussions and is being kept informed of progress in the ISC's investigation.

(13) As mentioned in the answer to part (6), the ISC is investigating insurance companies and other superannuation providers that manage superannuation accounts on behalf of electorate staff. The ISC investigation is aimed at:
resolving the specific problems relating to superannuation accounts with AMP;

determining whether other life offices/superannuation funds administering accounts for electorate staff payment arrangements are affected by similar administrative problems, and if so, ensuring that any errors are rectified and systems upgraded as appropriate; and
attempting to gauge, through field visits, the wider incidence of administrative problems in respect of the payment of superannuation contributions by employers to funds via group arrangements where:
(i) contributions include employer and employee components, and
(ii) the accounts involve personal superannuation products chosen by the employee.

In addition to its discussions with AMP, the ISC has written to 20 life offices/superannuation funds seeking information on Parliamentary staffer accounts and on their administrative systems generally. Where funds have not responded to the ISC's satisfaction, it is following up. In addition, the ISC has conducted field visits to several life offices to look at their capacity to promptly and accurately allocate contributions to personal accounts when payments are made by way of group cheques.

On balance, the ISC considers there is no endemic problem in the industry with either group/corporate or personal arrangements in respect of the processing of bulk contributions. However, there are some companies whose administrative procedures could potentially cause isolated problems. The ISC will work with the industry to develop solutions, including `best practices' guidelines, to overcome these inadequacies.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 8 February 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the Government's response to the recent study by the NSW Environment Protection Authority (EPA) which indicates that aircraft noise levels in certain Sydney suburbs have been much higher than forecast before the third runway at Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport became operational.
(2) Is the EPA report correct to suggest that the Federal Airports Corporation and the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) have been negligent in failing to warn the public about expected noise levels.
(3) Did the Australian Noise Exposure Forecast system fail to accurately forecast the suburbs to be affected once the runway was opened.
(4) When will the CAA release results of the noise testing which it has been carrying out since the third runway was opened.
(5) Will the Government adopt the EPA report recommendation that an independent body be set up to oversee the implementation of a noise management plan.

(6) When does the Government intend to respond to the "Airport Charter" which was endorsed at a public rally held at Sydney's Leichhardt Oval on 3 December 1994 and included calls for the re-opening of the east-west runway at Sydney's Kingsford-Smith Airport.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government considers that the EPA report gives a distorted view of noise exposure around the airport. The noise readings ignore any change in noise exposure due to daily or seasonal variations in wind patterns and aircraft movements, and are not representative of what will happen most of the time. Additionally, the EPA noise readings were conducted prior to the implementation of changes to aircraft operations announced by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport on 8 December 1994. These measures include the regulation of strict arrival and departure corridors, requiring all jets to depart from the southern threshold of the main runway when departing to the north, the application of steeper climb procedures and additional flexibility in downwind limits.
In fact, data released by the Civil Aviation Authority shows that the number of people seriously and moderately affected by aircraft noise since the new runway opened has been cut by around half.

The EPA report is correct in warning of the noise problems that would be encountered if a return were made to regular operations on the east-west (cross) runway, and the Government welcomes the EPA's indication of the NSW Government's support for the current curfew arrangements.

(2) No. The noise readings in the NSW EPA report are consistent with predicted noise levels and Sydney Airport's Australian Noise Exposure Forecast (ANEF). The Draft Noise Management Plan and Environmental Impact Statement on Sydney Airport involved substantial public consultative processes.
(3) No. It is the EPA's misinterpretation of the contours which has led to recent claims that some suburbs likely to be affected by noise were never identified before the runway opened.

The published noise (ANEF) contours for Sydney Airport show areas where aircraft exposure is expected to reach certain levels. This does not mean that areas outside the contours are not exposed to aircraft noise, but that they experience lower levels of noise because of factors such as less frequent overflights and the height or type of aircraft.

(4) The CAA presented information to the Senate on 15 February 1995 concerning noise testing that it has been carrying out since the third runway was opened. Noise levels in the vicinity of the airport are being constantly monitored, and information will be made available to the community through consultative mechanisms which have recently been established.

(5) On 8 December 1994 the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport issued a detailed joint statement on the Government's noise management initiatives at Sydney Airport. In that statement, the Government announced that to improve monitoring, information and consultation with residents affected by aircraft noise, the Government would establish a new community consultative committee to monitor noise abatement and amelioration measures. The committee, which is now in place, will also provide residents in noise affected areas access to information about the Airport's operations. The committee, known as the Sydney Airport Community Consultative Committee, is chaired by the Chairman of Worksafe Australia, the Hon Joe Riordan.

Information released through this Committee to the community will include, for example, details of actions taken on any breaches of the curfew or breaches of the Airport's flight corridors, and summaries of the results of noise and air quality monitoring.
The Terms of Reference of the Committee is attached.

(6) The statement issued by the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport on 8 December 1994 following the public rally at Leichhardt Oval clearly explained the Government's noise amelioration package for affected residents, along with the Government's proposals to minimise the actual numbers of residents and suburbs affected. The statement also reaffirmed that operational noise controls at Sydney Airport would be strictly enforced, and reiterated that the east-west runway would remain available for use when weather conditions precluded take-offs and landings on the parallel runways for safety reasons.

The Government is concerned to ensure safe operations at the airport and that parallel runway operations are accepted internationally as providing an improvement in safety over intersecting operations.

The CAA, in a public statement on 30 November 1994, reaffirmed its position that, on safety grounds, it strongly advises against the use of the east-west runway in intersecting operations with the parallel north-south runway system.

The CAA's position is based on the following considerations: it has been accepted internationally that parallel runway operations are an improvement in safety over intersecting operations; more complex three runway configuration operations would increase workload and complexity for air traffic controllers and pilots, with conflicting traffic patterns both on the ground and in the air; a large number of aircraft would need to cross the active east-west runway to position for take-off on the parallel runways, or taxiing to the terminals after landing (it is estimated that aircraft would be expected to cross the east-west runway every 45 seconds or less); and with the use of the intersecting east-west runway, the required safety corridors to accommodate aircraft carrying out missed approaches could not be readily provided.
The Terms of Reference of the Committee are to
advise the Minister of Transport generally with respect to the abatement of aircraft noise and related environmental problems at Sydney Airport
monitor air space management around the Airport, including adherence to flight corridors and action in regard to possible breaches
monitor adherence to curfew regulations and action in regard to possible breaches
review the results of flight path, noise and air quality monitoring and consider the adequacy of current monitoring arrangements
examine the patterns of community complaints on Airport operations and the action taken to response to complaints
consider reports on the noise and health impacts of Airport operations
monitor progress with the implementation of the Government's acquisition and insulation program.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 6 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Have there been changes to the Government's foreign investment policy in relation to mass circulation newspapers that was enunciated on 20 April 1993; if so, please specify these changes.
(2) Does the 30 per cent foreign ownership restriction on mass circulation newspapers that was imposed in April 1993 include passive portfolio holdings.
(3) Is there any way that the total foreign interest involvement in a mass circulation newspaper can exceed 30 per cent; if so, please specify.

(4) Is the Government aware of any mass circulation newspaper in which the foreign interest investment currently or since 20 April 1993 has exceeded 30 per cent; if so, please provide details including: (a) the names of the newspapers; (b) the level and names of each foreign interest; and (c) when the total involvement exceeded 30 per cent, and in each case what action was taken.
(5) What mechanisms are in place to ensure that the Government is aware, or is made aware, that foreign interest involvement in mass circulation newspapers is in line with Government policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (3) Yes. The Government's foreign investment policy limits the total (non-portfolio) foreign interest involvement in a mass circulation newspaper to a maximum of 30 per cent, with a single foreign investor (and associates) restricted to a shareholding of up to 25 per cent and unrelated (non-portfolio) shareholdings restricted to 5 per cent. Total foreign involvement may exceed 30 per cent if there are unrelated passive portfolio holdings in addition to the non-portfolio holdings.
(4) The Government is not aware of any mass circulation newspaper in Australia in which the foreign (non-portfolio) investment since 20 April 1993 has exceeded or currently exceeds 30 per cent.

(5) Under the notification provisions of the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act 1975, all proposals to acquire a substantial interest (15 per cent or more) or to acquire any interest beyond 15 per cent in an Australian corporation with total gross assets of $5 million or more, require approval. In addition, under the Government's foreign investment policy as it applies to acquisitions in the media sector, all proposals by foreign interests to acquire an interest, irrespective of size, in a newspaper in Australia (except in relation to the Fairfax papers) are subject to a case-by-case examination. The maximum permitted non-portfolio foreign interest involvement in mass circulation newspapers by a single shareholder (and associates) is 25 per cent and unrelated foreign interests are allowed to have (non-portfolio) shareholdings of up to 5 per cent. In the case of newspapers other than the Fairfax group, portfolio holdings are normally interpreted as investment less than 15 per cent. In the case of the Fairfax Newspaper Group, foreign interests need not obtain prior approval to acquire portfolio shareholdings under 5 per cent, in cases where the foreign investor is neither related to any other Fairfax investor (including The Daily Telegraph and Hellman & Friedman), nor represented on the Fairfax Board. For the Fairfax newspapers, portfolio shareholdings are normally those of less than 5 per cent (press release of 23 April 1992).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 9 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) In deciding the amounts to be made available in funding for community welfare organisations, have Superannuation Guarantee Charge amounts now required to be paid by these organisations to their employees been taken into account?
(2) Has any assessment been done on the impact of the Superannuation Guarantee Charge on the ability of community welfare organisations to provide an adequate service to its clientele?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Direct assistance is provided by the Government to community social welfare organisations (CSWOs) for a variety of purposes such as aged care, disability services, employment programs and child care. In determining the level of funding for each individual program in these sectors, the Government takes into account a range of factors in addition to the actual cost, such as the level of demand for the service, the efficiency of the program in meeting its specified outcomes, and the potential for overlap with other State and Territory programs, as well as the appropriateness of the program and the level of funding in the context of the overall economic environment. Once the overall level of funding is decided, a variety of methods is used to index programs for changes in wage and other costs so as to enable outputs to be maintained in the face of rising costs over time. These arrangements can involve indexation by changes in earnings based measures or changes in broad based indexes such as the consumer price index, or some mixture of the two. Thus, to the extent that the impact of the introduction of the Superannuation Guarantee Charge (SGC) in 1992 was reflected in the indexation factors used at that time, supplementation for the SGC would have occurred through the indexation arrangements.

(2) The terms of reference for the inquiry that the Industry Commission is currently undertaking into community social welfare organisations (CSWOs) provide the scope for an assessment of: the effectiveness of current government financial or other assistance to CSWOs; the appropriateness of the present taxation treatment of charitable organisations; and the effect of relevant industrial arrangements. The terms of reference provide an avenue for the impact of the SGC on CSWOs to be raised by CSWOs and assessed by the Industry Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 23 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that leakage and seepage from the Fimiston II tailings dam operated by Kalgoorlie Consolidated Gold Mines Pty Ltd (KCGM) is affecting sub soil aquifers in the vicinity of the Australian National Railway (ANR) line referred to as Trans Australian Railway Hampton Location 32; if so, how did the Minister come to be aware of this problem.
(2) Is the railway line suffering from subsidence due to the rising of the water table as a result of the Fimiston II tailings dam; if so, what action will be taken to fix the problem.

(3) What risk is there to Commonwealth property, trains, freight and passengers from the weakening of the foundations of the rail track by the high ground water levels caused by leakage and seepage from the KCGM Fimiston II tailings dam on Trans Australian Railway Reserve Hampton Location 32.

(4) What action will be taken to ensure that no elevation or contamination of groundwater occurs on Commonwealth property and that Trans Australian Railway Reserve Hampton Location 32 is not affected by pollution from the KCGM Fimiston II tailings dam.

(5) Can confirmation be given that either KCGM, Homestake Gold of Australia Ltd, North Kalgurli Mines Pty Ltd or Kalgoorlie Lake View Pty Ltd wrote to ANR indicating that water levels were rising on Trans Australian Railway Hampton Location 32 as a result of the Fimiston II tailings dam, seeking an agreement or permission to construct seepage interceptor trenches and monitoring bores on land which is part of the Trans Australian Railway Hampton Location 32.

(6) (a) Is the Minister aware of the current planned extensions to the Fimiston II tailings dam which has the potential to significantly impact upon Trans Australian Railway Hampton Location 32; (b) has the Minister considered the impacts of the tailings dam extensions on the railway; (c) what is the Minister's assessment of those impacts; and (d) what conditions has or will the Minister impose on those extensions to prevent further pollution such as saline, alkaline, cyanide or heavy metal constituents onto Trans Australian Railway Hampton Location 32.

(7) Were pre-existing drill holes under the proposed Fimiston II tailings dam required to be plugged to prevent leakage and seepage of pollution to Trans Australian Railway Hampton Location 32; if not, why not.

(8) Will a confirmation be given that there are seepage interceptor trenches constructed near the Fimiston II tailings dam operated by KCGM on the Commonwealth Trans Australian Railway Hampton Location 32 property.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian National Railways Commission (AN) recently advised the Department of Transport of this matter. The following information has been provided by AN.

(2) and (3) The Trans Australian Railway is not presently suffering from subsidence, and site inspections before the recent cyclonic rain indicated that ground water levels were falling from an observed high of 2m below natural surface to approximately 3m below natural surface. The embankment on which the line is built at this location remained stable even when the entire area was recently saturated by water from the creek system after recent cyclonic rain. AN considers that there is negligible risk to Commonwealth property, trains, freight and passengers from current groundwater levels.

(4) and (5) KCGM advised AN on 25 June and 19 July 1993 of the need to construct interceptor trenches and monitoring bores on AN land and permission was given for this construction. AN has also co-operated with KCGM to allow installation of an upgraded power supply and further pipe work needed to ensure any rising water is disposed of effectively.

(6) KCGM has advised AN that extensions to the dam would take place north of the existing dam. The extensions are being constructed on ground well above the Hannans Lake water course, and the relevant WA government authorities are aware of the findings of KCGM's hydro-geological study. AN has no reason to believe that pollution concerns have not been addressed by the relevant authorities.
(7) AN has no knowledge of pre-existing drill holes under the Fimiston II tailings dam as KCGM did not consult AN during the design stage of the dam.

(8) Seepage indicator trenches are constructed on AN land to control the rising ground water levels. KCGM has sunk additional bores to intercept ground water and these are located on the dam side of the interceptor trenches.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Job Placement and Employment Training Program

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, upon notice, on 29 March 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it correct that the pilot job placement and employment training (JPET) program, aimed at improving the employment prospects of young homeless people, has recently been evaluated and found outstandingly successful.
(2) Can confirmation be given of the continuation of the JPET program.

(3) Is the Government giving consideration to shifting the program to the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET); if so, why, given the success of the program under its present structure and management.
(4)(a) Have the coordinators of the JPET program been consulted about this possible shift; and (b) what has been their reaction.
(5) Is the Minister aware that those people `at the coalface' working in the JPET program are extremely concerned about how such a shift would affect the program.

(6) Does the Minister acknowledge the characteristics of the JPET program which have made it so successful, namely that: (a) it is voluntary; (b) it is informal; (c) the expert case workers are given considerable autonomy both with respect to the approach taken and their decision as to the number of cases that can be effectively handled at one time; and (d) there are no formal targets or rigid performance criteria.
(7) Does the Minister acknowledge that this contrasts with the approach to case management of DEET, which can be characterised as invasive, compulsory, formalistic and formula based.
(8) On these grounds, will the Minister dismiss any consideration being given to shifting the JPET program to DEET and deny the rumours that such a shift is imminent.
(9) Will a guarantee be given that, if the program is shifted to the DEET portfolio, the essential characteristics of the JPET program will be protected.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Housing and Regional Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The recently completed national evaluation of JPET found that JPET had been very successful in providing flexible services to assist young homeless people into open employment, achieving similar levels of success as other comparable labour market programs. However, the evaluation also identified a significant and increasing overlap with initiatives under Working Nation arrangements.

(2) The pilot phase of the JPET program will conclude on 30/6/95, after which it will be integrated with the arrangements under Working Nation to ensure that young homeless people have greater access to the range of new programs now available. However, clients of the JPET program who have not completed their JPET programs at 30/6/95 will be assisted to complete them.

(3) When JPET commenced operation there were no similar programs offering case management for this group of young people. Since then, new initiatives have been introduced under the Working Nation arrangements, including case management which may be provided by public or private case managers. Wherever possible, young people choose whether their case manager is from the public sector agency, Employment Assistance Australia, or from private, community or other organisations accredited and contracted by the Employment Services Regulatory Authority (ESRA). A number of JPET services have been accredited and contracted by ESRA to provide case management services.

(4) The JPET evaluation included an extensive process of consultation with service coordinators, workers and clients. Their views and reactions have been considered in both the evaluation report and decisions regarding the program's future.

(5) Yes, the Government is aware of the views of JPET workers regarding the future of the program and wherever possible took those views into consideration in arriving at its decision. However, it needs to be stressed that this program is a pilot which has always been scheduled to conclude on 30 June 1995 and it is in the best interests of clients to gain access to the full range of labour market assistance through the Working Nation arrangements.

(6) Most of these elements were referred to in the evaluation as contributing to the success of JPET. It should be noted however that JPET services were expected to meet performance targets and often developed formal agreements with their clients.

(7) No. The Youth Training Initiative (YTI) was implemented as a new approach to assist young unemployed people to gain access to suitable education, training or work experience through the provision of increased levels of support. The new case management arrangements under Working Nation are designed to be flexible and meet the individual needs of clients. Many JPET clients are already in receipt of case management services under YTI arrangements.

(8) No. As noted above, the pilot phase of the JPET program will conclude on 30 June 1995 and the interests of clients in the longer term will best be served by the integration of JPET with the arrangements under Working Nation.

(9) Yes. Case management arrangements under Working Nation support the job seeker in his or her search for work, providing assistance on a one to one basis. To ensure that the considerable expertise that JPET services have developed in providing flexible, individual support to young homeless people is not lost, JPET services that have not already done so will be encouraged to apply for accreditation and funding through Working Nation initiatives.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 5 April 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the issue of Trans Australian Railway Hampton Location 32 which may be affected by seepage from the Fimiston II tailings dam ('the dam') operated by Kalgoorlie Consolidated Gold Mines Pty Ltd (KCGM):
(1) Is vegetation showing signs of being under stress and dying as a result of seepage from the dam near the interceptor trenches located on Trans Australian Railway Hampton Location 32.
(2) Will any action be taken to ensure that the operator of the dam, KCGM, is made to clean up the contamination of the soil and sub-surface ground water on Location 32.
(3) Are monitoring bores located on Location 32 property near the dam; if so, how many are located on Location 32.

(4) Does the operator of the dam take samples from all of the monitoring bores and interceptor trenches located on Location 32 and provide the analysis of samples to Australian National Rail (ANR); if so, how frequently is the sampling done and analysis provided to ANR; if not, why not and will the operator be requested to do so.

(5) Does the operator of the dam measure water levels in the monitoring bores on Location 32 and provide the levels of ground water to ANR from all the monitoring bores; if so, how frequently are they measured; if not, why not and will the operator be requested to do so.

(6) Are samples taken by the operator of the dam or by ANR from all, or any, of the monitoring bores and interceptor trenches analysed for any of the following: cyanide, xanthate, copper, zinc, cobalt, gold, lead, mercury, arsenic, sulphate, total dissolved solids, sodium, aluminium or iron.
(7) Have any of the samples from the monitoring bores or interceptor trenches on Location 32 exhibited any levels of cyanide.

(8) Does ANR independently sample and check the samples from all the monitoring bores and interceptor trenches and submit for analysis to check the accuracy for any results received from the operator of the dam; if not, why not.
(9) In what month and year were interceptor trenches near the dam installed on Location 32.

(10) Is water seeping from the dam containing saline, alkaline, cyanide or heavy metal constituents a danger to people and the environment; if not, please provide information to show that there is no discernible danger or environmental impact from this water.
(11) Please provide a map showing the location of monitoring bores, monitoring bore numbers and interceptor trenches installed on Location 32 in relation to the dam.
(12) What is the analysis of samples taken from Location 32.

(14) Is it normal practice to allow companies or individuals to pollute Commonwealth Trans Australia Railway property as is the case for KCGM with the Fimiston II tailings dam.
(15) What is the approximate total cost per 500m of Trans Australian Railway track should the Trans Australian Railway need to be moved because of pollution from the dam.

(16) If the Trans Australian Railway line needs to be relocated or have any work done on the foundations caused through leakage and seepage from the dam, will the taxpayers of Australia be funding this or will the operator of the dam, KCGM, or the owner be made to pay the cost of such works.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 1 May 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are security contracts for Department of Defence buildings in the Australian Capital Territory (ACT) offered for tender through the Commercial Support Program (CSP), or independent of the CSP.
(2) If these contracts are offered through the CSP, who is responsible for drawing-up these security contracts.

(3) If these contracts are not offered through the CSP, who is responsible for the formulation of the contracts and are they formulated by a Defence committee, or are they drawn-up by an individual officer.
(4) If these contracts are not offered for tender through the CSP, who is responsible for awarding the contracts.
(5) Is the contract for the security of Russell Offices soon to be renegotiated.
(6) Who is currently responsible for security at Campbell Park, Russell Offices and ANZAC Park West Offices and are they guarded by Defence employees or contract staff.

(7) Is there a potential for corruption under the current security arrangements that protect Defence office buildings in the ACT and is the Minister certain that there is no conflict of interest between officers involved in the awarding of the contracts and the staff of the security firm providing the service.

(8) Have there been allegations of wrong-doing against security staff at any Defence installations in the ACT during the past year; if so, was any such matter referred to the Inspector-General's office for investigation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1)&(2) Security guarding contracts are offered through commercial contracting arrangements, but not under the Commercial Support Program.

(3)&(4) In considering possible contracts, an evaluation team is nominated by the project manager (Regional Security Manager—ACT) and the selection of this team is approved by the Assistant Secretary, Security, prior to the request for tender being released. The tender is assessed by the Assistant Secretary, Security.
Tenders are evaluated by the evaluation team and recommendations made to the Assistant Secretary, Security who makes the final decision.

The contract is drawn-up by a member of the evaluation team in consultation with all other members of the team. Contracts are formulated in accordance with the Capital Equipment Procurement manual and guidelines provided by the Defence Contracting Organisation.
(6) Campbell Park and Anzac Park West offices are guarded by contract staff and Russell offices is guarded by the Government guarding service, the Australian Protective Service.

(7) Security guarding contracts are let in accordance with standard departmental contracting procedures. As indicated in the answer to question 3, these require all tenders and contracts to be considered by an evaluation team that may include staff from outside of the Defence Security Branch and can involve consultation with the Defence Contracting Organisation.
Organisations not successful in winning contracts may obtain statements of reasons for and explanations of decisions affecting them.
All decisions can be subject to both internal and external audit. There are, therefore, thorough systems of checks and balances and accountability for all decisions.
Against this background, the Department is unaware of any conflicts of interest between staff involved in the awarding of the guarding contracts and any outside organisations.

(2) What will be the cost to CSIRO of its involvement in this interpretive centre for Skyrail.
(3) Will the centre be open to the general public or only people who pay to travel on the Skyrail.
(4) Will the CSIRO receive any financial return based upon the number of people passing through the interpretive centre.
(5) Will people be required to pay a specific fee to experience the interpretive centre.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) CSIRO is constructing an interpretive display on tropical rainforests in a building provided by Skyrail Ltd, the operators of a cable-car between Cairns and Kuranda.

(2) CSIRO will provide interactive displays for the interpretive centre at a cost of $150,000 and in-kind expertise to the value of $70,000. (4) As outlined above, Skyrail will be meeting a large proportion of the initial and ongoing costs of the display. This provides CSIRO a very cost-effective means of communicating to a wide audience about global conservation values of tropical rainforests, and about CSIRO's work in this area.
